Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: Mr Speaker, I inform the House that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has resigned as Treasurer. The Governor General has appointed me to that office- you told him?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: We will leave that to another day. May I say, in addition to that, Mr SPEAKER - until further ministerial arrangements are settled. NA  Speaker, I rise on a matter of privilege that is based on news reports concerning a Mr Bill Ludwig, the Queensland Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, and certain comments that he is reported to have made in relation to the unsuccessful challenge by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). I am raising this matter at the earliest possible opportunity in accordance with the practice that the House adopts with respect to questions of parliamentary privilege. It has been reported in many places that Mr Ludwig has publicly said that, if certain parliamentary members of the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party voted for the honourable member for Blaxland, those members would lose their preselection. The matter has received extensive coverage in the written press, on radio and on television. I am producing for you, Sir, extracts of the following newspaper articles: an article in today's Australian Financial Review entitled 'Hawke's key Queensland bloc begins to disintegrate'; an article in Saturday's edition of the Canberra Times entitled 'Defender of Women fights also for the PM'; and an article from today's edition of the Australian entitled, 'Hogg accused of blatant intervention for Keating-row puts Labor in dreadful position'. I am also producing full copies of the newspapers. I trust that the extracts will be authorised as true extracts so that I may return the newspapers to the Parliamentary Library.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: Why don't you buy your own?  need to buy my own today. I heard it everywhere. I refer to the article in today's edition of the Australian Financial Review, where it is said: AWU State Secretary Mr Bill Ludwig has said publicly that those who vote for Mr Keating will not be endorsed by party members. It is my submission that the conduct of Mr Ludwig amounts to a contempt of Parliament in that compliance with his demands by the relevant parliamentary members of the Labor Party would result in those members being inhibited in the performance of their duties as members of parliament and as members of this House. In this respect, the comments made by Mr Ludwig amount to intimidation or, at the very least, improper interference.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: What about Kennett?  interjecting, and clearly rejects this view, he being a comrade in arms recently of Mr Ludwig, but the mere gratitude displayed by the Prime Minister is not sufficient to let Mr Ludwig off this one. It would seem that, contrary to the Prime Minister's view, others share my view. For example, in today's edition of the Australian, Mr Bob Hogg, the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, is reported, in reference to Mr Ludwig's comments, to have said: The raising of it in my view reflected the concern that exists about possible intimidation under the current circumstances we have in terms of the federal parliamentary leadership. In a similar vein, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) is reported in today's edition of the Canberra Times as follows: "I'm . . . totally dissatisfied with the interfer- reward. ence of the AWU, the union in Queensland", he said on ABC radio. "And I find it a little bit distasteful that the Queensland secretary of that union is now speaking on behalf of elected Members of Parliament in that State on that issue. I totally disrespect the AWU and their part in politics in Queensland and in particular in the Australian Labor Party." Section 73 of the Crimes Act 1914 says that it is a criminal offence for a person who, in order to influence or affect a member in the exercise of his duty or authority as a member, gives or confers or promises or offers to give or confer any benefit of any kind to or on the member. That offence carries a penalty of imprisonment for two years. It is my submission that prima facie the conduct of Mr Ludwig falls within the ambit of this provision. The question I put before you, Mr Speaker, relates to parliamentary privilege, and I have made reference to the Crimes Act in order to highlight the seriousness of the matter under consideration. I turn now to consider briefly the question of parliamentary privilege. At page 706 of House of Representatives Practice, it says: To attempt by any improper means to influence a Member in his or her conduct as Member is a contempt. So too is any conduct having a tendency to impair a Member's independence in the future performance of his or her duty. At pages 707 and 708, reference is madc to a number of precedents which give effect to the principle that I have mentioned. In particular, reference is made to a report in 1947 by the United Kingdom House of Commons Committee of Privileges. There the Committee went to the trouble of elaborating upon the nature of the relevant head of privilege and what conduct may constitute a breach of that head of privilege. The Committee says: It is a breach of privilege to take or threaten action which is not merely calculated to affect the Member's course of action in Parliament, but is of a kind against which it is absolutely necessary that Members should be protected if they are to discharge their duties as such independently and without fear of punishment or hope of A restatement of this principle can be found in section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. Having regard to section 4, and in its terms, quite clearly Mr Ludwig's comments were designed or calculated to inhibit or interfere, or at the very least would have had the likely effect of inhibiting or interfering, with the performance of the parliamentary duties of the relevant members concerned. Finally, I note that on 13 September 1990 you, Mr Speaker, had cause to consider a similar case involving a letter from a Melbourne firm of solicitors directed to the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). On 17 September, after considering the principles and the precedents to which I have referred, you decided to give precedence to a motion to refer that matter to the Standing Committee of Privileges. This case, under present circumstances, in my view, is far more serious than the case you were concerned with in September last year. It is my submission, having regard to the relevant law and the practice and the ruling you gave on 17 September last year, that the matter under present consideration involves an important question of privilege. As such, it should be referred to the Committee of Privileges so that the House may have the benefit of its advice. In accordance with standing order 96 I leave the matter with you to decide the question of whether the matter involves a prima facie case of breach of privilege.

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Title: RURAL ECONOMY
text: Will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the House of the role played by the Australian Agrict;tltural Council in developing policies for a sustainable agriculture? During a time of undoubted hardship in the bush, what are the implications for the direction of agricultural policy?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: RURAL ECONOMY
text: As the honourable member has said, with the situation in the wool and wheat industries in particular, times arc very tough in the bush. We also recognise that some of the downturn and recession has not uniformly spread through the rural sector. It is very important that because difficulties facing individuals are more a consequence of specific commodity downturns rather than a function of general factors, we need to ensure that at the national level it is important that short term difficulties that some farmers find themselves in do not contribute to a long term decline in sustainability and profitability. Therefore, the appropriate response is to focus on long term structural reform-that is what this Government has been doing-not on short term palliatives, as would be put up by the people opposite, while ensuring that those who are suffering have access to adequate support. Quite by accident, I have here a report on sustainable agriculture. Members of the House who have an interest in this-that is mainly on my side-would be aware of the Australian Agricultural Council, which is the prime forum for Commonwealth State consultation. At its meeting in February 1990 the Australian Agricultural Council agreed to focus its work on the development of sustainable agriculture. The Council commissioned a standing committee to prepare a report on sustainable agriculture that would focus on the problems and solutions by identifying changes that may be required to ensure sustainability, examining research, analysis and extension activity needed to promote .such changes, and recommending changes to government policies. This report has been well regarded. Now that it has been published, I certainly advise honourable members that it is well worth a read. The Agricultural Council has provided initial direction and useful resource development for the working group on ecologically sustainable agriculture. As well, the information that is being assembled and the analysis and the expertise of the contributors to the report will be of great value in implementing the relevant sections of the ecologically sustainable development strategy. I emphasise that what we have here is an issue of substance, not gloss. It is an example of the Government getting on with the hard work during very hard times. NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! I warn the member for Gippsland.

Speaker: Mr SIMMONS
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I thank the honourable member for Dobell for that question, although I point out to honourable members that I am sure he meant Expo 92 in Seville. It is 11 months until the opening of Expo 92, and planning is very well advanced as far as the Australian Government is concerned. I am happy to report to the House that the project is both on time and, importantly, within budget. Construction of the Australian pavilion is scheduled for completion to fit-out stage by the end of this current year. The Expo in Seville next year will be a significant one by world standards. It is certainly the largest this century; to give honourable members an indication of just how large it is, the site will be five times the size of the site of Expo 88 in Brisbane. The theme of Expo 92 is the Age of Discovery, which focuses upon the SOOth anniversary of Christopher Columbus's voyage of discovery to the Americas. Consistent with this approach, the theme for Australia's pavilion at Expo 92 will be 'Australia: discover, explore and experience'. The Australian pavilion site is located in a very prominent position. It will be a very imposing building: five storeys high incorporating a series of exhibits, a 600-seat audio-visual theatre and a small rainforest atrium. Overall, the pavilion will be about two-thirds the size of the Australian National Library, and it is expected to attract about 4lj2 million visitors during Expo. During Expo 92 itself, the Spanish Government is expecting some 40 million visits during that six-month period. Importantly, many of those visitations will come from the northern European countries, those countries that do have very strong economies and-importantly from Australia's perspective, from a trade and tourism perspective-that have very high disposable incomes, particularly countries such as England, Germany, Switzelland, Sweden and Italy. From a tourism perspective, the Australian pavilion will complement the marketing strategy that has already been put in place so successfully by the Australian Tourist Commission, and we expect that there will be continuing high growth of international visitors as a result of our participation in Seville next year. Importantly, of course, 1992 sees the emergence of the single European market, and it is important that Australia does seek to use its opportunities there, both in trade and tourism promotion terms, to make the best of that. I understand that the Australian Trade - ommission is certainly cooperating in that regard. Recently, I had the pleasure to announce a joint venture between the Australia Council and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's ABC Enterprises which was successful with its tender to operate a retail concession at our site at Expo 92. The joint venture partnersthat is, the Australia Council and ABC Enterprises-will consult with a whole range of arts industry experts in selecting and commissioning works for sale and will represent the very best in Australian art and culture. So it is very much in keeping with our emphasis in promoting Australia as a centre for cultural tourism, because a large number of visitors who come to Australia, principally as tourists, also want to experience something about the Australian culture. Recent figures on visitations to museums and art galleries certainly bear testimony to that particular fact. Further focus on Australia's people will be provided by some 45 pavilion attendants, who will form an integral part of our pavilion's communication strategy and certainly will serve as young ambassadors for this country. I am aware of an enormous amount of interest in those positions. Indeed, I have had several representations from members on both sides of this Parliament who have in fact sought more information about these pavilion attendant positions. My Department will be calling for applications for those positions in the national press on Saturday, 6 July of this year, and we are certainly expecting a very large number. Qantas Airways Ltd and Argyle Diamond will also join the Commonwealth as major corporate sponsors in the pavilion, and negotiations are already under way with several very significant Australian companies in regard to the pavilion's official supplier program. In conclusion, I believe that the next 11 months will see an important culmination of the planning, the funding, the training and the preparation by this Government to achieve the most significant presence ever of Australia at an international exposition. All is in place for a very highly successful, highly regarded Australian presence in Seville in 1992. NA

Speaker: Mr HAWKE

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: HAWKE GOVERNMENT

Secondly, let me point out that the idea that there has been some monopoly on ideas is not correct. The situation is that this Government, through the whole of its period and through this term of office, has had a situation where the Cabinet as a whole has made a very significant contribution to the whole range of relevant Government policy for this country. Without being exhaustive about this, it was the Minister for Community Services and Health who revamped the social security system, directing resources to those in need, with particular emphasis on the family allowance supplement, who is comprehensively reviewing Medicare, and who was the original proponent of the better cities concept. He will see those proposals through from his new post as Deputy Prime Minister. Senator Button has had responsibility for our successful steel industry plan and other industry policy initiatives, for truly historic tariff reform, and for initiatives to support research and development in this country. May I say that the cooperative research centres, the Ballarat speech in 1987 committing us as to a microeconomic reform agenda, the Special Premiers Conference process with its unique ability to create nationally consistent laws and overhaul Commonwealth State financial relations, the 1990 round of microeconomic reforms, including telecommunications and the role of the airlines, and the recent waterfront negotiations were all contributions in which I was able to be very significantly involved. The deregulation of grain handling, the deregulation of oil marketing, the rescue of the wool industry, reforms to the sugar, tobacco, citrus and dried fruit industries, and the promotion of the interests of rural Australia arc only part of the contribution that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has made. The list goes on: environment protection; foreign policy; education reforms boosting payments to students; numbers of places at university and retention rates; defence, with a succession of overhauls and equipment, manpower, and contracting out to ensure that we have an effective fighting force. Those are simply some of the range of not merely ideas but of effective policy implementation which has been engaged in by a whole range of members of my Cabinet. There is still a lot more that will be done by this range of talent. The following initiatives, for instance, are in train and will be delivered over the next 12 months or so: the Medicare review-Opposition members-Ha, hal

The initiator of that is the Minister for Community Services and Health, the Deputy Prime Minister. That will be going on and there will, as I say, be the amelioration under that program of locational disadvantage by addressing problems of access to employment, education and services faced by people living in particular areas, such as the outer fringes of major cities and rural and remote areas. Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: HAWKE GOVERNMENT
text: It will maintain the structural integrity of the Budget while providing an effective level of support for the recovery which will start to become evident in the second half of this year. There will be a further ratcheting down in inflation. I say to those opposite who try to jump onto this particular bandwagon that all they could do was give to this country a legacy of double digit inflation. We have brought down the underlying rate of inflation to in the order of 4 per cent. We will continue during the rest of to this term of government to create what for the last generation has been a unique achievement, that is, having a rate of inflation in this country lower than that of the Organ1sation for Economic Cooperation and Development-the first time that has been achieved for virtually a generation. There will be a continuing focus on the means of underpinning the major initiatives in science, research and development under the clever country initiative. This is a government of and for the 1990s. It is the case, and I deeply regret it, that we have lost one of our better performers-of course we have-and we will miss him. 1 acknowledge that fact and I regret it, but I am saying that this Government has the resources, the talent, the skill, the will, the commitment and the purpose to emerge from this traumatic process, through which we have admittedly gone, better, stronger and even more prepared to put the interests of the ordinary Australians of this country first. Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL COUNCIL
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: given the appalling performance of the Australian Wool Council and the fact that the preselect committee that is to determine the makeup of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is heavily loaded with Wool Council hacks and we cannot, therefore, be very sure of the result of it, will he undertake to personally approach the Wool Realisation Commission and ask it to have a good look at the Todhunter zero coupon bond proposal, as it appears to be the only thing that can take from around the necks of wool growers the 15 per cent tax?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL COUNCIL
text: There are quite a few assumptions and premises in the honourable gentleman's question. I think he should understand that there is a need to keep the wool industry well and truly involved as it manages its way, trades its way, through the stockpile and the debt, and the wool industry has indicated its clear desire to do just that. It follows from that that the Wool Council of Australia, which is the peak body of the woolgrowing industry, should be involved. Mr Beale-Bob said he had fixed this problem. Mr Costello-Forget it. Mr Beale-It has been rescued.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL COUNCIL
text: Order! The honourable member for Bruce and the honourable member for Higgins will cease in terj ecting.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL COUNCIL
text: Are you right now, fellows? It has been a long-held principle with respect to statutory marketing authorities that the levy payers-and that is, in this case, the wool growers-should have a role and a say in terms of who goes on the statutory marketing authority boards, particularly as they are the levy payers. Given the circumstances in the industry and that the Government and the taxpayers are also now well and truly very big stakeholders, I have changed that from a majority of Wool Council members to a 3 : 3 : 1 split with respect to the selection committee. But the honourable gentleman should also take into account that the way I have specified the very boards themselves, where it is up to a maximum of two growers, there is really no way that the Wool Council, particularly in the way that he describes it, can dominate or dictate who shall go on the relevant bodies. As well as that, the role and functions of the new Wool Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commiss10n are fundamentally different. There is no longer a reserve price scheme, which was the centrepiece of all the Wool Corporation's powers. So we have a totally different situation; we have a different selection procedure. The honourable gentleman mentions one of several methods whereby the Wool Realisation Commission may sell the stockpile. I will certainly convey Mr Todhunter's proposal to Mr David Clark and the Wool Realisation Commission board when it is elected. But I would assure him that it is only one of many, many ways, and I have full faith in that board, when it has been constructed, to get on with the job of rem'oving the stockpile.

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I move: That this House has no confidence in the Prime Minister. Mr Speaker, there are 148 members in this House and there are 76 senators. The majority of them no longer have confidence in the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The 103 people on our side of the two Houses certainly have no confidence in the Prime Minister, and now there are 44 on the other side of the Houses who have today voted 'no confidence' in the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has lost the confidence of the Parliament and, what is worse, he has lost the confidence of the Australian people. They have been lied to-repeatedly lied to-and they have been betrayed by this Government. They have lost confidence in his personal integrity and they have lost confidence in the integrity of his Government. The people have lost confidence in the Prime Minister and his Government because they have shown a disregard for the truth, a disregard for honesty, a disregard for openness about themselves and about our economic circumstances. It is now clear that during and after the 1990 election the Prime Minister lied to the Australian people about his future in the job and about recession. This Government has taken the Australian people for granted and, what is worse, in many cases it has simply treated them as irrelevant. The bottom line of all the infighting and all the secret deals within this Government is that they have undermined the basic principles of parliamentary democracy in this country. Orders Let me go first to the issue of the Prime Minister's personal integrity. The Prime Minister claims to be a man who prides himself on his integrity. He claims that his word should always be taken seriously. He claims that he can be trusted. He claims that he has some special kind of relationship with the Australian people, a relationship he once described, in very romantic terms, as a love affair with the Australian people. All these pretensions by the Prime Minister have now been totally blown away. I said last Thursday in this Parliament, in a debate about the advertising ban and disclosure, that this Prime Minister has no principles, no sincerity and, most importantly, has lost the sense of what is right. The only thing he thinks that is right is what has to be done to ensure his own political survival. Looking back on those words just four days ago, how prophetic they were. We thought it was bad enough, for example, when he failed to act in relation to what he should have known to be right and proper in relation to Brian Burke. The evidence was overwhelming, the damage to our international reputation was significant, and yet he let Brian Burke continue as our Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See-simply because he was a mate. As I have said previously in this House, the tragedy of that is that even Brian Burke, in his moment of disgrace, had a better idea of what was right than the Prime Minister had. All the Prime Minister ever thought about was what was in his own best interests and what he thought was essential to his own political survival. There is currently before this Parliament legislation in relation to the advertising ban and disclosure, which again shows just how low the Prime Minister will stoop. in order to ensure his political survival-even to the point of sacrificing one of the basic principles of our democratic system, namely the right of free speech, just so that he can make our lives difficult going into the next election, just so that he can make it difficult for us to get our message across, to advertise, just because those opposite have not got the capacity any more, as a divided shambles of a government, to raise money in order to fund themselves through the next election campaign. The Prime Minister does not care. He judges every issue by what is good for, or what is essential to, his personal survival, not what is in the best interests of the people of Australia, and that is why they hold him in contempt. The Prime Minister has betrayed the trust of the people of Australia because they know, out of this particular incident, how he was prepared to trade the prime ministership of this country like a sack of potatoes. They know that he did a deal with the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). They know that he mortgaged his high office and the future of this country as the essence of that deal. They know that he then went out and knowingly and deliberately perpetrated a fraud on them at the last election. They know that he welshed on that deal, as the ex-Treasurer has gone out of his way in recent days to draw to the attention of anybody who would listen. We know that, right through those circumstances in particular, he proved himself as a man who can no longer be trusted. By his own actions and by his own words, he has forfeited the right to respect by the people of Australia. Let us go back through the appalling and unforgettable episode of the Kirribilli House conspiracy. It is a classic case of deception and double-dealing, and it shows how deeply run the mistrust and suspicion that underlie that false mateship of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). Indeed, as the Speaker himself recently said, there are no friends in Canberra, just permanent interests, and that applies among the Labor Party members. Honourable members can forget all the phoney talk in recent months about Labor mateship; when mateship is put to the test, at times it crumbles-as shown in the last few days when the Prime Minister demonstrated his capacity to welsh on a deal. I have said in this Parliament for months that this Labor Government is built on deals. It is built on deals with union leaders, deals with faction leaders, deals with big business, deals with extreme greenies, deals with some ethnic groups and deals with the Australian Democrats. Deals, deals and more deals! I guess the ALP has produced a manual on how to do deals and when one should do deals. Under this Government, everything has been reduced to a deal. If Government members have a problem, for example, they should do a deal. If they still have a problem, they should do another deal. If things still do not turn out right, they should do a secret deal. If something still goes wrong, they should go out and deny the deal ever happened or blame somebody else for what has happened. Deals are the essential elements of the basic approach of this Government to its survival. Now we have the evidence, disturbingly, of the biggest, the most secret, the most undemocratic and the most unjustifiable deal of them all-a deal to deal the prime ministership of this Australia like some sack of potatoes, without reference to the party in government or the Caucus, without reference to the Parliament and, most importantly, without reference to the people of Australia. It was without equal as the ultimate deal of this Government and it will be the essence of the collapse of this Government. A government that lives by deals dies by deals, and the daddy of all deals will make sure that the Government dies on the basis of it alone. That deal was to deliver to the honourable member for Blaxland what he could never win in his own right, the keys to the Lodge. Throughout the life of this deal, which was born in secrecy at Kirribilli House, the Prime Minister and his former Deputy, the honourable member for Blaxland, consistently deceived the Australian\ people and each other. They broke their promises to the people and they broke their promises to each other. As far as we know, this matter started back about the time of the ex-Treasurer's statement about a 'Bring home the bacon' Budget in August 1988, after which the Prime Minister, obviously embarrassed by the publicity that the Treasurer got at the time, made it known the Treasurer was not indispensable. About that time, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in a direct frontal attack on the Prime Minister, told the Prime Minister that it was time to go. Mr Dobie-Full frontal?

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Yes. Those opposite do not stab each other in the back; they do it at the front. The Prime Minister acknowledged that the honourable member for Blaxland should succeed him, but not yet. He did not want to go into the 1990 election looking like a lame duck leader, as he has admitted in the Parliament today. But the honourable member for Blaxland, suspicious of his Prime Minister, unable to trust his Prime Minister, wanted more than just a nod; he wanted a solemn pledge and he wanted witnesses. He did not trust the Prime Minister, and how right the honourable member for Blaxland was not to do so. lt is fascinating that the witnesses chosen on this occasion were Sir Peter Abeles for the Prime Minister and Bill Kelty for the honourable member for Blaxland. They represented big business and big unions, the natural partners of the Hawke Labor Government. Can honourable members imagine the scene at Kirribilli House, with the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland, Bill and Sir Peter all sitting around-the champions of the Australian workers-trading the prime ministership of this country? Trading the prime ministership were one of the richest businessmen in Australia and one of the most blatant and antagonistic union bosses-the one who has had all the veto power over most policy reform over the last few years. Can honourable members imagine having him there to make sure that this deal went through in the way that at the time they all thought it should? I bet people down in the pubs of Coburg and people in the factories and supermarkets are impressed by that deal and its grubbiness. The fact that the Prime Minister was prepared to do a deal on the prime ministership of this country, without reference to the people of Australia, his own Caucus or anybody else, in the presence of those two people is absolutely staggering-beyond the belief, I am sure, of most average Australians. It shows just how out of touch the Prime Minister has become when he feels that he can go out, look people straight in the eye and have no repercussions from having traded so lightly with the prime ministership of this country. Today the Prime Minister is trying to defend his indef\!nsible conduct, but he has only got himself into a bigger hole. In his press conference today he referred to the fact that it was as a result of Bill Kelty's initiative that the deal took place. If it was not bad enough as it was first described, it is much worse when one figures on the fact that it was Bill 'Kelty who dictated that there ought to be a deal and that there ought to be witnesses to the deal. Who runs this country-the Prime Minister or Bill Kelty? Just look at all the deals that have been done; look at all the reform that has been blocked by Bill Kelty. There is an old statement, of course, that if Bob Hawke had really wanted to run the country he should have stayed as head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There is no doubt that Bill Kelty has had an unbelievable influence over this Government to the detriment of the Government, to the detriment of the Labor Party and to the detriment of all workers in Australia. The deal was done and nobody was to know about it. On no fewer than eight occasions after November 1988 until early 1991 the Prime Minister publicly stated that he would serve out his full three-year term to the next parliament, all the time knowing he had promised the former Treasurer that he did not intend to do so. Honourable members might remember that in February 1991 Senator Button thought they had a deal and he said so publicly. What did the 'prime Minister say about Senator Button? He said: Despite, and let me be quite clear about this, the gratuitous and incorrect observation of Senator Button, I will serve a full term. Senator Button doesn't know what he is talking about. It is as simple as that. I simply believe that the electorate will believe mehonourable members should listen to thisrather than some assumptions that a talkative senator has expressed. So much for honesty and openness in government. In the election campaign in March 1990, the deception of the Australian people reached its peak. Do honourable members remember that 60 Minutes performance with the two bosom pals sitting there, the Prime Minister and the ex-Deputy Prime Minister, being interviewed by Richard Carleton? Richard Carleton asked the Prime Minister whether he would be Prime Minister for the next three years, and he answered: Well, if they elect me on 24 March, which I hope they will, then the answer is an unequivocal yes. If that was not enough, he went across and asked the ex-Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Keating, if he would be happy to sit around for another three years playing second fiddle, and Mr Keating said: I am happyyou can just imagine one of his grinsto be led by the most successful Prime Minister in the post war years. It is a pleasure for me. It has been a matter of great sense of accomplishment for all of us who have been in this cabinet. We are a very happy ship. He did not use the word 'Titanic', but he said: . . . a very happy ship. I might just sayand this is wonderfulwe are a very happy couple. Both of them, on television, lying through their teeth to the people of Australia; they perpetrated the worse sort of fraud on the people of Australia. If Australians had known that by voting for Hawke they would be getting Keating, then this Government would never have been re-elected. Although the Prime Minister showed an acute sensitivity to the interjection of my colleague the honourable member for  right: Bob Hawke would not have been returned in 1990 if the truth had been known about a vote for Hawke actually being a vote for that charming, wonderful, elan ish type-the Treasurer. What appals Australians today is not just how the deal over the leadership was done; they are particularly appalled that it should have been done at all. A Treasurer with a record of failure epitomised by engineering the worse recession in this country for 60 years, by the assessment of any Australian, should have been fired, not promoted. They cannot understand why that deal should have been done at all. How insecure is this bloke? How much influence was he subjected to by Bill Kelty that he would do a deal about something as sacred as that? We now know that beyond that the duplicity continued. The Prime Minister started to annoy the Treasurer towards the end of 1990, and the Treasurer broke out in that famous National Press Club speech where he called himself the Placido Domingo, I think, of Australian politics, or whatever. Yesterday on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio I heard a wonderful version of a song by Placido Domingo. The Prime Minister ticked the former Treasurer off and then started talking about staying on until 1996, even though he knew that the deal was there. That is the best example of a doublecross we will ever see. In another meeting between the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in late January-remember Senator Richardson spying in on that one through the cameras?-the Prime Minister told the Treasurer that the deal is off. That is when the Treasurer decided, obviously, to make good his prophecy of 1980. As a result of that second meeting in January this year, the Treasurer decided to make good his prophecy of 1980, which was, 'The first Labor leader I tear down will be the one I replace'. H- started working on tearing down the leider while professing his loyalty everywhere. On Face the Press on 3 May the Treasurer said: I think loyalty is the stuff of politics. Political parties are built on loyalty. It is loyalty. Loyalty is the common thread, I think, which runs through the political organisation, and loyalty matters. It matters to me. We have seen his brand of loyalty in the last few days. We have also seen the Prime Minister's brand of loyalty in recent times. Despite all his' protestations over subsequent days, in April and May of this year, the Prime Minister knowingly was at war with his Treasurer, and all the time they were consistently denying the truth to the Australian people. They were simply claiming that the Prime Minister would stay his full term and so would the Treasurer. Indeed, as recently as the middle of last week, the Treasurer said, 'The Prime Minister will stay Prime Minister as long as he deigns it to be the case'. The Prime Minister's credibility can never recover from that. His integrity has been fatally compromised. It begs t-e question: what other secret deals has this bloke done over the years? Two have been revealed in the last couple of weeks-the gold tax deal where he changed the policy for a campaign contribution in Perth, and now this deal that has been done. Why should the people of Australia ever believe anything this Prime Minister says? Not only has his integrity been totally compromised; he can no longer govern. The people of Australia have enormous doubt about the integrity of his Government. How did he survive today? He did a deal with the left wing. A government that is ridden with deals does one more deal just to stay alive, this time with the left wing. We can imagine what will happen to policy in the course of the next 12 to 18 months. What will happen to Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale, the three mines uranium policy, a wealth tax, or maybe a dozen other harebrained schemes'? The Left and the new Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) have been put into that position to ensure that the deal takes place, to ensure that the deal is honoured by this Prime Minister. This country is in the worse recession in 60 years. The last thing it needed was a political crisis. The last thing it needed was the dishonesty, deception and the lack of integrity of the Prime Minister and his Government. Millions of Australians around this country are crying out for leadership in what are the most difficult circumstances that this country has seen in 60 years. They now know that the only way to get that sort of leadership is to vote him out at the next election. They are aware that he has deep-seated divisions within his Party that will stop him from governing. If he could not govern this country when he did not have the deep seated divisions, how on earth will he do it now, particularly when he has done a deal with the Left and has elevated the leader of the Left to the position of Deputy Prime Minister? The Australian people know that the Prime Minister is a lame duck. They know he is a captive of the Left. We have seen how well the Left has managed the State of Victoria. That is what the rest of Australia has to look forward to in the next few days. The people want politicians to get on and do their job, to put their personal ambitions to one side and address the real problems. They want them to look after those people who have been thrown out of work, to restore the hope, which has been put beyond their reach, of buying a home in this country; to get a job and keep a job; and to raise their living standards. All these things have been compromised by a Prime Minister who could not care about anything but his own political survival. Only a coalition Government has the vision and sense of direction to deliver this country to where it has to go, to re-establish its standing in the world.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The Leader of the Opposition's time has expired. Is the motion seconded? Mr Tim Fischer-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Mr Deputy Speaker-Opposition members inteJjecting

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was heard in silence, it might not be a bad idea if members of the Opposition reciprocated.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! Members of the Opposition may seem to be mounting a campaign of sustained interjections. I advise them that interjections are out of order.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I regard this want of confidence motion very seriously. I trust that those opposite would do me the decency of allowing me to respond to what I regard as one of the few serious censure debates that they have brought forward in this House. It is serious in the sense that it deals with an important issue. I want to respond to everything that the Leader of the Opposition said. Firstly, let me make it clear that the fundamental premise of the argument put by the Leader of the Opposition is false. In his proposition he is arguing that I did a deal with a businessman and a trade union leader about who would be the next Prime Minister. The fact is that it was not in my provenance to determine who the next Prime Minister would be. What was in my provenance was to decide whether there would be a vacancy. But there was no capacity within Sir Peter Abeles or Bill Kelty to make the decision for the Australian Labor Party as to Who would lead it. That would be solely a matter for the Labor Caucus. The proposition has been falsely put by the Leader of the Opposition because it suits the practice of those opposite to peddle these falsehoods. The case was that I could never make the decision as to who would be the next Prime Minister of this country. All I could do was make an opportunity for my colleagues in the Caucus to make a decision on that matter. I was motivated in what I did at all points not for my own personal satisfaction-Opposition members-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Those opposite can laugh. By the time of the 1990 electionor if T had retired in 1991-1 would have been Prime Minister for seven years. I regard it as an enormous privilege and honour given to me by the people of this country to be their Prime Minister. I do not seek further years as Prime Minister for my own personal satisfaction. Opposition members inteJjecting

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Those opposite can make all the noise they like. The fact is that as far as the personal satisfaction, happiness and contentment of Bob Hawke are concerned, he would have a life of considerably greater ease and pleasure and, may I say, would honourably attain greater reward, by ceasing to be Prime Minister. Mr Downer-Resign, then.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Because that is all that drives honourable members opposite, they say, 'Go'. That is their only criteriapersonal satisfaction and reward. As I said, I have been in public life for over 30 years. If I had been motivated by things such as personal satisfaction and personal reward, I would not have pursued the career of politics. What I have been about since the time. I left university, joined the trade union movement and came into this Parliament has been solely serving the people of this country. The circumstances of 1988 were at one with that position, because I profoundly believed-and the Leader of the Opposition conceded it in his speech-that only Bob Hawke could have won the 1990 election. That was the very foundation of his speech. The honourable member for Kooyong  robbed. My heart bleeds for him. In other words, the honourable member for Kooyong asserts the accuracy of my assessment in 1988, which was that only I could lead the Labor Government to victory in 1990. Mr Rocher-You lied and got away with it.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The member for Curtin!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I am not being immodest about that; that is the assessment I make. Importantly, it is the assessment the Opposition makes. That is why the honourable member for Kooyong said he was robbed. I had only one consideration at that time: not my personal satisfaction or remuneration but my profound belief that it would be bad for this country to have a Government composed of members of the Liberal and National parties. It would have been a disaster to have had them in government; it would have been a disaster to have had the honourable member for Kooyong as Prime Minister. Just so that some colour can be given to that belief, I understood better than anyone what the philosophies of the Opposition were and what it had been about in government. Let it not be a matter of my judgment alone as to what sort of government the conservatives had recently provided and what they would be committed to were they to be returned. Let me turn to two quotations of profound importance. These quotations from totally independent sources spell out the philosophy of conservative government in this country and what the Opposition would have returned to had it been allowed to win the 1990 election. First, I turn to the report of its own Costigan royal commission-the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I quote from chapter 2 of interim report No.3, under the heading 'Slutzkin Rides Again'. I believe the people of Australia will never forgetOpposition members inteljecting

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Members of the Opposition can shake their heads; they do not like to hear. Here is spelt out what they did in government. I remind this House and the people of this country of the date of the report: it was 18 December 1981. That is important when one sees exactly what the Commissioner had to say: The Commission's investigations-

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: It is unbelievable that the Opposition could have done that to this country; the honourable member for Kooyong is right. This is what the conservative government's-not the Labor Party's-royal commissioner had to say about the philosophy of the conservatives and what they had done to this country: The Commission's investigation into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers' Union has led it, to the surprise of many, to the tax avoidance industry. Mr Downer-What about your union mates?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Members of the Opposition will do anything to avoid the facts. Listen to what the Liberal Government's own royal commissioner said about it.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Opposition members interjecting- .

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: They do not like the facts, and little wonder. This is what he said: This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five yearsthat is, from 1976 to 1981-the Opposition's period of governmentat a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. He continued: It has introduced into the community a class of people, almost invariably the highest earners, who pay little or no tax and make no contribution in that way as citizens to their fair share of community costs. In addition it has made more difficult for government the task of providing for the community as a whole a more equitable and reduced taxation burden. Listen now to what Professor Russell Mathews had to say at the same time in 1980.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I know that members of the Opposition do not like to hear this. This is what I was concerned about in 1988. This is what the Liberal Government had done to this country. Let me read to the House what Professor Russell Mathews said about the previous Government and its approach: Despite the emphasis which has been given to vertical equity in the design of the Australian income taxation system, the essential problem is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax, or even more tax, than the poor-it is to make the rich pay any income tax at all. Mr Carlton interjecting

Speaker: Mr S
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: EAKER-Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: He went on: It must be recognized that a massive tax revolt has already taken place; but it is a revolt of business taxpayers against wage and salary earners, of the rich against the poor. I knew in 1988, because I had lived through all this, that that was the philosophy of those opposite. The one thing that can be said about the philosophy of the conservatives is that it is not vcry complicated. It is very simple and straightforward, and it is this: protect the privileged; protect the rich; impose a greater burden on the poor, the underprivileged, the low to middle income earners. I knew that that is what they did in their last period in government, and I knew, on the evidence, that that is what they were committed to do again. Mr Costello inteljecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Higgins!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Let there be no doubt what they were about. They want to do the same thing again. So that it has not just come out of my mouth, let it also come out of the mouth of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). We have a situation where they were building it up in 1988, they were building it up for the 1990 election and they are still going ahead with it now. They want to impose a broad-based consumption tax. They wanted to do it then-and I was going to do everything I possibly could to stop them having that opportunity. The centrepiece of their attack, which would be the most disastrous attack on the poor and the underprivileged in this country's history, would be to impose an additional $12 billion with their consumption tax. Let me say that the honourable member for O'Connor got it right when he expressed the sort of concern that I had back then in 1988 and again in 1990. In August of last year, the honourable member for O'Connor said: On the basic principle, as percentage of i ncome, the poor would spend more on consumption than the rich. Rolls Royces will get cheaper . . . but bread and milk will be more expensive. That is from the Opposition, from the honourable member for O'Connor. That is exactly what would happen. Those opposite would make the necessities of life more expensive and reduce the tax on luxuries-all as a part of putting billions of dollars back into the pockets of those who are already rich. That is what 1988 and 1990 were all about as far as I was concerned. I knew, and those opposite have confirmed, that I was the only one who could keep them out of office. I had seen the disaster which they had inflicted upon this country-a disaster which flowed out of their philosophy of propping up the privileged and slugging the poor. I knew that they were about to do it again in 1990 if they were elected-and I was prepared to do all that I could to stop them from once again having an opportunity.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Kooyong!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I regret that in those circumstances I had to go to the people in 1990 in the way I did. But the point is this: the commitment that I made in 1990 is a commitment that will be kept. I committed myself to lead this Government for the whole of its term. I will lead it for the whole of its term, and I will do that for one reason and one reason only. Mr Chaney-No-one else could do it!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Pearce!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: It would be the greatest disaster for this country if those opposite, committed to the protection of the pri vileged and the smashing of the poor, were to be given the opportunity of governing again-and I will do everything in my body to stop that happening.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: After a performance like that, I am tempted to ask the members of Caucus: do you want another vote this afternoon? It would probably result in a different re-ult. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to go back to Costigan. I thought he was going back to Chifley, to Curtin, to Barton. Mr Melham inteJjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Banks will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: How far back did he have to go to produce a defence to seek to justify his lying? He admits, he confirms and he compounds the lying to the Australian public following on the Kirribilli deal. Clearly, it is time that this Government went out of office. It is time for the Government to pay the price for the ultimate deal, the ultimate betrayal, the ultimate shabby Kirribilli arrangement involving Prime Minister Hawke, Sir Peter Abeles, Keating and Kelty. That has led to a situation-Mr Lavarch interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Fisher!

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: If one does an honest head count of this Parliament this Monday, there are no fewer than 147 members of the Australian Parliament who this day have declared no confidence in the Prime Minister and just 77 who have a lingering confidence in him. We will see how many are honest enough to vote with their hearts on this motion of want of confidence or whether they are going to vote with their feet and toe the party line. It is also very interesting that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) failed to come into the House to support the Prime Minister on this critical speech. Where is the honourable member for Blaxland? Has he taken his bat home? It is time for this Government to admit that all this has been about big business, big unions, big government and big deals, forgetting about small business and the vast number of Australians whose standard of living has been devastated by the economic policies of this Government. In short, it is not only time for the honourable member for Blaxland to goand he has gone-but it is time for the Prime Minister to go. It is time that the Government went to the people and went out of office as quickly as possible. Both the Prime Minister and the former Treasurer have lost every shred of credibility with the 1988 secret deal-the ultimate deal. As my colleague the honourable  rectly says, it was the ultimate lie. Indeed, the time has come to expose even more the ramifications arising from this deal and to build on remarks made so capably by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Firstly, the Prime Minister should state very clearly exactly what he did say to the then Treasurer at Kirribilli because what has emerged is that the Prime Minister did not trust his then Treasurer and the then Treasurer did not trust the Prime Minister; they could not rely on their own handshake. We now know that they met here in Parliament House in October 1988 and had a discussion. They reached agreement in 1988, in that great bicentennial year now besmirched by this shabby lie, this shabby deal. But that was not good enough: both of them said, 'I don't trust you as far as I can kick you'. So for nearly three years we have' had a Prime Minister and a Treasurer, to this day, who were not able to trust each other; and so they sought seconds to the big duel. They sought witnesses to come forward. Whom did they seek? They sought Sir Peter Abeles from big business and Bill Kelty from big unions. The then Treasurer suggested a member of Caucus to act as witness-we now know that from the press conference-but the Prime Minister said, 'I don't trust any member of my Caucus. I don't trust or rely on any member of the Caucus in the House of Representatives or the Senate. I want outsiders. I want particular outsiders to act as seconds to this shabby deal'. So it was that we had the ultimate deal, bypassing all members of Caucus, all members of Cabinet, and reasonable people such as the former Leader of the Opposition in the Victorian Parliament. He could have acted as duel broker. He could have acted as witness to this secret agreement at Kirribilli, but the Prime Minister would not trust him. The Prime Minister would not trust the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). Well might he not trust the honourable member for Shortland because it is a particular insult to the honourable member for Shortland that the Prime Minister went to Sir Peter Abeles. I remind the - ouse of testimony given in a book elsewhere that the honourable member for Shortland, when he was Minister for Aviation, was astounded to be called around to the Prime Minister's office in the old Parliament House and to find sitting there Sir Peter Abeles, who went into a detailed discussion on forthcoming changes in the Government's aviation policy-another deal in the making. The second thing which ·must be said is that quite clearly the Prime Minister has absolutely misled. the Australian public for over two years in his repeated declaration.s that he was 'going to stay on'. In the last 12 months the Prime Minister upgraded that promise. Let us look at two particular quotes. On 28 November 1990 on Perth radio, Western Australia, yet again, he said: What I have made quite clear now for quite a long period of time is that after we win the next electionin 1993 or wheneverI would think in that ncxt period it would be time to think about making way for the successor then. In other words, it was an absolute commitment by the Prime Minister to serve out this particular parliamentary term. That particular statement on Western Australia radio was made ahead of the famous speech by the then Treasurer to the Christmas dinner of the National Press Club, the date on which the Prime Minister, in retrospect, claims that the famous agreement was absolutely torn up. I say to the House that that statement was made, is a quote and is absolute. The Prime Minister made that statement in the full knowledge that he was lying in his teeth as a consequence of the secret agreement at Kirribilli House. Then on 12 December 1990 the Prime Minister gave another so-called absolute commitment: I now make it clear that I will lead the party to the next eJection, and with the intention of going through that term while I retain the keenness towards the job and the fitness for it that I do now. It's an absolute commitment '" that I will lead the party into the next eJection with the intention of leading the party through the whole of that term. Clearly, once again, he spoke in the knowledge of the secret agreement. He misled and lied to the Australian public and to the Parliament. I guess the quote to top it all off is a more recent one-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The Leader of the National Party should not say that the Prime Minister lied to the Parliament.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: He misled the Parliament, and I take that guideline. On 9 May-and I quote directly from Hansard-the Prime Minister told the Parliament: My Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister is not disloyal. This was 9 May, just a few weeks ago. The Prime Minister said of the honourable member for Blaxland that the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister of that day was not disloyal: I enjoy the full support and cooperation of the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister. Some support! Some cooperation! He went on to say: I have been proud to be shoulder to shoulder with him when our employment figures have been rising; when our unemployment figures have been coming down. I have been proud to stand beside him and to take the credit with him, when we should get that credit. I am equally prepared, and always will be, to stand next to him, shoulder to shoulder, when the figures are going the other way. That is the way it has been for eight years, and that is the way it will be for many, many years yct. Yet here we are, less than a statutory 28 days later, with the then Deputy Prime Minister and the Treasurer far removed from the front bench-and amen to that. We will not complete this double until we see the Prime Minister far removed from the front bench. I want to take up a particular comment made by the Prime Minister when he said in his speech a moment ago: 'It would have been bad for the country if I had stepped down prior to the 1990 elections'. Does he not realise the disaster he has already created for Australia in his own policies, in allowing the Treasurer the full rein that he has? The balance of payment figure is yet again today $1.6 billion. As our shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), will develop in this debate, that is up some 70 per cent. The net foreign debt is $133 billion. There is rocketing unemployment and, worse still, a rocketing down of the employment base-a tragedy for thousands of people in Albury-Wodonga, in Liverpool, in Lavington, in Lilydale, and in every suburb that one can mention around Australia. There is story after story of the heartburn created by the economic recession we had to have. Both Prime Minister Hawke and Treasurer Keating, as he was until 10 o'clock this morning, have a great deal to answer for in terms of their economic performance. Now they have a lot more to answer for in terms of the shabby, secret deal which has done so much to tear up every shred of credibility associated with this Government. This secret agreement, this compact, was a grubby exercise from go to whoa. This great man of consensus, who speaks of his special empathy with the people of Australia, can no longer claim that special relationship. Whilst the Government is paralysed on these matters the recession rolls on. A number of key decisions are required from the Government, such as Coronation Hill and other vital issues, including the preparation of this year's Budget. What has happened to the Budget Cabinet meetings and the subcommittee meetings and the Expenditure Review Committee meetings? The Government has been absolutely paralysed for days. We know it is a government of special deals. I sound a note of warning: it is time for an end to the special deals because the special deals have been exposed and no longer are going to calise this Government to survive. In fact, they will provide the basis for the defeat of this Government when the next election occurs. In the context of these special deals, how can the Government explain the three-mines uranium policy? What deals have been done with the conservation movement to preserve this illogical policy? How can the Government explain its telecommunications policy? What deals have been done with the Telecom unions to bring about this second-best solution? The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) knows that it is a second-best solution. The honourable member for Blaxland made it very clear that it is the second best. The ultimate area of deals of this Government is with the trade union movement, the industry relations club and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. There was deal after deal until we got to accord mark VI, when even that got to be too much for the Government, which went out on a course on its own, leaving the Industrial Relations Commission out to dry. Yet another deal was the gold tax industry deal. We now know, from evidence in the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, that the Prime Minister significantly upgraded the commitment that there would be no gold tax by saying at that time that there would be no gold tax for an additional parliamentary term. That meant a lot of dollars for a lot of people. What arose from that dinner-what donations were made to the Australian Labor Party-is now history. The Australian people will never again take a statement from this Government or this Prime Minister at face value, and neither should they. They have lost faith with this Government. From this point on, the Government will be seen-as it deserves to be-as nothing more than a discredited, shabby collection of desperate individuals. Some Government members, at least, had the courage to get off'the fence. I give them credit for that. For example, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) got off' the fence. He backed the former Treasurer. If he had any courage to comply with the parliamentary convention, he would resign today as Whip. I think it was Tony Staley who set that precedent. At that time he resigned as Whip because he had moved against the then leader of his Party. So it is that honourable member for Canning is on thin ice indeed. This is one of many examples. It is no longer .a true government; it is no longer a cohesIVe government. In these critical economic times-be it world recession or deep Australian recession with many parts of Australia such as Geelong, Horsham and other areas in actual depression-people expect and want a governmen- of coh-sion and leadership. They are slCk and tIred of watching Caucus fiddle while the country burns. It is high time that we got back to the proceedings of government and the determination of Cabinet under a firm leadership. In all that has happened over these extraordinary five days, what we have had is proof positive that this Government has lost the right to govern Australia because this Prime Minister and the fo;mer Treasurer have misled the public of Australia and have totally misled the Parliament of Australia. There is no more honourable a choice for the Prime Minister in the circumstances now obtaining than for him to back the judgment of no fewer than 44 members of his Caucus and resign.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: We have just heard two speeches from Opposition members on the want of confidence motion against the Government that is essentially about the relationatives ship betwe-n i;ndiv-duals and is essentially about subJe-t1ve Issues. The reality, in terms of thIS Government, is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a commitment, which essentially will be sustained through this term of Parliament. The commitment that the Prime Minister made was clear and unequivocal: that he would serve the whole of this term as Prime Minister. That is a commitment he will meet. There is one fact about the Labor movement and the Australian Labor Party which ought to be abundantly clear to all honourable members of this House: we are a party committed to the principles of participation and democracy. For 100 the years the La-or Party, and only the Labor Party, has flg-rously pursued the right of eve-y Austrahan to participate in the affairs of our community. That fact is reflected in the rules, structures culture and policies of this great Party. So when people speak of private agreements about succession, we on this side of politics say, 'Bunkum'. Succession is for royalty. The democratic choice of a leader and an executive by the parliamentary party is the - al1mark of the Labor Party. This mornmg we have again confirmed Bob Hawke in the leadership. . It is one thing to talk-certainly on this SIde-about a significant change in persO.n;nel. However, if one looks at personalItIes and power within the conservative parties, one will see a succession of backstabbing incidents which resulted in musical chairs on leadership and represented no standards of integrity to hold up to anyone, let alone to the Australian people. So when people talk about succession in this Party we remind ourselves of our democratic traditions and we have made deci-i-ms this morning in the light of those tradltlOns. S.i-ilarly, we will continue to pursue poilcies that a-e based firmly on the right of all Austrahans to participate in the aff-ir.s of their community. As we develop pohcles to take Australia into the next century, that will be the stark difference between the Labor Party and the conservin this country. Again and again, we have seen the conservatives come into this Parliament and want to talk about s?me issue that has to do with personaliUes or some problem that might exist in the Government ranks but has nothing substantial to do with policy. Mr Reith-How do you justify the lie? Mr - OW--They are not prepared to c?-e mto thIS Parliament and defend po-1t10-S that they will canvass lightly when Lt SUlts them. Mr Snowdon-You wouldn't know, you goose! Mr SPEAKEROrder! The honourable memoer for the Northern Territory!

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Labor stands for democracy and participation. The tories, the conservatives, represent sectional interest and privileges. The tories have no idea about the way we should live together in society, which they simply see as noninterference-no public action to ensure liberty. They would leave all social arrangements to agreements between individuals. The social reality is for them to talk about deals. The reality is that they have no public policy and no sense of direction that can be defended publicly. Essentially, when they do develop their thinking, it is about private arrangements and agreements between individuals, not about the role of government and public policy. The conservatives insist that government should minimise its role on the basis that arrangements are much more effectively made between individuals. This position is evident in the proposals of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to privatise welfare, highlighted in the recent paper from the Centre for Independent Studies which proposed that prime responsibility for delivery of income supported community services be handed over to private welfare organisationscharities-funded directly by taxpayers, who would elect that a proportion of their taxes be given to particular charities. This extreme argument is carried by the coalition into the field of employment. It is easy to see what might happen in a libertarian world when an impoverished person agrees on weak terms to an employment contract with the rich and powerful. The rich or powerful person mayor may not impose extreme penalties or abuse the employment contract in other ways. But, if he did, there would be nothing to stop him. That is precisely what the tories argue should be the case. The fact is that fairness and justice are indispensable to achieving freedom. From this point of view, citizenship does not guarantee an ideal of total freedom. What it does aspire to is equal and assured freedom for everyone to the greatest extent possible. Because we live in a social world and we are not isolated individuals, citizenship requires certain kinds of work and effort on the part of individuals. It also requires work on the part of governments. Labor's view of society, and of what all Australians as citizens should be able to expect from our government, is based on what we need to be able to function as effective members of our society. It is a view which in no way attempts to determine how we function, what diverse values we may espouse in shaping our lives or, within broad limits, what we do; but it acknowledges that there are certain basic capabilities and resources that all in our society need to effectively realise about their civic freedoms. Consider the way we think about poverty. We can think about people in poverty as being unable to provide for their material needs. If we look at individuals in isolation, we need only to declare some minimum provision of income and make sure that a level of income is provided to those who cannot meet their material needs. However, if we think about people in poverty as those who lack the means to function effectively in our society, then we are looking at a much more complicated set of issues. For example, we need to work towards making sure that people in this situation have access to information, education, training, health care, and the services and transport they need to support themselves in work and to gain equitable access to employment opportunities. Labor as a Government aims to achieve a set of objectives. Among them is social justice. We measure our success in implementing concrete programs in terms of our progress towards achieving these goals for all our citizens. It is clear to Labor that the relationship between where people live and work and the location of training they need to help them to improve their opportunities, the services they need to support them in their working lives and the transport links between these points is extremely important. So it is focusing on these kinds of issues-the locational disadvantages, the need to restructure services and improve physical infrastructure and take account of demographic change-that is close to the heart of Labor's approach. / Against that-honourable members should remember that, ultimately, behind the rhetoric in this kind of debate we have important differences in terms of political philosophy-we see that the conservatives will dismantle the income security safety net, abolish sole parent pensions for people when their children are three years old, while not worrying about the vulnerability of people in that situation, and abolish the unemployment benefit. This demonstrates how harsh a conservative government would be. On 11 October, Dr Hewson said: We have painted ourselves as a harder-line alternative to the Government and as time goes on the electorate will come more and more behind us. They will vote for us in the end if got credibility, if they genuinely believe that we are going to do what we say we will. If that involves pain they will wear it. The Opposition has no policy reason and no principles. It is just that the visiting professor needs to appear tough. He wants to make the tax system grossly less fair. The Opposition would abolish the capital gains tax, leaving the spivs of the 1970s and 1980s to re-emerge in all the glory of their tax avoidance. The conservatives are essentially a party of privilege and they specialise in making deals to protect the privileged. All this rot about deals comes from members opposite. We just need to have a look at their proposal for a goods and services tax, the centrepiece of their tax policy, to know that. A goods and services tax will have a disastrous impact on inflation. A lO per c-nt goods and scrvices tax which replaced the existing wholesale tax system could increase inflation by almost 9 per cent. The burden of a goods and services tax would fall most heavily on low income earners and social security pensioners and beneficiaries. The burden would fall more heavily on those with children than those without children. It is, of its essence, a regressivc tax. The coalition intends to introduce a comprehensive goods and services tax which would include all food. This will particularly disadvantage families with children, low income earners and social security beneficiaries, because they spend a high proportion of their income on food for themselves and their children. A goods and services tax will also impact heavily on the purchase of new homes. An attempt to compensate losers through the tax system will be untargeted and give those who already gain further windfall gains. It will be very costly in revenuc forgone on some estimates-$600m or more. H is clear from work done by the Australian Tax Research Foundation that it is impossible to compensate all losers under a goods and services tax without substantial increased expenditure. Attempts to construct compensation packages have left out those who are unemployed. They we've would suffer substantial increases in the cost of essential goods and services without compensation, undermining their ability to get back into work and recover their position. The longer people are unemployed, the worse would be their position. The Opposition can produce all the anecdotes it likes about the impact of indirect taxes. The facts, on which good policy should be based, are that its proposal would lead to low income earncrs paying more tax and high income earners paying less tax. That is obviously inherently unfair. I have referred to these broader policy issues because we have heard a lot about integrity from members of thCr Opposition. We have heard something from them about the politics of so-called survival. They keep mentioning notions of deals. Essentially, over a period we have seen conservative governments in this country amass deals which are absolutely incredible in terms of their impact. We heard from the Prime Minister at the beginning of this debate about the impact of the taxation policy in the course of the last period of conservative government. During that period, the only industry that was growing was the tax industry. It was the greatest growth industry of all in the country, at a time of incredible cconomic attrition, hsing unemployment and massive decline in the viability of Australian industry. It was unbelievable and massively unfair. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who is at the table, fails to develop any clarity in terms of his policy. In a minute he will talk about integrity. But what integrity does he bring to a policy debate? He makes broad assertions about who, amongst the poor, would be targeted for the $3 billion in Opposition cuts and who would be impacted with the goods and services tax. He says nothing about the detail of that which, inevitably in terms of its regressive impact, would add to those expenditure cuts and he says nothing about the privatisation of wclfare. In each case, he is elevating some sectional interest over and above the public good. He is essentially saying that, in the end, individuals need to be protected. The mass of people on low incomes, those who are vulnerable, do not deserve protection; rather, they are to face additional imposts in consumption taxes.
