Essentially, that is about government for a sectional interest; it is government for those who are the friends of the tories and those who would be the beneficiaries of a tory government, those in the most powerful sections of corporate capital in Australia. In this debate, certain questions regarding relationships which have existed between people in our Government have been elevated into an issue far beyond its importance. The reality is that, at the beginning of this term, the Prime Minister made a very clear commitment that he would lead the Labor Party through to the next election. With a democratic party such as the Labor Party such a commitment is always provisional. In the end it is always dependent on the continuing support of the parliamentary Labor Party. Today, a decision has been made by the parliamentary Labor Party to reaffirm and re-eJect the Prime Minister into office so that he can meet his contract, his commitment to the Australian people. Ultimately, if one is going to talk about ethics or morality, at the end of the day the Australian people will have the expectation met by the presence of the Prime Minister through this particular term. But, more importantly, they will have in place a set of policies that are based on Labor Party principles and on a commitment to social justice, which tends towards the creation of a fairer society and, ultimately, would enable people to live much more effectively in this country than they would in terms of Opposition policy. That is what is being obfuscated by members of the Opposition. They do not want to detail their policy. They always look for the sideshow, they arc not intcrcsted in defending their philosophy and their purposes.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I will comment on the remarks made by the newly elected Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe). Politics in this country is principally about political debate on policy issues, but it is also about honesty. It is telling people straight what the issues are, instead of the lies and the deceptions that we had going into the last election. Was it not remarkable that this former Methodist lay preacher never went to the issue, which was the lies and the deception of his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the last election? That is because the lies of the Prime Minister were indefensible on any reasonable criterion. The Government's problem is that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) will be Prime Minister within 12 months. He has plunged the knife into the Prime Minister and will do so again and again until he brings him down for his own personal ambitions. Well might he lunge the knife into the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is guilty of a base breach of faith. He is guilty of a treacherous, faithless betrayal of the trust of the Australian people, a deceitful violation of a promise. The Prime Minister is a liar, who professed his loyalty to this country for his own personal ambitions so he could cling to the keys of the Lodge. This was a gross act of perfidy, and ought to be declared as such. This motion calls on Government members. Where will the 44 members who voted against the Prime Minister this morning vote, how will their conscience dictate the way in which they votc when this matter comes to be voted on very shortly? This is an open and shut case. We have the Prime Minister's own words on the public record---:-on the radio, on the television, in print. Wherever that man went in the last election he made a clear promise as to his intentions, and that was that he would stay on for the fourth term of an incoming Labor Government. Listen to the quotes, and there are many of them. This one was repeated in the Weekend Australian last weekend concerning questions to the Prime Minister before the last election: Q: Will you lead the Party into the next election or not? A: I would expect to . . . Q: .Is this just an expectation or a definite A: An intention. I mean, I ean't be sure of intervening eireumstances . .. beyond my control. As far as those that are in my control arc concerned, it would be my intention. That is clear black and white. He swore blue murder that he would in fact be the Prime Minister for the full term of an incoming Labor Government. In doing so, he broke the standard he himself set. This was the man who, back in May 1989, said, whilst speaking during a censure debate: It is a special responsibility of the leadership on both sides to protect those values by sctting standards and by enforcing them. He went on to say: . . . One of the greatest of Australia's resources is the strength and the stability of its political system; our great parliamentary democracy. Anything that detracts from that strength and stability damages Australia. One of the vital clements in that strength and stability is the standards and integrity, the stability and the quality of ship . . . That is a clear setting of the standards by the man himself. He went out and broke that standard for his own personal gain. He is the same man who said that members of parliament are all in a position of service, responsibility and duty to the nation, where there is a fundamental requirement for integrity, probity, the ordinary decency of public life and honourable conduct. He is the same man who, in the 1990 election, lied through his tceth to maintain himself in office. What was his answer today? He said the political realities drove him to lie and to cheat and to run a fraudulent campaign in the last election.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! This is a want of confidence motion. The honourable gentleman has had quite a deal of latitude. He is not entitled to use the language that he is using. I would suggest that he use other words.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I say that the charges brought against the Prime Minister today in this want of confidence motion substantiate the motion without a shadow of doubt. He is the man who said that Government members are entitled as a political party to go into an election and deliberately mislead people on the basis of believing that the policies of the Opposition might be wrong for the country. That is the ultimate in moral bankruptcy, if ever I heard it. That is the equivalent of the ends justifying the means. No prevarication, no dissembling by the Prime Minister, will get him off the hook of his deception in 1990. I say that a Prime Minister who says he is entitled to lie when it suits his political ends is not entitled to remain as Prime Minister of this country. So the first charge against the Prime Minister is that he lied to the Australian public in the 1990 election. The second is that he participated in the Kirribilli conspiracy. He put mateship for his mate Sir Peter Abeles and for his mate Bill Kelty before the interests of the nation. I suspect that there was more to that particular deal than what has already come out so leader- far. He treated the democratic processes with contempt. How can the Minister for Transport and Communications and Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) stand here, as he is going to, and defend a Prime Minister who himself treated the Minister with the absolute contempt with which he treated the rest of the Caucus? He treated the prime ministership of this country as. his own personal chattel, as part of his 'own fiefdom, as if it was his to play with, as if it was a personal chattel which he could control without consulting the Australian people. For that he deserves our absolute condemnation. How dare this man trade in the prime ministership of this country? The third charge is that he failed to deal with his deputy after the 'Placido Domingo' speech of last year. The Prime Minister himself has said today that that was treachery, absolute treachery. That is how he characterised the remarks of the former Deputy Prime Minister; yet old jelly back sat back and did absolutely nothing, let the matter continue to fester. Talking about the Prime Minister's own political interests-even his own staff are reported as saying, effectively, that it was politically inept not to sack the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, because it would have been very popular to do so, as obviously it would have been to sack the man who has been the principal architect within the Government in bringing on the recession that we 'had to have'. Of course, fourthly, a critical element of the charge is that the Prime Minister reneged on his own deal. It is one thing to be a participant in the Kirribilli conspiracy, but the Prime Minister then proceeded to renege on his own deal. It is not just a question of his not being able to trust people in his own Caucus as to what he was up to in the Kirribilli conspiracy; he himself cannot be trusted as a result of his breaching and reneging on the deal that he did with the honourable member for Blaxland. This charge is, I might say, not just a charge made by the Opposition; it is also a charge made out eloquently by the honourable member for Blaxland, who himself has said that the Prime Minister cannot be trusted-that, of course, being the basis upon which the witnesses were brought in and the basis upon which the honourable member for Blaxland has proceeded with his challenge in the last few days. Lastly, as part of the charge against the Prime Minister-the buck stops there with the Prime Minister; ultimately he is the one responsible for the management, politically economically and otherwise, of this Government and he has allowed great damage to be done to the Australian democratic process and the standing of the political process-by continuing in the office of Prime Minister, this man demeans Australia's political process. He reveals the Australian Labor Party as being a party entirely without principles. It has been shown to reveal finally what it is. A charge laid not just by the Opposition but also by the honourable member for Blaxland is that the Prime Minister leads a Government entirely bereft of ideas, devoid of vision, devoid of answers for an economy which has been plunged into the depths of recession-in fact, an economy that stares down the barrel of a depression, as a result of deliberate government policy. Do not forget that it was at the last election-and this is another great lie that was told to the Australian public-that the people were told, 'Don't worry, it will be a soft landing'. The Prime Minister said in the week leading up to the election, 'There won't be a recession'. The then Treasurer himself said-talk about Mr Arrogance-he would not let there be a recession; yet, as was revealed post that election; their policy all along was to bring on a recession, to wreak great damage, great hardship on the ordinary working person in this country. As a result of this policy paralysis, as a result of the quest for the top job-for the keys to the Lodge-what do we have across the broad spectrum? The Government likes to talk about policy. Look at the policy paralysis on its own side: Coronation Hill, to take the immediate one; a decision again deferred. Look at the uranium policy. The Government talks about integrity on policy. These guys have been playing with the uranium policy for one reason only, and that is to shore up the votes of the Left for today's leadership challenge. Then there was the Premiers Conference. What a farce! At a critical time for this country, as we look toward the future and the need to maintain a tight fiscal policy, what a farce it was that we had the Prime Minister and ex-Treasurer dealing with the Premiers last week. What does that mean for the average person? It means people continue to pay high interest rates because this Government has not been prepared to take the hard decisions in relation to fiscal policy. The Prime Minister says there will be no damage as a result of this. He just cancelled his trip to Europe-cancelled the further negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which are absolutely critical. Various Ministers were brought back from overseas. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was called back from his proposed visit to South Africa and the Deputy Prime Minister himself, the Minister for Community Affairs and Health (Mr Howe), was called back from government business being transacted on our behalf last week. Another consequence is the institutionalisation of a government in a state of instability. How will some Ministers look the Prime Minister in the face? There is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). We know he was the ex-Treasurer's campaign manager back in 1988 and is still a strong supporter of his. We have the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett), the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). They will all sit in the Cabinet while owing their allegiance to one outside the Cabinet as he continues to deal more deals-double deals, triple deals, all designed to bring down this Government. As these people fight over the top job, what about the ordinary Australian? Those opposite profess much compassion for the ordinary Australian. What does the ordinary Australian say today about the rise in unemployment as a deliberate result of Government policy? Just last night the ANZ Bank's job figures were put out. What did we see? We saw another big drop in the number of advertisements. The figure has gone from over 40,000 just two years ago down to 13,000. That is an important leading indicator on where the job market is going. There was no discussion on that today; there was no policy response from those opposite except that I suppose they want to blowout on the fiscal side. Mr Downer-What about the balance of payments?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I am indebted to my colleague the honourable member for Mayo. Again today, a balance of payments deficit of $1.6 billion was announced, a huge figure by any reasonable definition. We had a turnaround on the merchandise trade which those opposite have been crowing about as an indicator of the success of their Government's policy. The truth of the matter is that those opposite have made no real structural changes to this economy. The sad thing for this economy and this country is that the ex-Treasurer waits in the wings for the top job. He was the Treasurer who said: The first Labor leader I tear down will be the one I replace. Back in 1981 he also said-and this is a good one: If people cannot vote for me because I have lopped off a few heads in the face of massive provocation, if the cost is I am passed over, that is the way it has to be, but they will pass me over at their own political folly. ' Honourable members should remember those words. Forty-four honourable members opposite voted for the ex-Treasurer this morning. I say to them that if they have a shred of conscience, if they have any real interest in the future of this country, when this motion is voted on in a few moments time they ought to sit on this side, or at the least abstain, and do their country a decent favour for a change.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: There is no question but that this is a day of sadness for us. The sadness arises not from anything that the Opposition has managed to say in the three speeches that have been made by its members to this point but from the circumstances in which we find ourselves where we have been obliged to make a choice we never wanted to make. No member of the Caucus ever wanted to make the choice that we were obliged to make today. That was the choice between two people who have been-though not solely-the effective Ministers of this Government for the last 81/2 years. That is obvious in the case of the leading position. We finally got to a point where we had no choice but to make a choice. That was not something any of us wished or something that any of us wished on the country. As a result of that, inevitably, we have lost the services from the front bench of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who is the greatest Treasurer of this country since Ted Theodore. We do not rely for that view on the humbug merchants opposite, but on the people who have witnessed the way in which this country has operated. Mr Chaney-What about the results?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I will get on to the results in a minute. The second area of sadness is that unquestionably, for a time, circumstances like these which we face advantage our opponents; our opponents have been seeking to take advantage of that here today with their usual hypocrisy and humbug, as reflected in the speeches that they have made here. Those opposite came in here clothing themselves in the view that there is instability on this side which tortures the lives of the poor people in this country-but knowing what sits behind their policy. This, too, will pass. In my view, Harold Wilson did not make many contributions to politics, but he made one, and that was this: he said that a week is a long time in politics. A week is a long time in politics, and two years is an era. But we know one good thing about those opposite, with all their cant and hypocrisy about what happens with big business. They will allow all the funny money merchants and spivs of the 1980s that still have a tipple worth of property left on their books to keep their ill-gotten gains, tax free, and they will make the poor ordinary people, for whom those opposite hypocritically bleed, pay for it at a rate of 15 per cent tax. I want to say one or two things about the issues here. We could go through all the ramifications those opposite like. But the first that is important as far as public commitments are concerned is this: at the last election, at which this Government submitted itself to the public for its approval, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) undertook to the people of this country that he would serve this term, and he honours that undertaking. The second point about the cant and hypocrisy from the those opposite is that they do not come into this debate with clean hands. In less time back into history than we are away from the next election, we confronted those wonderful scenes in this place where the honourable, honest people opposite, who never do deals or tell lies behind anybody's backs, were disporting themselves in the old 'Andrew and John and Fred and Alice' show. That is what we had from the mob opposite less time ago than the time to the next election, if we look forward into the future. Two years before that, those opposite went through the same dance and parade. They do not think of the lies that were told at that time, even though they now talk about bitter deception. Let me refer to an interview between Michael Carlton and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). Mike Carlton said: Do you accept Andrew Peacock's denials, his claim that he knew nothing about this until the weekend; that he was simply drafted . . . That is, drafted for the leadership. The honourable member for Bennelong answered: I can't believe that in the face of what transpired on Monday night and what I know . . . I cannot believe in all my heart that he was not privy to the detail of that. And so say all of us. Mike Carlton asked him: So you believe he has lied? The honourable member for Bennelong replied: Well, somebody is not telling the truth . . . You can't have gone into that kind of detail and then expect people to believe that suddenly people came along and tapped you on the shoulder and said, 'Hey chum, we'd like you to be leader'. Then there are the words of Senator Michael Baume, who said: There is a simple question. One has to decide who is lying-John Moore and Wilson Tuckey or Andrew Peacock. Those opposite should not come into this place saying that they are believers in the high politics of total integrity. We on this side have had to explain a few things and the Prime Minister has been doing that in Question Time. But what we will not cop in this debateis the cant and hypocrisy from the other side of the House the cant and hypocrisy when it comes to areas of deception. Of course, we have that in policy terms. Those opposite have their own internecine struggles. Nobody expects every politician to walk out into a public place and expose his heart on what he intends his activities to be. Nobody in politics conducts a sort of mobile gestalt around the press gallery by saying, 'Well, today I am feeling like being leader of the Liberal Party, but tomorrow I might feel like being the shadow Treasurer and it is entirely possible that in a week or so I will feel like being the shadow Minister for Defence'. Nobody in the media in this countrynobody in this country-expects politicians to come out and say absolutely everything that is in - their hearts at every point of time. I will tell the House what they expect. They expect that honourable members opposite will at least have the honesty to stand up in public-Mr Filing inteljecting

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: l warn the honourable member for Moore.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: And say what their policies are, say where they intend to go, what they intend to do about their livelihood. What we have from the Opposition on a permanent basis is the floating of ideas, followed by concealment. Let us have some health vouchers: what does that mean? 'Maybe we won't, maybe we will, but we will tell you in our own good time if we feel like telling you. But we might not and just go through to the next election with it'. The Opposition has a record on policy of complete deceit. But I do congratulate the Opposition on one thing. There is one area where it is not being deceitful at the moment, at least not in totality but in terms of basic principle. It has not yet given US the figures as to what will be covered by the consumption tax, what level it is going to be, what the compensation arrangements will be. But we do know this: there will be one. We also know that there will be a removal of the capital gains taxes, so people out there at least have the knowledge that they will go down the gurgler. Mrs Bailey-No secret deals though.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: No secret deals! No secret deals in the Liberal Party! There has never been, in the history of the Liberal Party, a secret deal done with any businessman, done with any person, by anyone of them! The Liberal Party in its entire 50-year history has operated as a total open book for all the public to see and write upon it whatever they wish to write upon it-those totally populist individuals who have no policies. Cop the two-airline agreement, for starters. What was one of the Opposition's wonderful little deals that we managed to uncouple when we came into office? Honourable members opposite have been abusing the Prime Minister for his personal friendship with Peter Abeles. Who took off the two-airlines agreement, of which Peter Abeles-at least as far as the private sector was concerned-was the principal beneficiary? Little old us. Who put it on? Little old you. There is much being concealed behind the persiflage of this Opposition when it comes down to those secret deals issues. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has said here that as far as the Opposition is concerned the shoddiness of what the\ Government is proposing is reflected in its political disclosure legislation and advertising bans. My God, I would love to have had a bit of political disclosure legislation around the place for Liberal Party campaigns when those twoairlines agreements were being put in place in the 1950s and the 1960s and the 1970s and in the 1980s. I would have liked a bit of political campaign disclosure around the place when those deals were being put in place. The Opposition should not come in here wrapping itself in micro-economic reform flags, saying that it does not know a thing or two about political deals around the place. One of the most significant microeconomic reform proposals put in place by this Government was the abolition of that two-airlines agreement-and do we know it in Western Australia, where for the first time in our lives we finally have a decent amount of air communication with the eastern States. I am sorry I have been ruled out from being able to use the word 'liar'. On this side of the House we were going to let it go but the Speaker earlier today was too fastidious. One of the pieces of 'misleading' we managed to get from the Leader of the Opposition was that absolute untruth, that statement he made that the gold tax policy was sold for contributions . In no way at all has that been established by any of the propositions put forward during the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia. That was not an argument the Opposition was capable of sustaining when it raised it before in the House, but it now intends to mythologise it. Mr Dobie-Is this you defending Hawke?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for Cook.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The Opposition now intends to mythologise it by coming into this place and saying, 'We can ramble that off in a taxonomy of our criticisms of the Government; we will run that down the list'. There was one outfit that was making life hard for us on the gold tax at the time, when we were rustling around as to whether or not we ought to introduce it, trying to take the policy issues and the political flak on it. I did not dispute at the time, and I do not dispute now, that there were people in our own ranks who disagreed, but our fundamental political problem was not divisions amongst ourselves on that issue, not calculations about the economic consequences, although those had to be thought through, but that the Opposition, the great moralists on the subject of a gold tax, had decided it would exempt it for all time. In the end, that is why we came to the decision we did. The Opposition then made it an issue in the replacement ultimately of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) as Leader of the Parliamentary Liberal Party. In so far as the gold tax represented anything in political arrangements in this place, it represented front and centre chicanery in the Parliamentary Liberal Party. The Opposition then has a description of the way in which the Government undertakes a consultancy process with the public as a deal. Its conception of democracy in this country is that we have elections and, after those elections, a government is put in place. The government receives revealed truth upon itself . according to its ideology. The government stands back from the public and introduces policy on the basis of that revealed truth which has come through to it, and it never talks to anybody in the community. That is the Liberal Party theory according to honourable members opposite. It is not its practice, but that is the Liberal Party theory of how one should conduct oneself in politics. If, on the other hand, one believes that democracy is a condition of mind and operation in public policy in the community as a whole, and that merely winning office does not end the consultative process with people who are concerned in the community about decisions that one might take, somehow or other that is transformed not into a democratic process but into a political deal. That is the Liberal Party theory as expounded in the sorts of words put forward here today. The Opposition criticises us for being prepared to talk to manufacturers in the timber industry, loggers in the timber industry, the people who object to logging, the people who object to uranium mining. There is all this nonsense about the uranium mining policy in this country giving us a problem with development when we cannot sell the uranium we have at the moment. But the fact that we are prepared to talk to conservationists or a few people who are a bit serious about the issue of nuclear weapons or whatever is regarded as deals. The Opposition says in that context that what we are talking about is deals. Above all, there is the criticism that the Opposition makes of arrangements we put in place for the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Mrs Bailey-We didn't make deals.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member for MCEwen will not interject out of her place.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I will tell the House this about the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the people who are individual union members, who elect their officials: they are much more reflective of the thinking, the needs and lives of the ordinary people of this country than the types of people that Opposition members are and that they represent. Those changes have guaranteed us a level of employment in this country that is cushioning us from the worse effects of the recession. Those changes have lifted profit share to ensure new investment. Those changes have brought in a social wage that has benefited the very poor people of this country. That sort of deal is precisely the sort of deal that any decent government ought to be entering into when it has to deal with the people whose survival depends on how they behave. This motion is contemptible. It ean be dealt with right now. Therefore I move: That the question be now put. Question put. A division having been called and the bells being rung

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: On the evening television news last Friday, both Channel 9 in Sydney and Channel 3 in Newcastle falsely and maliciously defamed my character as well as the characters of my sons and the Director of Public Prosecutions in New South Wales. The most painful burden parliamentarians have to endure is when sections of the media indulge in the cowardly process of attempting to damage their reputation by attacking members of their family. Mr Speaker, I will not stretch your patience or the rules governing personal explanations by seeking to canvass the facts that led to the Director of Public Prosecutions dismissing certain charges laid by the police against my sons. I propose to raise those matters on another occasion. However, it is relevant to explain the manner in which I have been misrepresented. In September 1990 one of my sons was assailed by two security guards and a rottweiler guard dog in a caravan park adjoining my home after he had endeavoured to exercise his undoubted right of way to access our home. He was falsely arrested by the security guards and both my sons were subsequently assaulted, arand imprisoned by the security The nature of the misrepresentation and television news items that impugns character is: firstly, in a totally onedistortion of the facts, the false impression is given that my sons were guilty of the charges laid against them; secondly, the powerful inference was then made that I used my influence to corrupt the decision of the Director of Prosecutions. Indeed, on the program Mr Tony Day, spokesman for the Police Association of New South Wales, called for the decision of the Director of Prosecutions to be investigated by the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption. Given that Independent Commission Against Corruption only investigates questions of corruption by holders of public office, the only conclusion that can be drawn from the statement is that the Director of Public Prosecutions has been corruptly influenced in his decision. The presentation of the item, which strongly emphasised my name and film footage of my previous campaign and my role as the first law officer of New South Wales, leads to the strong inference that it was my influence that should be investigated by the Independent Commission Against Corruption. I wish to inform the House that I left the defence of the undoubted and demonstrable innocence of my sons in the very capable hands of one of this country's most eminent and respected Queen's Counsel. I made no personal contact directly or indirectly with the police or the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in New South Wales. The only point of contact was the senior counsel who acted on my sons' behalf. I should add here that it was the senior police prosecutor involved in the case who first expressed the view to senior counsel that having read the brief he was going to recommend that the charges be withdrawn. The matter was then taken out of the hands of the Police Prosecutor's office by the Greiner Administration and given to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Senior counsel, in accordance with the proper and accepted processes of law, drafted a submission to the Director of Public Prosecutions which was engrossed and forwarded by the highly reputable legal firm of Taylor & Scott who were the instructing solicitors. The Director of Public Prosecutions duly considered the matter, agreed with the senior police prosecutor and then advised the parties that the charges were to be withdrawn because in the view of the Director of Public Prosecutions the police were not acting properly in the .execution of their duty. For the television item to suggest, as it did, that I could have improperly influenced either the New South Wales police force or the Greiner Administration is an insult to the intelligence of the viewing public who were perfectly aware of the recent political history in New South Wales and the true nature of my relationship with those administrations.

Speaker: Mr FIFE
Title: URGENT LEGISLATION
text: The motion just moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) covers more than the suspension of the 11 o'clock rule. There is a second part to it and that is what I want to focus on. The Government is now proposing to apply the guillotine to 33 Bills. All of those Bills must be dealt with by dinner time on Thursday evening; I think the precise time is 6.10 p.m. The Government is again rushing legislation through the House in the dying stages of the session and severely restricting debate on important and complex issues. If I can invoke the word that I have used on a previous occasion in relation to this particular matter, it is outrageous. It emphasises once again the utter contempt that the Government has for this Parliament. It uses it as a rubber stamp and as merely a means of getting its legislation through as quickly as possible and getting back to the Cabinet room and the Caucus room to actually govern the country. This House has been sitting since 12 February this year. It has met every month, most months for only two weeks. On one other occasion in May, it met for three weeks. The House is due to get up at the end of this week and, as the Leader of the House has indicated, we could well come back during the week commencing 17 June and also the first week in July. So there is adequate time to deal with the legislation in a reasonable and rational way. The Government introduced six Bills last Wednesday night. Between midnight last Thursday and 3.30 a.m. on Friday, it introduced another 27 Bills. All of these 33 Bills, plus four others introduced earlier, a total of 37, are now being put under the guillotine. The volume of new legislation has made it impossible for the Opposition to adequately consider the Bills and for the shadow Ministry to meet and decide its approach, apart from putting its recommendations to the coalition parties in an appropriate way. No real time has been given for proper scrutiny and analysis of the legislation and far less for debate. I suspect that that applies to members of the Government, just as it applies to members of the Opposition. I wonder how many honourable members sitting opposite me, for example, have actually scrutinised the Bills that are currently before the Parliament? I suspect that very few have done so. By denying us the time, the Government is abrogating its responsibilities to the electors. Earlier last week, the Govcrnmcnt also used the guillotine when it introduced its package of seven Bills dealing with the general, regulatory framework covering telecommunications in Australia. Only 4 hours and 20 minutes was allowed for debate on those Bills and consequent amendments. Yet these were crucial matters affecting the future of the vital telecommunications industry. We also had to debate the highly controversial Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, which, apart from being a blatant attack on free speech, in the opinion of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, clearly constitutes a breach of Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. For all stages of that Bill, members had only 41f2 hours for debate in this chamber-and precious little time to consider the Bills outsidc of the Parliament in the shadow Ministry and in the . joint party room. This week, the House is going to have to deal with 37 Bills in four days and these will all be subject to the guillotine. At most, we will get only 40 minutes on each Bill, apart from one, the Proceeds of Crime Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, for which a mere 15 minutes has been allocated. This use of the guillotine has become a recognised practice of this Government. As has been mentioned on previous occasions, and despite the protests of the Leader of the House, I reiterate that the repeated use of the guillotine can be put down to only two things: firstly, that insufficient time has been set aside to deal with the legislation; and, secondly, that the legislation that the Government wishes to deal with has been introduced too late. I go back, Mr Speaker, and remind you and the House that we have been sitting here since 12 February, yet it was only last week that this package of Bills was introduced in the carly hours of the morning. There were very fcw members in the House because of the hour of the day, and there was very little time in which to consider the legislation. It is scandalous and it is indicative of the attitude of this Government-an attitude of a Government that rules by deals and deception, and now a Government that is turning its back on the Parliament, the main forum that is available in a democracy. This recurring bunching of legislation at the end of the sitting period suggests a breakdown in the Government's managemcnt process, as well as its attitude to the Parliament and the people of Australia. If the Government had a regard for Parliament, and if it could manage its own affairs, this legislation would have been introduced in February, March or April, and it could have becn on the table of the House and have been dealt with in a civilised manner. It is the rcsponsibility of the Government to cnsure that legislation is processed through the Cabinet procedures and brought into the House to allow proper debate. This, of course, must also mean that sufficient time is given for the Opposition to be able to adequately consider such legislation before it comes up for debate . I am sure that all honourable members on both sides of the House havc accepted over the years that democracy is a system whereby the majority view prevails and the minority view is heard. This Government is moving in such a way that, in future, the minority view is going to be heard less and less. A lot of the measures being dealt with under the guillotinc during the current sittings, as well as previous ones, are most contentious and complcx. It is therefore essential that a propcr allotment of time be provided to allow serious scrutiny of them. I am sure that members of the public, Mr Speaker, and indeed you and all members of the House, will be interested to know of the important legislation that is being brought into the House at this timc. Wc havc, for example, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill, a very important piece of legislation, and I am sure that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is very interested in that piece of legislation. That is the first to be dealt with, and that piece of legislation has to be completed through this House by 5.50 this evening. We have the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill. We have the Migration Amendment Bill. We have three Bills dealing with social security matters. We have the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. We have three Bills dealing with the very important and highly contentious problems within the wool industry. We have the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill. We have the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill. We have the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill. There are no fewer than seven Bills dealing with the fishing industry. There is the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill, the Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Bill, the Proceeds of Crime Legislation Amendment Bill, the Quarantine Amendment Bill, the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill and the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. There are two health Bills: the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill and the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. There are two Bills that deal with the road transport industry-the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill-and finally the Foreign Judgments Bill. Mr Speaker, this is a matter that should be of great interest and indeed great concern to you as the custodian of the rights and privileges of members of this House. Mr Speaker, although it is not a matter that you have a direct responsibility for, I ask you to listen to what I am saying and to take this matter up-immediately if you like, but certainly at a subsequent hour-with the Leader of the House, and say to him what you ought to say as the Speaker of this House: that enough is enough, that we have gone far enough with this kind of legislation and this way of dealing with legislation. It is my hope that we would get an assurance from the Leader of the House, at this late stage in the life of the Hawke Government, that the guillotine will not be used again in this way.

NA PROCESS AMENDMENT BILL 1991 Second Reading Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by My Duffy: That the Bill be now read a second time.  The House is debating the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill 1991. The coalition will not be opposing the passage of the Bill. Indeed, the coalition supports the Bill, although we take the view that it does not go far enough. In this respect, during the committee stage, time permitting, I will be moving comprehensive amendments which are designed to supplement the provisions found in the Bill. However, looking at the clock and the guillotine having been put down, I get the feeling-the debate on this Bill expires at 6.30 p.m., as I recall-that the Executive imposed guillotine on the Parliament will prevent me moving those amendments. Therefore, I hope that, in accordance with convention, the amendments will be incorporated in Hansard and it will fall upon my colleagues in the Senate to pursue the matter. The origins of the Bill under present consideration lie in a report produced by the Australian Law Reform Commission in 1987 entitled Service and Execution of Process. The Commission produced its report in June 1987 and the report was presented to Parliament in December of that year. The report came about because of a reference given to the Commission in November 1982 by the then Acting Attorney-General, the Hon. Neil Brown. The Commission was asked to inquire into a report upon the adequacy of the law relating to the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the States and Territories. In many respects the reference came about largely at the behest of some State judges who were concerned to see that the procedures for the service and execution of interstate process be streamlined. Accordingly, the Commission was asked to examine the adequacy of the provisions of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901, the Act that the Bill which we presently have before the House seeks to amend. Among other things, the Commission was specifically asked to consider whether it would be desirable for the provisions of the Act to be extended to cover tribunals which carry out adjudicative or investigative functions. By section 51 (xxiv) of the Constitution, the Commonwealth Parliament has power to legislate with respect to: The service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgements of the courts of the States: It was necessary to confer that power upon the Commonwealth Parliament, having regard to the inability of colonial legislatures to enact legislation with any extraterritorial effect beyond their respective boundaries. For example, at the time of Federation, John Quick and Robert Garran wrote: With reference to the service, beyond the limits of a colony, of civil process issued within a colony, the constitutionality of laws passed by colonial legislatures authorising this to be done has often been questioned. Prior to Federation, if one were to enforce a judgment obtained, say, in Victoria against a person domiciled in, say, Tasmania-out of respect for the honourable member who is following me-it was necessary to commence a further action at common law. That requirement flowed from the principle also mentioned by Quick and Garran which states: No man can bc legally bound by a judgment given behind his back and without his having had an opportunity of heing heard. By conferring upon the Commonwealth Parliament power to legislate with respect to the service and execution of interstate process, those jurisdictional doubts were settled. Therefore, in 1901 the Commonwealth Parliament passed the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901. That Act was the eleventh Act of the first Commonwealth Parliament. The 1901 Act, among other things, provides for: the service of initiating process for civil and criminal proceedings in State and Territory courts outside the State or Territory concerned; the service of other process in proceedings, including the process to procure witnesses throughout Australia; the execution of warrants for the apprehension of persons throughout Australia-in other words, the interstate extradition of persons; and the recognition and enforcement of judgments given by a court of one State or Territory in another State or Territory. The 1901 Act applies only to courts and, in the Law Reform Commission's view, this was a shortcoming which needed to be addressed. Turning now to the Bill, we see that a new part 3A will be inserted into the 1901 Act. The provisions found in new part 3A will govern the service and execution of process by investigative tribunals, such process relating to the service of subpoenas and to the execution of warrants. The new measures contained within the Bill will be available for current inquiries, such as the royal commissions in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and Victoria, and for use by the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) in New South Wales and the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland. The Attorney-General would not want me to discuss any of those royal commissions, would he? He is remaining mute on this matter. I will go on.

text: I suggest that you get on with it.  tertaining things. I could entertain the House by hanging them from the rafters, if I get onto a few of them. I will take the Attorney-General's suggestion tonight, because I want the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) to have the opportunity to speak on this Bill, which this side of the House is certainly not opposing. I was referring to the fact that it will apply to other commissions, to the ICAC and to the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland. In this respect, the Bill defines an 'investigative tribunal' to mean a body established under the law of the State for the purpose of inquiring into and reporting on any matter and, in doing so, a body that is authorised to take evidence on oath or affirmation. The definition of 'investigative tribunal' excludes courts or persons exercising judicial functions. By press release dated 24 August 1990, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) announced that the Government intended to repeal and replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 following consideration of the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. In the same press release, the Attorney General indicated that the Government would let the Bill lie on the tablc of the House so that further community consultation could take place. The Bill before the House at the moment is, as the Attorney-General acknowledged during his second reading speech, an interim measure, as it seeks to implement only one part of the Commission's recommendations. Were we to reach the committee stage and not be guillotined, I would hope to move amendments which seek to implement the entirety of the Commission's recommendations. Under the amendments that I hope to be move, those remaining parts will be subject to a deferred commencement clause so that an appropriate community consultation may take place and, if need be, the provisions can be fine tuned prior to their commencement. In effect, I wish to place a clear obligation on the Government to take action to implement the entirety of the Commission's recommendations within a fixed time frame-namely, one year-in order to fulfil the promise given by the Attorney General in August of late last year. The amendments, if carried, would ensure that the Government's Bill remains intact so that it will represent a self-contained part of the Act dealing with investigative tribunals. It is appropriate at this stage that I give a brief outline of the whole of the Commission's recommendations. The coalition accepts the Commission's recommendations. The major recommendations were: that the 1901 Act be updated in light of the development of an Australia-wide commercial community and advances in i the tcchniques of travel and communications; that the need for a plaintiff to obtain leave to proceed with an interstate service of initiating process be modified; that challenges to jurisdiction or the question of the appropriate venue not be determined solely on the basis of the traditional nexus conditions, but on an assessment of all relevant considerations; and that the reach of the 1901 Act be extended so that its provisions could be available for the service and exccution of process and orders of tribunals-both tribunals exercising adjudicative functions and tribunals exercising investigative functions. The Commission's recommendations have been well received. If implemented, the Commission's recommendations would represent a useful and meaningful revision of the Act and of the procedures used for the service and execution of process interstate. Perhaps the only controversial aspect of the Commission's rceommendations relates to the extension of the Federal Act to the service and execution of process and orders of tribunals. It is perhaps ironic that it is this aspect which we find the Government responding to today in the form of the provisions set out in the Bill under present consideration. Having touched upon the broader policy questions, I turn now to consider some constitutional issues that are relevant to the Bill and to the Commission's recommendations. At the conclusion of his second reading speech, the Attorney-General acknowledged that there is a question whether it is within the legislative competence of the Commonwealth to provide for the service and execution of process of State tribunals. It is appropriate that I elaborate on some of the issues involved therein. The question is whether the legislative power referred to in section 51 (xxiv) of the Con- of stitution is limited to the service and process of State courts as opposed to State tribunals. The issues were canvassed in some detail in the Commission's report. Having regard to the words of section 51(xxiv), it is necessary to consider whether the term 'courts' places a restriction upon the meaning of the word 'process'. A similar consideration arises in relation to the possible meaning of the words 'civil and criminal' process in the sense of whether those words are restricted to final and conclusive orders made by the courts. In this respect, most orders made by quasi-judicial tribunals are not enforceable unless and until they have been registered with the court. Subject to appropriate safeguards, once that registration process is completed, such an order may then be enforceable as a judgment of the court. The leading case in the area is the 1972 decision of the High Court of Australia in Amman v. Wegener, a report of which can be found in volume 129 of the Commonwealth Law Reports at page 415. In that case Mr Justice Gibbs, as he then was, said: In section 51(xxiv), which empowers the Parliament to make laws with respect to 'the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the Courts of the States', the word 'process' is not governed by the words 'of the Courts'; those words refer only to 'judgments'. In other words, section 51(xxiv) enables laws to be made with respect to the service and execution of.(1) the civil and criminal process of the State, and (2) the judgments of the Courts of the States. In that passage, Sir Harry Gibbs would seem to be reaffirming the broad interpretation placed on section 51(xxiv) by the earlier 1955 decision of the High Court in Aston v. Irvine, a report of which can be found in volume 92 of the Commonwealth Law Reports at page 353. In a unanimous judgment of the full bench it was said in Aston's case: The nature of this powerthat is, section 51 (xxiv)as well as the prior history of the subject to which it relates, provides strong ground for interpreting it as enabling the Federal legislature to regulate the manner in which officers of the law in one State should act with reference to the execution the process of another State. It is a legislative power given to the central legislature for the very purpose of securing the enforcement of the civil and criminal process of each State in every other State. However, returning to Amman's case, Mr Justice Mason, as he then was, expressed some reservations about 'whether or not the power'-as set out III section 51(xxiv)-'extends to the process of Royal Commissions and Tribunals which are not Courts in the strict sense'. The words of Sir Anthony Mason bring into play the very question of whether the Government's Bill, in seeking to insert a new part into the 1901 Act to deal with investigative tribunals, may in the event of a High Court challenge be found to be unconstitutional. Notwithstanding the reservations expressed in Amman's case by the present Chief Justice, I am somewhat optimistic that at the end of the day the provisions would be upheld-as, I am sure, is the Attorney-General. Perhaps I am influenced by the approach advocated by that great jurist Sir Owen Dixon that certain aspects of our Constitution should be given a liberal interpretation so that those provisions can adapt to the ever changing circumstances of our society. In any case, it would be a brave man at this time who would deny the power to the royal commissioner who asked the Attorney-General to give him the power. Quite apart from the courage that would need to be shown, I think it would show a lack of sagacity. For those reasons as well as the sorts of interpretations that I have put-

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Title: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF
text: Or just wrong.  is a helpful contribution after all I am doing here on behalf of the Attorney General. He should wait until the next Bill comes along. In regard to Sir Owen Dixon's more liberal interpretation of words so that we can have a living being, a growing Constitution, the words of section 51(xxiv) reflect the concerns that our founding fathers had at the time of Federation. At the time of Federation, of course, there did not exist the multiplicity and variety of investigative, administrative and quasi-judicial tribunals that we have today. I know a little bit about this because I have an ancestor who was involved in the debates of that time; he stayed on in the colonial parliament, allegedly because the talent came here. He stayed on in the new State Parliament of Victoria. Our founding fathers did not have to turn their minds to the question of whether the words of section 51(xxiv), and in particular the reference to 'courts', should be extended to cover other bodies, as they simply did not exist. I am also heartened by the approach that the High Court has taken in relation to the application of the Act to arbitration proceedings. In this respect I refer the House to a 1983 decision of the High Court in Alliance Petroleum Australia (NL) v. Australian Gas Light Co., a report of which can be found in volume 48 of the Australian Law Reports at page 69. In that case it was decided that the Act, in so far as it enables service of subpoenas issued in relation to arbitration proceedings, was valid on the basis that arbitration proceedings are civil proceedings within the meaning of section 16 of the Act. It would seem that analogous reasoning could be adopted with respect to the relationship between investigative tribunals and the concept of criminal process. For example, there is no doubt that committal proceedings come within the traditional concept of the phrase 'criminal process', and it is arguable that investigative tribunals are on a similar footing. There will remain doubts about whether the provisions contained in the Bill can survive constitutional challenge. Ultimately, if the question arises in any formal way, it will be a matter for the High Court to determine. I conclude my comments on the Bill by saying that the coalition welcomes the reform contained within it, and would welcome further reform by the Government at the earliest possible time by its implementing the Law Reform Commission's remaining recommendations. Perchance that my proposed amendments have been circulated in my name, I would trust that if I am unable to move them at the committee stage because of the guillotine they will at the very least be incorporated in Hansard.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF
text: In speaking to the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill 1991, I certainly would not wish to assign to the Attorney General (Mr Duffy) any lack of sagacity. He is a most sagacious Attorney, and in this regard the sagacious Attorney has very properly adopted a course in relation to the request of the royal commissioners conducting the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia to enact legislation which will facilitate the service, in other parts of Australia, of process emanating from that Royal Commission. If we direct our minds to the broader issue, it is useful to see this as a further step in the consolidation of a national legal system. It has always been puzzling for those who are not constitutional experts or versed in State laws that we have disparate legal systems with complexities of enforcement between the States and with gaps between the capacity to enforce the rulings of a tribunal or a process that emanates from them. As the shadow Attorney, the honour has correctly said, this whole area has been the subject of a report by the Law Reform Commission. The Government has that report before it and no doubt will be making more extensive legislative amendments in due course. But that is no reason for not proceeding in the urgency of this matter upon the request of the commissioners, who want to make sure that no witnesses resident interstate can avoid coming before a commission of inquiry duly constituted. Of course, now there is not simply one royal commission in existence, as this House is very much aware. There are royal commissions now established in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and Victoria, and there are commissions of inquiry on permanent investigative duties in New South Wales and Queensland. So the sense in which it might once have been thought to restrict the ambit or power of tribunals to their own local jurisdiction really has become quite irrelevant as we move towards full nationhood. I think most members of this House would welcome a Federal initiative to make sure that in one further area we treat our legal system on a national basis. Increasingly we do so by various mechanisms such as the cross-vesting of jurisdiction between State and Federal tribunals and courts. We look to make sure that there are avenues for the enforcement of State orders of courts so that they can be most effectively proceeded with and enforced. We have legislation which facilitates those matters. We turn now to the amendments which are before us. These are very sensible and common sense amendments. They build in many safeguards which are designed to ensure that no witness who is subject to compulsion to come before a commission of inquiry or an investigative tribunal will be put to any unnecessary difficulty. For example, if a witness is required simply for the production of documents, there are provisions in the legislation which facilitate the witness's providing that information without the need for personal attendance. Similarly, there are procedures which require, on the service of a subpoena for attendance, the proper tender of sufficient money to make sure that that witness can travel appropriately and be accommodated in the other State. Failure to comply with those obligations means that the subpoena is invalid. There are also provisions for the setting aside of subpoenas in certain circumstances which will allow a person upon whom a subpoena is served, who would urge in the particular circumstances that he or she ought not to be required to attend, to contest the issue of the subpoena. One important safeguard is that subpoenas have to be issued by a judge of the supreme court of the State in which the tribunal is proceeding. Obviously that will not occur without a considerable degree of scrutiny, and will not be a matter of course. All in all, this is a sensible and a modest response to the request made by the Royal Commission in Western Australia. It shows that this Government is willing to move promptly to respond to what was a request made of it. Turning briefly to the constitutional sues which have been raised, it would be apparent to most constitutional lawyers that, although from time to time some modest doubts have been expressed as to the ambit of placitum (xxiv) of section 51 of the Australian Constitution, the better view would be that the word 'process' is not to be read as limited in any way by the further words 'judgments of the courts of the States'. As the former Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs indicated in Amman's case, the issue appears to be clear with respect to the power to enforce process of investigative tribunals. Certainly it would require the upsetting of what is regarded as the established authority in this area for a challenge to succeed. To conclude my remarks, and because I do not believe this is a contentious matter, I indicate that this Government does not lack courage. The reason we are introducing this legislation is not that the Attorney is in some way reluctant to confront a royal commission; it is simply that the Government believes it is appropriate to act to extend a nationwide system for the recognition and enforcement of process from tribunals of inquiry and royal commissions, and that it is seen as timely to do so upon the request of the Royal Commission. I am pleased, of course, that the honourable member for Kooyong regards the Attorney as sagacious in that regard.

One must say that it is a pity that longevity is not what it could be, because although he died without children and there was a relationship in another way which I have forgotten, it would be no doubt a great pleasure to see that his relation, whatever it is, is able to be here today carrying on from that second convention on the Constitution in which Sir Alexander played a role. The most important matter with which I wanted to deal is the reason we are not dealing with more than this at this stage. The honourable member for Denison dealt with that matter sufficiently but, for the record, I will repeat that the Australian Law Reform Commission report on the Service and Execution of Process Act had a Bill annexed, but there are problems with that Bill which require further consultation. In relation to the draft replacement Bill, it will be necessary, for example, to make major amendments to the following parts of the Law Reform Commission's replacement Bill: first, the replacement of the code for personal service of process with rules picking up the mode of service intrastate; also, it will be necessary to deal with the replacement of the procedures for transfer of proceedings between State and Territory courts generally, with statutory power for lower courts to stay proceedings and the specific provisions relating to service of subpoenas on prisoners and the various other forms of lawful restraint including bail, parole and probation preventing travel interstate. In our view, and on close examination the Opposition would agree, I am sure, the Law Reform Commission's recommendations are really unworkable. If we adopted those recommendations, it would make a court a custodian of some people on bail. The problems with that are obvious, and in fact the court would have interstate custody of the person. When one looks at the drafting of specific provisions relating to tribunals, the Law Reform Commission included provisions picking up court procedures by reference and the inclusion of revised provisions in suppression orders, including add itional grounds, applications for each ground and for revocation of orders. In August 1990 we announced our decision to repeal and replace the Service and Execution of Process Act following consideration of those recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in its report. It has been made absolutely clear that, in the circumstances, the Government-and I do not think it is disputed by the support we have received this evening but, nevertheless I think there is some misunderstanding as to why it cannot all be done now-had no choice other than to proceed with the amendments with which we have now proceeded, rather than attempting to adopt that report of the Law Reform Commission which, I have indicated, in our view is flawed and a good deal more work will have to be done on it. The shadow Attorney touched on the various tribunals that are affected by this, and it is obvious-not that I would suggest any government would be silly enough to do it-that when an urgent request is received from the Royal Commission into the Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia, one would have been brave to the point of absolute stupidity to suggest, 'We could not do that for you now but we will do it when we have had the opportunity to consider more fully the Law Reform Commission's report. We do not want to make these amendments at this stage because we would rather wait until we are able to deal with the whole Bill'. As I say, to have done that would have been just absurd. Therefore, based on the request made by the Chairman, we decided to proceed with this Bill at this stage. It does affect quite a few other inquiries in addition to the Western Australian Royal Commission. It is for those reasons that we have decided to go ahead at this stage. Touching very briefly on one other matter, there has bcen some confusion as to exactly what the Bill does and what are its powers. While it provides that the interstate service of subpoenas will enable evidence to be given before State and Territory persons and bodies appointed or established for the purpose of inquiring into and reporting on matters, and which have the power to take evidence on oath or affirmation, nevertheless restrictions are placed on it. It will not be one of those pieces of legislation that can be used in a way which can be too flamboyant in that sense, because it requires leave of the Supreme Court of the State in which the tribunal is established for a subpoena to be served interstate, and I refer to section 19M (1).
