'(2) Where the power of a tribunal to make an order for costs in a proceeding is limited as to amount, an order made under paragraph (1) (c) that requires security to be given in excess of that amount is ineffective to the extent of that excess. '(3) Subsection (1) does not limit the power of the tribunal to make an order requiring security for costs. Other process may be served in any part of Australia '46. (1) A process issued in a State or Territory, other than a process that is(a) an initiating process; or (b) a subpoena addressed to a person who is not a party to the proceeding in relation to which the subpoena has been issued, may be served in some other State or Territory. '(2) Service must be effected in the same way as service may be effected in the place of issue. 'Division 3-Service of subpoenas related to adjudicative jimctions Application of Division '47. This Division applies with respect to a subpoena addressed to a person who is not a party to the proceeding in relation to which the subpoena is issued. Order for leave or for production '48. (1) Where a subpoena has been issued by or out of a tribunal in a State or Territory, a court of the State or Territory may, on application(a) if the subpoena is addressed to a person who is not under lawful restraint give leave to serve the subpoena outside the State or Territory; (b) if the subpoena is addressed to a person who is under lawful restraint in some other State or Territory and the person need not attend before a tribunal for the purpose of complying with it give leave to serve the subpoena outside the State or Territory; or (c) if the subpoena is addressed to a person who is under lawful restraint in some other State or Territory and the person must attend before a tribunal for the purpose of complying with it order that the person be produced at the time and place specified in the subpoena as the time and place at which compliance with the subpoena is required. '(2) The court shall not exercise a power under (a) paragraph (1) (a) or (1) (b) unless it is satisfied of the matters specified in paragraphs 23(2) (a) and (b); or (b) paragraph (1) (c) unless it is satisfied of the matters specified in paragraphs 29(2) (a) and (b). '(3) Subsection 23(3) applies, with the necessary modifications, in connection with the operation of paragraph (1) (a) or (1) (b). '(4) Subsection 29(3) applies, with the necessary modifications, to the consideration of an application for an order under paragraph (1) (c). '(5) Subsection 29(4) applies, with the necessary modifications, to an order made under paragraph (1) (c). '(6) In this section, "court" means (a) where a person who is a member of, or who constitutes, the tribunal of issue of the subpoena is a magistrate or a judgethe person; (b) in any other case-the court that would have jurisdiction to the extent of the value of the subject-matter of the proceeding, or the amount claimed in the proceeding in relation to which the subpoena was issued and if there is more than one such court: the court of more limited jurisdiction. Further provisions concerning subpoena or order for production '49. (1) Where leave has been given under paragraph 48(1) (a) in relation to a subpoena, se.ction 22 and sections 24 to 27 inclusive apply, with the necessary modifications, as if the subpoena had been issued by or out of a court or by an authority. '(2) Where leave has been given under paragraph 48(1) (b) in relation to a subpoena, se.ction 22 and sections 24 to 27 inclusive apply, with the necessary modifications, as if the subpoena(a) had been issued by or out of a court or by an authority; and (b) was addressed to a person who is not under lawful restraint. '(3) Where an order has been made under paragraph 60(1) (c), sections 42 to 48 inclusive apply, with the necessary modifications, as if the order was based on a subpoena issued by or out of a court or by an authority. 'PART V-EXECUTION OF WARRANTS 'Division I-General Persons subject to warrants may be apprehended '50. (1) Subject to this Division, where a warrant has been issued in a State or Territory, the person named in the warrant may be apprehended in some other State or Territory. '(2) The person may be apprehended by(a) a person by whom the warrant may be execl\ted in the place of issue; (b) a person who, in the State or Territory in which the person named in the warrant is found, has similar powers to a person referred to in paragraph (a); or (c) a member of the police force of the State or Territory in which the person named in the warrant is found. '(3) It is not necessary to produce the warrant when the person is apprehendcd. Procedure after apprehension '51. (1) A person shall, as soon as practicable after being apprehended, be taken before a magistrate in the State or Territory in which the person was apprehended and, if the warrant or a copy of the warrant is availablc, it shall be produced to the magistratc. '(2) If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced, the magistrate may(a) order that the person be released; or (b) adjourn the proceeding for such reasonable time, not excceding 7 days, as the magistrate specifies and remand the person on bailor in such custody as the magistrate specifies. '(3) If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced when the procccding resumes, the magistrate shall order that the person be released. '(4) If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is produced, the magistrate shall, subject to subsection (6), order(a) that the person be remanded on bail on condition that the person appear at such time and place in the place of issue of the warrant as the magistrate specifics; or (b) that the person be taken, in such custody and otherwise as the magistrate specifies, to a specified place in the place of issue of the warrant. '(5) The order may be subject to other specified conditions. '(6) If, on application by the apprehended person, the magistrate is satisfied that(a) the warrant is invalid or it would be manifestly unjust or oppressive to make either of the orders referred to in subsection (4)-the magistrate sha!! order that the person be released; or (b) it would be manifestly unjust or oppressive that either of the orders referred to in subsection (4) be effective immediatelythe magistratc shall(i) make an order under subsection (4) and suspend its operation until a specified time; or (ii) adjourn the proceeding for a specified time, and order that the. person be remanded on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies until '(7) An application may bc made at any time to vary an order made under paragraph (6) (b). '(8) When a proceeding resumes following an order made under subparagraph (6) (b) (ii), the magistrate shall(a) make an order under subsection (4) or paragraph (6) (a); (b) make an order under subparagraph (6) (b) (i) and order that the person be remanded on bailor in such custody as the magistrate specifies until a specifIed time; or (c) make a further order under subparagraph (6) (b) (ii) and order that the person be remanded on bailor in such custody as the magistrate specifics until a specified time. '(9) An order of a magistrate under this section may be executed according to its tenor. '(10) For the purposes of a proceeding under this section(a) the magistrate may adjourn the proceeding and remand the person on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies for the adjournment; and (b) it is not necessary that a magistrate before whom the proceeding was previously conducted continue to conduct the proceeding. Procedure on remand on bail '52. (1) Where a magistrate has made an order under paragraph 51 (4) (a), the magistrate shall prepare an instrument setting out the conditions to which the grant of bail is subject. '(2) The magistrate and the person the subject of the order shall each sign the instrument. '(3) A copy of the instrument shall be(a) given to the person; and (b) furnished to the court, authority, tribunal or person before which or whom the person has been remanded to appear. '(4) If the person(a) refuses to sign the instrument; or (b) does not comply with a condition to which the grant of bail is subject, being a condition precedent to the person's release on bail, the magistrate shall revoke the order and make an order undcr paragraph 51 (4) (b). '(5) If an amount of money or any other thing is given as security for compliance with the conditions to which a grant of bail under paragraph 51 (4) (a) is subject, a sum of money equal to that amount, or that thing, shall be paid or given to the Attorney-General of the place of issue of the warrant or, if the warrant was issued in a Territory other than the Northern Territory, that time. to the Administrator of that Territory. Review '53. (1) Where an order has been made under section 51, the apprehended person or a person to whom the warrant was directed may, within 7 days after the making of the order, apply to the Supreme Court of the State or Territory in which the order was made for review of the order. '(2) Where the application is made by(a) the apprehended person-a person to whom the warrant was directed shall be the respondent; and (b) a. person to whom the warrant was directed-the apprehended person shall be the respondent. '(3) Notice of the application must be served personally or by post on the respondent. '(4) The Supreme Court may, pending its review(a) stay the execution of the order; and (b) order the person to be remanded on bail or in such custody as the court specifies. '(5) The review shall be by way of rehearing. '(6) The Supreme Court may confirm, vary or revoke the order and, if it revokes the order, it may make a new order. '(7) The order as confirmed or varied, or the new order, may be executed according to its tenor. '(8) If the order as confirmed or varied, or the new order, is an order that is similar to an order n:ferred to in paragraph 51 (4) (a)(a) the Supreme Court shall cause an instrument of the type referred to in subsection 52 (1) to be prepared; and (b) subject to subsection (9), the succeeding provisions of section 52, with the necessary modifications, apply. '(9) For the purposes of paragraph (8) (b), a reference to a magistrate(a) in subsection 52 (2) is a reference to the person whom the Supreme Court has caused to prepare the instrument; and (b) in subsection 52 (4) is a reference to the Supreme Court. Law applicable to grant of bail '54. Notwithstanding subsection 68 (1) of the Judiciary Act 1903, the provisions of a law of a State or Territory with respect to the granting of bail apply in relation to a power under this Division to grant bail to a person apprehended in that State or Territory as if the person had been apprehended under, or by authority of, a law of that State or Territory. Enforcement, &c., of bail '55. The provisions of a law of the place of issue of a warrant with respect to bail and matters related to bail apply in relation to a person who has been remanded on bail under(a) an order made under paragraph 51 (4) (a); or (b) an order confirmed, varied or made under section 53 that is similar to an order referred to in paragraph 51 (4) (a), as if the person had been remanded on bail under, or by authority of, a law of the place of issue. Custody, &c., of persons '56. (1) For the purpose of complying with an order made under paragraph 51 (4) (b), or an order confirmed, varied or made under section 53 that is similar to an order referred to in paragraph 51 (4) (b), the person to whom the custody of the apprehended person has been committed may(a) require that the keeper of a gaol in some State or Territory receive the apprehended person and keep the apprehended person in custody for such time as the person requires; and (b) require that the keeper of a gaol who has custody of an apprehended person pursuant to a requirement under paragraph (a) surrender custody of the apprehended person to the person at the time and in such manner as the person requires, and the keeper of the gaol shall comply with such requirements as are reasonable. '(2) The provisions of a law in force in the place of issue of a warrant that relate to the liability of a person who escapes from lawful custody apply to a person being taken to the place of issue in compliance with an order referred to in subsection (1). Warrants issued by tribunals '57. (1) The preceding provisions of this Division do not apply in relation to a warrant issued by or out of a tribunal unless(a) the warrant was issued because of non-compliance with a subpoena in relation to which leave has been given under paragraph 48 (1) (a) or 48 (1) (b); or (b) the Supreme Court of the place of issue of the warrant (not being a warrant referred to in paragraph (a)) makes an order under subsection (3). '(2) For the purposes of the application of the preceding provisions of this Division in relation to a warrant referred to in paragraph (1) (a), the requirement under section 51 to produce a warrant or a copy of the warrant shall be taken to be a requirement to produce the warrant or a copy of the warrant and a copy of the instrument by which leave was given under paragraph 48 (1) (a) or 48 (1) (b), as the case may be. '(3) The Supreme Court of the place of issue of a warrant (not being a warrant referred to in paragraph (I) (a)) issued by or out of a tribunal may, on application, make an order authorising the apprehension of the person named in the warrant. '(4) Where the warrant was issued for the purpose of bringing the person named in the warrant before the tribunal to give oral evidence or to produce a document or thing, the court shall not make an order(a) where the warrant was issued in connection with the exercise by the tribunal of an adjudicative function-unless it is satisfied that the evidence likely to be given by the person, or the production of a document or thing specified or referred to in the warrant, is necessary in the interests of justice; or (b) where the warrant was issued in connection with the exercise by the tribunal of an investigative function-unless it is satisfied that(i) the evidence likely to be given by the person, or a document or thing specified or referred to in the warrant, is relevant to the exercise by the tribunal of the investigative function; (ii) the evidence, document or thing cannot reasonably be obtained from a person in the place of issue of the warrant; and (iii) where the evidence, document or thing may constitute or contain evidence that relates to matters of state-having regard to the purpose and subject matter of the investigative function, the public interest in having the testimony, document or thing made available to the tribunal outweighs the public interest in preserving secrecy or confidentiality in relation to the evidence, document or thing. '(5) An order may be subject to specified conditions. '(6) Where an order has been made under subsection (3) in relation to the person named in a warrant(a) the preceding provisions of this Division apply in relation to the warrant subject to the conditions, if any, to which the order is subject; and (b) for the purposes of the application of those provisions, the requirement under section 51 to produce a warrant or a copy of the warrant shall be taken to be a requirement to produce the warrant or a copy of the warrant and a copy of the order. Release of persons unnecessarily detained '58. (1) A person, who, pursuant to an order made, confirmed or varied under this Division, has been taken in custody to the place of issue of a warrant for the purpose of giving oral evidence or producing a document or thing, may apply to a court for an order that the person be released from custody. '(2) The person at whose request the warrant was issued shall be the respondent. '(3) Notice of the application must be served personally or by post on the respondent. '(4) If the court is satisfied that the person(a) has been in custody for a period that, in the circumstances, is unnecessarily long; or (b) need not continue to be held in custody for the purpose of securing the giving of the evidence or the production of a document or thing, the court may order that the person be released from custody and the person shall be released accordingly. '(5) In this section, "court" means(a) if the warrant was issued by or out of a court or by an authority-the court of issue or the authority of issue; or (b) in any other case-the Supreme Court of the place of issue of the warrant. 'Division 2-Suppression orders Interpretation '59. In this Division"jury" means a jury trying a criminal offence in a court; "protected person" means the person referred to in subsection 60 (1) as the person charged with a criminal offence; "publishing organisation" means a person who, or a body that, is in the business of publishing newspapers, magazines, periodicals, books or pamphlets or making radio broadcasts or television transmissions, whether or not the business is carried on for profit; "suppression order" means an order made under subsection 60 (2) and includes an interim suppression order. Suppression orders '60. (1) This section applies where it appears to(a) a magistrate conducting a proceeding under section 51; or (b) a Supreme Court conducting a review under section 53, that the publication of a report of(c) a part of the proceeding or review held in public; or (d) a finding publicly made by the magistrate or court, would, give rise to a substantial risk that, by virtue of the influence that the publication might exert on the members of the jury, the fair trial of a person charged with a criminal offence that may be tried by a jury might be prejudiced. \ '(2) The magistrate or court may, on application or of the magistrate's or court's own motion, make an order forbidding the publication of any report of the part or finding. '(3) The magistrate or court shall not exercise any other power that the magistrate or court might have to make an order in the nature of a suppression order for the purpose of preventing or lessening the prejudice referred to in subsection (1 ). Duration, &c., of suppression orders '61. (1) A suppression order remains in force until(a) it is revoked; (b) the verdict of the jury is given at the trial of the protected person; (c) the protected person is discharged in respect of the offence; (d) a plea of guilty made hy the protected person at committal proceedings in respect of the offence or at the trial of the person is accepted; (c) the prosecution of the protected person for the offence is discontinued; (f) if the protected person is the apprehended person concerned in the proceeding before a magistrate and the magistrate makes an order under paragraph 51 (6) (a)-the end of the period of 7 days after the making of the order; or (g) if the protected person is the apprehended person concerned in the review before the Supreme Court and the order confirmed, varied or made on review is similar to an order referred to in paragraph (f)-the confIrmation, variation or making of such an order. '(2) A suppression order(a) shall specify whether it is to be enforceable in(i) the State or Territory in which it is made; (ii) other specifIed States or Territories; or (iii) throughout Australia; and (b) may be made subject to specified exceptions or conditions. Interim suppression orders '62. Where an application has heen made for a suppression order, the magistrate or the Supreme Court may, without inquiring into the merits of the matter, make an interim suppression order to have effect, subject to revocation, until the application is determined. Variation and revocation of suppression orders '63. (1) A suppression order may be varied or revoked(a) where the suppression order was made by a magistrate conducting a proceeding under section 51-by a magistrate in the State or Territory in which the proceeding is or was conducted; (b) where the suppression order was made by a Supreme Court conducting a review under section 53-by the court; (c) in either case-by a magistrate or court before which the protected person has appeared or been taken for the purposes of committal proceedings in relation to the offence or the trial of the person for the offence. '(2) The power to vary or revoke a suppression order may be exercised on application, or on a magistrate's or court's own motion. Application, &c. '64. (1) An application for a suppression order, or for the variation or revocation of a suppression order, may be made by(a) the apprehended person; . (b) a person to whom the warrant was directed; (c) a witness in the proceeding or review in which the suppression order is sought; (d) a publishing organisation; (c) a person who satisfies the magistrate or court that the person has a special interest in the question whether a suppression order should be made, varied or revoked; or (f) where an application is made for the variation or revocation of a suppression order-the applicant for the suppression order. '(2) A person referred to in subsection (I) may, without being joined as a party to the proceeding or rcview, make a submission to the magistrate or court on the question whether a suppression order should be made, varied or revoked, and may call or give evidence in support of that submission. '(3) The magistrate or court may delay a proceeding or review to allow a submission to be made, or evidence to be called or given, as referred to in subsection (2). Appeals against suppression orders '65. (I) Except as provided by the Judiciary Act 1903, an appeal lies as of right against the decision of a magistrate or court(a) to make a suppression order; (b) not to make a suppression order; (c) to vary or revoke a suppression order; or (d) not to vary or revoke a suppression order. '(2) The appeal lies(a) if the decision was made by a magistrateto the Supreme Court of the State or Territory in which the decision was made; or (b) if the decision was made by a court-to the court to which appeals against final judgments or orders of the court in civil proceedings generally lie. '(3) Except as provided in this section, no appeal lies against a decision or order made under this Division. '(4) On the appeal, the appellate court(a) may confirm or vary the decision, or revoke the decision, whether or not it substitutes another decision; and (b) may make orders for costs and deal with any other incidental or ancillary matters. Institution of appeals '66. The appeal may be instituted by(a) if the decision the subject of the appeal was made on application-the applicant; (b) the apprehended person; (c) a person to whom the warrant was directed; (d) a publishing organisation that(i) made a submission to the magistrate or court that made the decision the subject of the appeal; or (ii) did not make a submission as referred to in subparagraph (i) but that satisfies the appellate court that the failure to make such a submission was not attributable to a lack of diligence on its part; (e) a person who made a submission to the magistrate or court that made the decision the subject of the appeal; or (f) a person who did not make a submission to the magistrate or court that made the decision the subject of the appeal but who satisfies the appellate court that(i) the person has a special interest in the question whether the suppression order should be made, varied or revoked; and Oi) the failure to make a submission to the magistrate or court was not attributable to a lack of diligence on Disobedience of suppression order '67. (1) A person shall not fail or refuse to comply with a suppression order. Penalty: A fine not exceeding $5000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year. '(2) It is a defence to a prosecution for an offence against subsection (1) if the defendant proves that(a) at the time when the publication was made, the defendant did not know a fact that made the publication a contravention of subsection (1); and (b) either(i) before the publication was made, the defendant had taken all steps that were reasonable in the circumstances (having regard, among other things, to the likelihood of such a contravention) to ascertain that fact; or Oi) if the defendant did not take the steps referred to in sub-paragraph (i)-the defendant would not have discovered that fact even if all those steps had been taken. PART VI-JUDGMENTS Interpretation '68. In this Part"court of rendition", in relation to a judgment, means(a) the court in which the judgment was given, entered or made; or (b) if the judgment is an order of a tribunal(i) if a law of the State or Territory in which the tribunal is established provides that an order of the tribunal is enforceable without registration or filing of the order in a court-the tribunal; or (ii) in any other case-the court in which the order is registered or filed otherwise than under this Part; "enforcing court", in relation to a judgment, means a court in which the judgment is filed under subsection 69 (1); "place of rendition" means the State or Territory in which the court of rendition is established; "proceeding" includes a proceeding as defined in section 38; "relevant initiating process" means the initiating process issued in relation to a proceeding in which a judgment has been given, entered or made. Enforcement of judgments '69. (1) Upon production of(a) a copy of a judgment certified by an officer of the court of rendition to be a true copy; or (b) a copy of such a copy of a judgment, the prothonotary, registrar or other proper officer of an appropriate court in a State or Territory other than the place of rendition shall file the copy in the court. '(2) The judgment thereupon becomes a record of that court and(a) has t-e same effect; and (b) subject to subsection (3), may give rise to the same proceedings by way of enforcement or execution, as if the judgment had been given, entered or made by that court. '(3) A judgment is capable of being enforced in or by a court of a State or Territory in which a copy of it is filed under subsection (I) only if, and to the extent that, at the time when the proceeding for enforcement is or is to be taken, the judgment is capable of being enforced in or by(a) the court of rendition; or (b) a court in the place of rendition. '(4) In this section(a) "appropriate court" means a court in or by which relief as given by the judgment could have been given, and if there is more than one such court, the court of more limited jurisdiction; and (b) a reference to enforcement, in relation to a judgment, includes a reference to execution in relation to the judgment. Stay may be granted '70. (1) A court of a State or Territory in which a copy of a judgment has been filed under subsection 69 (1) may, on application by a person against whom the judgment has been given, entered or made, order that proceedings in that court by way of enforcement or execution of the judgment not be commenced until a specified time, or be stayed for a specified period, on condition that the person make ,and prosecute an application to an appropriate court to set aside, vary or obtain other relief in respect of the judgment. '(2) The order may be made subject to other conditions, including conditions as to the giving of security. '(3) In subsection (1), "appropriate court" means a court that has jurisdiction under a law in force in the place of rendition to grant an application to set aside, vary or obtain other relief in respect of the judgment. Costs '71. Where a copy of a judgment is filed under subsection 69 (1)(a) the reasonable costs or expenses of and incidental to obtaining the copy and filing it are recoverable in proceedings by way of enforcement or execution of the judgment; and (b) entitlement of a person to, and the liability of a person for, the costs or expenses of and incidental to such proceedings are the same as they are in proceedings by way of enforcement or execution of a similar judgment given, entered or made by the enforcing court. Interest '72. Where a copy of a judgment is filed under subsection 69 (1), interest on the amount of the judgment(a) is payable at the same rate or rates and in respect of the same period or periods as would be applicable in the court of rendition; and (b) is recoverable to the extent that the judgment creditor satisfies the court in which proceedings by way of enforcement or execution of the judgment are taken as to the amount of the interest. Rules of private international law not to apply '73. Where a copy of a judgment is filed under subsection 69 (1), a court of a State or Territory in which it is filed shall not refuse to permit proceedings by way of enforcement or execution of the judgment to be taken or continued by reason only of the operation of a rule of private international law. PART VII-MISCELLANEOUS Jurisdiction of courts with respect to matters arising under Act '74. (1) The several courts of the States are invested with federal jurisdiction and, so far as the Constitution allows, jurisdiction is conferred on the several courts of the Territories, with respect to matters arising under this Act. '(2) The jurisdiction so vested in, or conferred on, a court is vested or conferred without regard to the limits of jurisdiction of the court under the law of the State or Territory in which the court is established. Jurisdiction of courts and tribunals in proceedings '75. (1) The jurisdiction that a court has by virtue of service of process under this Act is not affected by any limitation arising under a law of a State or Territory concerning the locality in which the process may be served. '(2) The jurisdiction that a court of a Territory has by virtue of service of process under this Act extends only so far as the Constitution permits. '(3) Where an initiating process has been served under this Act, proceedings against a person by way of enforcement or execution of a judgment given, entered or made in the proceeding in relation to which the initiating process was issued shall not be taken in any court unless the court is satisfied that(a) the initiating process was served personally on the person; or (b) the person has received actual notice of the judgment. '(4) In this section"court" includes tribunal; "proceeding" includes a proceeding as defined in section 50. Constitution of courts '76. The jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory in a matter arising under section 48, 49W, 53, 57, 58 or 60 or under paragraph 63 (1) (a) or 65 (2) (a) shall be exercised by the court constituted by a single judge. Regulations '77. (1) The Governor General may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Act, prescribing all matters(a) required or permitted by this Act to be prescribed; or (b) necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Act. '(2) In particular, the regulations may make provision for or with respect to(a) the practice or procedure in connection with the service and execution of process and judgments; (b) the fees to be paid in connection with the service and execution of process and judgments; (c) the costs or expenses to be allowed to a person for obtaining a copy of a judgment and its filing; and (d) the recovery of any such fees, costs or expenses. '(3) The regulations may make different provisions with respect to different States and Territories, with respect to different process and judgments and with respect to different courts and tribunals. '(4) So far as the regulations do not make provision for or with respect to a matter of practice or procedure, the practice or procedure shall be(a) in connection with the service of processthe practice or procedure that would be applicable in the place of issue; and (b) in connection with the execution of process or judgments-the practice or procedure applicable in the State or Territory in which execution is effected. '(5) So far as the regulations do not make provision for or with respect to fces, costs or expenses, the fees, costs or expenses shall be(a) in connection with the service of proccssthe fees, costs or expenses that would bc applicable to service in the place of issuc; (b) in connection with the execution of proccss or judgments-the fces, costs or expcnses applicable in the State or Territory in which execution is effected; and (c) in connection with obtaining a copy of a judgment and its filing-the fees, costs or expenscs applicable in the State or Tcrritory in which the copy is filed. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a third time.

Title: TRIBUNALS

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Dundas) (8.00 p.m.)I was hoping that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) might be here tonight to listen to this debate. I am glad in a sense-although I understand these matters are still under deliberation-that he is the Minister on duty tonight. I see that he has brought plenty of advisers along to at least listen and prepare comments for him. The Bill that we are dealing with is the Migration Amendment Bill 1991. The explanatory memorandum mentions the detailed issues that are covered in this particular Bill. We are told that it is designed to improve and streamline immigration procedures in three main areas: immigration processing of undocumented arrivals-that is, essentially those people who are commonly referred to as boat people-the merits review system; and the operation of the Migration Act. We have been anticipating an amendment Bill to the Act. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) foreshadowed almost 12 months ago that he would be seeking to introduce an amending Bill, following on from some of the criticisms that had been mounted in relation to the Act and regulations. In the main, the amendments tonight will prove to be largely unexceptional, dealing with technical and grammatical amendments among others. However, there are some significant matters and also some matters which have been the subject of some discussion between the Minister and myself and which may bring forward further amendments that he has outlined in correspondence that has passed between us. I will highlight those as I discuss the Bill. The first matter that I mention relates to an amendment dealing with section 4-'lnterpretation'-of the principal Act. The principal Act dealt with the issue of who might be an authorised officer. The matter that was of concern to me and on which I sought clarification was the extent to which the Minister might be given power under the amendments to authorise any other person to be an authorised officer of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. This matter was of concern to me. I understood it was to deal with staff who mi-ht be engaged to deal with data proceSSIng arrangements. The Minister has foreshadowed that he will clarify that further by amendment to prescribe that such a.uth-risations may only proceed by notIce In the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I thank him for that. The next matter that is dealt with is the period of grace, particularly provisions relating to the operation of the period of grace in this legislation which have been proposed to be clarified. The period of grace would recommence in the event that an applicant for an entry permit withdraws his or her application or a person withdraws certain review requests. It allows for recognition of the withdrawal of such an application or request. That amendment seemed particularly reasonable to the Opposition. The next matter that was dealt with was the concept of an entry visa being broadened to give the document dual quality. An entry visa can act either as an entry permit or a visa when it is first issued depending on where it was in the circumstances of the application. This is to enable it to operate vice versa. There is also a provision introduced to protect returning permanent residents from innocently becoming illegal. Without detailing further the changes that are intended there, let me say that that matter also has the Opposition's agreement. Provisions were made to remove certain redundant provisions under section 47 and to reinforce the existing powers to grant visas and entry permits under sections 24 and 34. It was also supplemented by the Minister's special powers under s-ctions 115 and 137. The existing proviSlOn to grant a permanent entry permit to Australia only to the holder of a valid e-try permi- was retained. Those proviSlOns met WIth our agreement, as did the provisions dealing with increases in penalties, remuneration-so far as it affects the Remuneration Tribunal-and also amendments dealing with the technical problems that were occasioned by the difficulty that the Government was experiencing in dealing with rendering carriers liable to certain costs associated with the Commonwealth's ability to remove persons who are not permitted to enter Australia and to keep those people in custody. . Th?se - atte.rs were covered extensively In thIS legIslatlOn and, as I say, met with our approval. There are, however, some other matters which this legislation deals with which were the subject of discussion between the Minister and myself. One of them relates to the question of character checking. The explanatory memorandum explains that with the insertion of new s-c-ion 107A there would have been proVISlOns to allow, under prescribed circumstances, an immigration officer to assess the character or conduct or both of an individual on the basis - f a decl-ration made by the individual. Whilst provisions were still to exist under sections 20 and 14 of the Act to provide for deportation of that person if he was found to have made a false declaration, we in the Opposition were concerned that this particular provision could open a new area for abuse and possible confusion which can arise in relation to this important question of character checking. We were concerned that rather than leaving the matter open for this matt-r to be dealt with by way of prescribed clfcumstances-that is, by the regulatory procedure-the Act itself ought to make more explicit the way in which this question is to be dealt with. The Minister in his letter to me says that this clause has the potential to cause confusion about departmental practice in relation to character checking and may lead some people to believe that character checking will not be attempted in particular situations. He therefore agreed that all applicants who were not Australian citizen's will be required to make declarations and that he would move amendments during this debate to require all visa and entry permit application forms to contain a declaration about character to be made on behalf of the applicant. The legislation and the explanatory memorandum, which the Minister has shown me, will spell out in greater detail the way in which that matter will be addressed. I welcome his cooperation in relation to that. The next matter that was dealt with concerned certain custody arrangements. We were concerned about custody arrangements under sections 88 and 89 of the Act and the processing area amendments contained in this Bill. We raised the point, as well as it being raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, that the Government, in endeavouring to put in place, as I understand it, revised but essentially the same arrangements for dealing with those people described as unprocessed people who enter Australia illegally-usually we are speaking about boat people-and in wanting to be able to deal with them in a more humane way than it is often able to deal with the landing of such people, needed to put in place new arrangements for dealing with such applications. One of the issues was the extent to which such people might be kept in an unprocessed state, essentially in detention:, over a long period. In his letter to me the Minister has assisted in explaining the way in which this matter would work. It may be important, from the point of view of this debate and to people looking at this particular question, to understand 84the basis upon which the Opposition has accepted the Bill in the form in which it now proceeds. The Minister stated: The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was concerned about the absence of a specific mechanism Act to allow a person to challenge being designated an unprocessed person. However, a decision to designate a person an unprocessed person would be a decision which could be challenged under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 on the basis that an error of law had been made in arriving at that designation. That Act would allow for a declaration to be made as to whether a person is an unprocessed person. Proceedings under that Act are relatively easy to initiate and conduct. However, apart from relief of a declaratory kind from the Federal Court, it is not intended that there be a mechanism in the Migration Act which would provide for the release of a person from a processing centre other than in compelling circumstances such as the need for medical treatment. It must be borne in mind that unprocessed persons will be persons who have arrived in Australia without permission, seeking to enter Australia in circumstances in which they would become illegal entrants and in which proper immigration, health, customs and quarantine clearance procedures have not been carried out. For the purposes of the Act, these persons have not entered Australia and are potentially prohibited persons. While clearance procedures are being conducted after the persons' arrival, the policy to be expressed in the legislation is that they be restrained from entering the broader Australian community. I mention that because the Opposition has a very strong view about the need to maintain the integrity of Australia's immigration program and borders. In my discussion I will return to the ways in which I think the Government has been less than scrupulous in addressing these matters in the past, which are leading to a breakdown in immigration control. For that reason, the Opposition was not mindful to press any amendments in this area which might send a signal or might suggest in any way that by seeking to accord specific rights to unprocessed persons, it was relaxing Australia'S ability to be able to ensure that those who seek to circumvent our immigration requirements will not be rewarded by being allowed to remain here by use of our legal procedures or otherwise. I wish to address two other questions dealt with in the Bill. The first is the amendment to reduce the processing days available for people who might want to apply for review of decisions taken under the Immigration Act. The Minister made in the it clear that the Government was moving amendments to the review provisions to give more generous periods in which a review of certain decisions might be taken at the first tier and before the second tier review; that is, the review by the Immigration Review Tribunal. I should explain the background, in part, to the basis upon which the review provisions were enacted. When the Immigration Act was the subject of substantial amendments by the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), he and I were involved in certain decisions about the form in which the Bill then before us might be amended. One matter I raised with him was the question of the extent to which it might be more difficult for people outside Australia to access review. Under the old review arrangements there were periods of between, I think, one month if people were in Australia, or 90 days if they were outside Australia. Senator Ray said, 'Let's compromise on this', and he proposed a compromise of 28 days for people within Australia, and 70 days for people outside Australia, to access review. Senator Ray put in place provisions for people to exercise their review rights for both stages within those specific time limits. The Government is now seeking to provide separate times for undertaking applications for each process. I do not regard it as unreasonable, nor does the Opposition, to separate them out, but it is clear that by doing so the Minister is doubling the times in which people can access review through both stages. In effect the Government is taking it from a period of 28 days to 56 days and from 70 days to 140 days for which applicants can seek to have applications dealt with through both stages of review. I have to say that the Opposition sees those as unduly long periods of time. They compromise the immigration review process in an unreasonable way and do not require people to be expeditious in pursuing their rights. The Opposition intends to move amendments at the appropriate stage to reduce each of those periodsthat is, 28 days to 21 days, and 70 days to 50 days. In effect, that would prescribe 41 days in lieu of 28 days, as it was before, and 100 days in lieu of 70 days, as it was before. In other words, it would still be more generous than the Minister's provisions, but it would attempt to ensure that people are still required to press their claims expeditiously. I want to mention the matter of reviewable decisions. The present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has made it clear, again in correspondence to me, that where there were some doubts in our minds because the Government was providing that classes of decisions under section 120, under which the Minister may exercise powers under sections 115 and 137 of the Act, might be expanded by way of regulation. In his note to me, the Minister indicated clearly the areas in which that prescription will be made. I think it is appropriate to put it on the record for clarity. The Minister states: You have asked which decisions will be prescribed. As 1 indicated in my Second Reading Speech, the decisions prescribed will concern applicants who are unable to sustain a claim for refugee status but who are to be assessed on humanitarian grounds, and those long standing illegal entrants who came forward as a result of the Government concessions that took effect in December 1990 but in respect of whom the current law prohibits the making of further applications. To be more precise, the pa,rticular decisions that will be identified in the draft instructions for regulations are: . - refusal of a domestic protection temporary entry permit-regulation 117A - refusal of a December 1989 [temporary] or [permanent] entry permit-regulations 131A and 142c Honourable members can see in relation to those matters that in our discussions the Minister and I have reached a large measure of agreement in relation to this particular legislation. In the time left to me I want to deal with the question of control of the immigration program, because that is a matter of concern to the Opposition. In our view, the Government seems to have failed to control and maintain the integrity of Australia's borders. In order to understand what has been happening, one need only look at the area of change of status application to permanent residency for people who have entered Australia on visas obtained for other purposes, either as visitors or as temporary entrants. Notwithstanding all the protestations of the Government, there has been a significant increase in the number of people seeking to stay in Australia as permanent residents who have applied to do so onshore. This is notwithstanding the fact that we have ruled out amnesties; it is notwithstanding the fact that the Minister went on and said time and time again that the Government was going to be tough in relation to illegal entrants. In 1989-90, 14,355 persons were approved for permanent residency. As at 10 June 1990, there was a backlog of more than 35,000 cases, some of them under the new arrangements, some of them under the old arrangements, for grant of residency status. The indications are that the great bulk of those who applied under the old rules or the old regime are likely to be granted entry to Australia. This sends out a signal to those people who are seeking to come to Australia, and who would not meet the immigration standards set down for entry from overseas, that if they can simply get to Australia and apply, they will be rewarded. We forget the statement that the Deputy Secretary to the Department made, which I think in clarity states the position, which ought to be the Government's bible in relation to these things. Mr Gibbons said: All States have the sovereign right to determine who may enter and remain within their territory . . . Immigration rules are essentially about control of the borders; about filtering those who would seek to enter. What we are seeing is that the Government is losing that control, and it is particularly evident in relation to the large and growing number of onshore change of status applications that we have seen in various forms that have been coming forward. When it is known that we have numbers, which the Government itself admits approach 90,000, and which I believe are probably nearer 150,000, of people who are here illegally, the enormous size of the problem that we are facing is appreciated. The Government tries to adduce evidence through deportations, raids and a great deal of judicious press that it is very active in relation to these matters. But the fact is that, when we should be dealing with tens of thousands, we are merely dealing with hundrcds of people-or maybe at times thousands, but not the tens of thousands that we know are here in Australia illegally now. We have, of course, certain other problems that have emerged as a result of the way in which this Government has dealt with the issue, particularly of refugee status. On the whole question of these provisions in this legislation that deal with unprocessed persons, we in the Opposition have given the Government every support to put in place a proper legislative base to deal with these issues. These areas of concern are leading to a situation in which our ability to control our borders is being lost to us here in Australia right now, and it is through the numbers of people who are claiming refugee status. We used to receive applications that might approach 500 in one year from people who were seeking protection within Australia because of their claim of being in need of protection because of their genuine fear of having to return to their home country where they might well have suffered persecution, and which they had left as a result of that persecution. The principles here are well understood. They are applied internationally. But the fact is that, because Australia has relaxed the way in which it deals with these matters, because of the way in which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) dealt with decisions in relation to Chinese students who were in Australia at the time of Tiananmen Square, when it refused to undertake proper bona fides checking, when it put in place provisions to treat all arrivals on the same basis, regardless of the bona fides of their claim, Australia lost its ability to deal with refugee claims in a proper and sensible way. There is an enormous amount of evidence on the record right now that that one decision, taken by the Prime Minister of his own volition-and I do not believe with the support of his Department or the responsible Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairshas led to a situation where we now have about 14,000 applicants for protection, for refugee status. Those figures, according to departmental evidence given to the Senate Estimates Committee, are rising at the rate of 1,000 a month. They are expected to peak at about 20,000. The Department is faced with the enormous cost of putting in place new administrative arrangements to cope with that inordinately large number of people. We know that the Government allowed some 20,000 people from the People's Republic of China to enter Australia after the Tiananmen Square massacre as students, many of whom came here, I believe, with the expectation that they would be able to make claims to stay permanently. I made that point in debates at earlier points in time and we know that, of the 14,000 people making applications now for refugee status in Australia, over 8,000 are from the People's Republic of China. In other words, of those 20,000 students who entered Australia, a very significant proportion are now claiming to be refugees and are swamping our system of evaluation. In fact, our ability to entertain claims from those people, who are often seen to have some justification for consideration on refugee grounds, is being lost to us. I will just mention, because it has been a matter of some controversy recently, the claims in relation to boat people. The fact is that the great bulk of people who enter Australia seeking to access refugee status do not come by boat at all; they come by plane. In fact, one of my Chinese friends refers to them as 'jumbo people' to make the distinction between boat people. It could be said that we have 150,000 jumbo people as against 300 boat people to deal with. Some of the Cambodians are making claims for refugee status. The fact is that their claims, notwithstanding the fact that many of them have been here for very long periods of time, have not been able to be entertained. The Minister might be able to give us all sorts of reasons, as we have seen in the past, for the way in which those applications have been dealt with, but the fact is that the reasonmore substantial than anything else-that they have not been able to be dealt with is the misapplication of resources. Mrs Crosio-Talk to some of the lawyers in this country.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I say to the honourable member for Prospect that it would not be in the hands of the lawyers if the Department had the resources to properly ensure that advice was available to those people as they arrived here in Australia and to ensure that claims were put forward in an expeditious and sensible way. But the fact is that we now have institutional paralysis. That is what we have got: institutional paralysis. We saw the very shoddy way in which the Cambodian people were recently treated. I do not complain that Cambodians, Khmers, may have been shifted around in the dead of night by the Department, because I did not complain when they were shifted from Darwin to Sydney or from Darwin to Melbourne-and I would not have complained if they were shifted from Sydney to Darwin. But the fact is that there are some very reputable people, some that I know, who attended meetings with the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I am told that the Minister gave the assurance to the Khmer people in Sydney that no Khmer would be shifted without being properly advised of what the Government's intentions were in relation to that person. I am told that at a meeting on three occasions he promised that such notice would be given. I regard that as a very serious matter. It is a matter which the Minister needs to clarify and it is a matter that I think undermines his credibility in dealing with this issue. r put out a statement some weeks ago in which I said that the Minister needed to be strong in the way in which he dealt with these matters. If the Khmer cannot substantiate proper claims, they have no more right to remain here than the Chinese students. Claims should be dealt with consistently on a case by case basis. Those without bona fide claims should be sent back to where they came from. It is the only consistent and proper way in which the border controls about which this legislation speaks can be administered properly without being brought into disrepute and without being undermined in the way in which we have seen. Unless the Government gets this under control quickly, we face a problem of very significant proportions.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The Migration Amendment Bill involves a number of important amendments to the Migration Amendment Act which have already been signalled in a number of important decisions of the Government over the last few months. These amendments have also been extensively debated and discussed. Many of them have come, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) knows, through the deliberations and recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, of which he is the Deputy Chairman. Others came after extensive discussion at the Caucus immigration committee. I want to thank the members of both committees for the role they played in trying to get together an immigration system which works, which is fair and in which the crinkles which were left when we brought in all the regulations at once after the new administration came in can be ironed out. The interesting thing about the honourable member for Dundas is that, on the one hand, he supports the system for immigration regulations but then goes on to make such claims as the Government is losing control of the immigration program. I do not get that complaint at all. If anything, I get the opposite complaint-that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is generally too tough in its determinations rather than losing control of the program. So I do not know where he has been and what he is on about. Quite often at the Joint Standing Committee we have to make amendments in order to ensure that justice is done to individual applicants and that the Department does not exercise its powers in too rough a fashion or in such a way as would deny natural justice to applicants. I know that the honourable member has also complained in this way about the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, so how can he say that the Government is losing control of the immigration program? I do not know where that sort of claim comes from. I know that there are a couple of honourable members around the place who do not like our immigration program and would like it to be reduced to nothing, but that is a different matter altogether. It certainly has nothing to do with the generally rather responsible fashion in which the Immigration Department has been handling a difficult transition from a process of non-regulation to one of regulation in the immigration area. Of course, there continue to be problems to iron out. We have this legislation because, although many of the problems have been ironed out by changes to the regulations, there is also from time to time a need for important legislative changes. In saying this, I do not in any way run away from the fact that there are problems in the immigration area. But it does not follow that the Government is not handling them properly or has lost control of the program or-Mr Ruddock-An extra 120,000 does not matter?

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I will address that as one of the problems. Let me turn to that problem of the increase in applications under refugee status. The honourable member knows that, because of the desire to control the numbers and because of the toughening regime, we have had to control applications from people who want to change status when they arrive in Australia either as visitors or as students. We have said that previously the matter was too lax. We have had to bring in regulations to make matters tougher so that most people will return overseas if they wish to apply to emigrate to Australia. They will have to apply in the proper queues and under the proper programs; that is what we have tried to do. In those circumstances, one could expect that there may be some people who feel so desperately about the idea of going back to their own countries that they are prepared to use any loophole in the system or to use any way possible to apply. That is what has happened, and the honourable member knows very well that that is the reason for the increase in the refugee applications. The vast increase in the numbers of refugee applications has to do, as he mentioned, not only with the problem of the People's Republic of China-I will come back to that in a minute-but also with other countries to which people feel, either for economic or for humanitarian reasons, they just cannot return. What would the honourable member for Dundas have us do? Would he have us say, 'We will not have the refugee humanitarian category at all just because there has been an increase in numbers'? Should we get rid of people without consideration? That would be a nonsense and he knows that. There is no point in him pretending to be some kind of humanitarian on immigration law and then saying that these people should not be able to apply under the refugee humanitarian category. Of course, they should be allowed to apply. The question is: what can be done once the applications have increased to these numbers? I do not know why he is making such a fuss about the increased numbers. The fact is that the increased numbers have to do with contingencies which are out of our control. Because of that, we had a choice to make. We could have arbitrarily-Mr Ruddock-That is the only thing right you said, that it is out of control.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The program is not out of control. The contingencies are different. We did not create the problem with the People's Republic of China. That had to do with something over there. We had to deal with the problem in a humanitarian fashion. For the honourable member for Dundas to come in here and to say, 'Because of the situation you have got a big increase in refugee applications; therefore, it is all your fault and therefore the fault of the program', is a nonsense. The fact is that this is a problem created overseas, having to do with the situation in the People's Republic of China. Let me continue on this point. On the one hand, we have said that we cannot simply arbitrarily dismiss these applications as nothing; we have to deal with them in a reasonably humane way. On the other hand, we have to be ready to deal with them speedily because, if we are not, we will have years and years of queues in the system. So we have introduced the radical new system of dealing with refugee applications, which is a two-tiered process. First, they are considered on one level within the departmental structure. If they are rejected, they have the right immediately to appeal to the new Refugee Status Determination Committee. Given that situation, whereby they are able to go through the two processes, we will see many people accept the determination because they will realise that they do not have much of a case. Other people will go to the other body. Once that body has set criteria with respect to particular groups of people, people will see that it is useless merely to make an application for refugee status on flimsy grounds, because it will be defeated. Once the system is given a chance to operate in the future, I am confident that, even though we have had this increase in operations, it will deal with them in a speedier and fairer fashion. If the honourable member has some suggestions as to how we can deal with these problems in a humane way, let him come forward with them at the Joint Standing Committee or within the Parliament. Let us hear them. But it is nonsense to say that because there has been such an increase in applications the whole system is falling apart. The Government has not created the increase in the applications; it has been created by the contingent factors in such places as the People's Republic of China. It is true that some people are trying to use the refugee situation as a last loophole after they have been rejected for othe- immigration categories. I think that is a matter the Government ought to look into. If somebody arrives in Australia, whether as a visitor- a student or anything else and claims refugee status, that is very different from a person arriving, claiming immigration status, being rejected under a whole number of immigration categories, and then trying to claim refugee status. That, it seems to me, is a matter that ought to be looked at. One way of cutting out the flimsy claims may be to look into the question of whether, if a person has applied for other kinds of immigration categories, he should at that point be entitled to apply for refugee status. It seems to me that a person knows whether or not he is a refugee when he arrives or shortly afterwards. For a person to be able to wait until after he is dealt with through other immigration categories and who fails before he applies for refugee status, it seems to me to be over- ment. generous on our part to allow for a loophole. That could be looked into by the Government and the committees. I suggest that this is one way we can go forward in solving these problems. I also wanted to speak on a number other issues, including the question of the boat people, but time has virtually run portant out. Let me say a couple of things about the boat people situat.ion. The Bill tains provision for the Minister for migration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to set a time limit whereby, when a person arrives unauthorised in this country, he has to make an application. That is something we found when we visthe ited Darwin with a parliamentary comit mittee, and it has been emphasised time and again by the Caucus committee. We should be setting a time limit within processing must take place. One of the biggest problems in the Sydney debacle was that for nearly months the lawyers were playing games and did not put in the people's applicathink tions. That is a disgrace. Whether it is fault of the rules, the Department or the lawyers is not the issue. Mr Ruddock-It could not be the fault of the Government, could it?

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Listen to this. The Government set down the regulations on this matter. I am saying that what is necessary now is an even tougher situation where we require people, when they arrive in these circumstances, whether they arc represented by lawyers or by anyone else, to make an application within a specified period of time. Those people will get a fairer go because they will not be waiting for one whole year-as is happe-­ ing in Darwin, for example-before theIr applications even go to the Department, never mind before they are considered. I believe that such a determination, which I understand is going to be made by regulation as a result of a clause in this Bill, ought to go forward as quickly as possible. That determination, along with other determinations and suggestions, I think will be put forward to the Joint Standing Committee and will go to the Govern

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I cannot let this opportunity pass to express my disgust at the way the Government has handled the presentation of a number of Bills to the Parliament during this week Tonight we deal with one of of many important matters, yet the time limit for debate on these particularly imissues is severcly restricted. In fact, we had the absolute farce earlier this conafternoon where the time for the dcbate Imon an important environmental Bill actually expired before we got to deal with it. I want to say very clearly to the Government that I believe I am elected by the people in my electorate to do a job, and Government's ineptitudc in the way has presented these Bills to Parliament has denied me the right to carry out my responsibilities correctly. r want to put which that on record as strongly as I can. Listening to the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), if one were to 15 take him seriously-and I am not sure whether or not everyone does-one would that Australia has in some way rethe neged on its responsibilities in its immigration policies. I would have thought that he would krlow-I think most people dothat Australia has done far more than its share in accepting refugees to this country. We have accepted refugees from all over the world. It is probably correct to say that we have had a higher per capita intake of refugees to this country than any other country in the world. As far as I am concerned, it is ridiculous to suggest that we have in some way abrogated our responsibilities. We in Australia can hold our heads high in terms of our response to the needs of genuine-and I think that is the word that underlines this-refugees. If people listened to the honourable member for Calwell, they could sometimes interpret him as saying that we ought to have some sort of laissez faire immigration policy-anything goes, Rafferty's rules, anyone can come. That is not the approach we on this side of the House would advocate at all. Yet when I listen to him sometimes I think that is rcally what he has in mind and what he would like to sec happen. I find that absolutely unbelievable. As the honourable member [or Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said, and I think he is reflecting the view of by far the majority of Australians, we have a responsibility and a right to protect the integrity of our borders. We must do that in the interests of all Australians. The suggestion that we should in any way encourage people to come to Australia in the hope that once they arrive here they will somehow have an implied right to stay is dangerous, improper and certainly misleading. It is not the intention of the Government, and it is certainly not the intention of the Opposition, that people should be given the impression in any way, shape or form that once they come here they will be able to stay. Yet I think the honourable member for Calwell is leading us down the track where we give the wrong signals to people who want to come here from some of these countries which have-and there is no doubt they have-political and economic turmoil. We do not blame them for wanting to come here; we want them to understand that we will give them every consideration. In humanitarian terms, I believe that we as a nation can hold our heads high for the way we have reacted, for the way we have responded to people who have cried out in their time of need. We have done that consistently, year after year, going back to the years immediately after the Second World War. But we must ensure that we set the rules and, having set the rules, apply them fairly and consistently so that people know what the rules are. People must know that there is no advantage to them to hop in a boat and float across the ocean, and, having arrived here, to be given the impression that somehow they will be able to stay. Notwithstanding what I have said, the Government is guilty, in my view, of giving the impression that that can happen. We have alluded time after time in this place to the Government's handling of the Chinese students. Confronted with a difficult problem-obviously a difficult problem, and we had sympathy for the situation of some 20,000 Chinese students-the Government, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in particular, almost overnight took a decision that they could all stay. The signals go out around the world to the people waiting in line to come here legitimately. The criticism, quite fairly and logically, is levelled at us that all these people have jumped the queue. We have recently taken further action to give them the impression that they will be able to stay. They are now able to attend citizenship programs, they are entitled to get jobs, and they are entitled to social security. By the end of their time here they will be very comfortable. I am sure it is going to be very difficult for us then to turn around and say 'Time is up; it is time to go home', if they have not been given permission to stay at that time. Our concern in this whole debate, when it comes up from time to time, is to make sure that we have rules and that those rules are applied strictly, fairly and consistently. Any suggestion that is made that that situation has broken down I believe is very dangerous indeed. It is interesting that this debate tonight on immigration should occur at a time when the whole immigration issue is high on the agenda for debate within Australia. An increasing number of people-and, I have noted, an increasingly significant number of economists-have begun to question the wisdom of Australia maintaining the levels of immigration it has sought in recent years. I think it is also significant that a number of ethnic people have also taken that stance. I do not know the answer to that question. I find it a very difficult area. But, certainly, it is at the moment a controversial subject and one which is being reviewed. It is a fact that the entrenched positions taken by people, for various reasons, are being questioned. An increasing number of Australians have begun to question the whole concept of multiculturalism because of the way that they see it has divided rather than united the Australian community, as its intention may well have been. It is also a coincidence that this debate comes at a time when confidence in this Government and its Prime Minister is at an all-time low. I do not know whether the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) will come into the Parliament tonight to participate in this debate. He seems to still be the immigration Minister, and I assume he will retain that position, having apparently picked the right side today in supporting the Prime Minister. But I ask whether there is in fact any confidence in this Government. Has the Minister given the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) some advice?

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: You just get back to your speech.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I will listen to what she has to say. Let me ask that question again: is there any confidence in this Government's immigration policies? Last night on 60 Minutes, I was interested to view, I think, a very one-sided presentation, admittedly, of the question. It certainly placed the whole question very high on the agenda. When a program picks up a subject and runs with it in the way that it did, it certainly does get a lot of exposure. It will be interesting to see what sort of reactions are received to that program. I remind the House that at present there is a huge number of illegal immigrants here in Australia. I do not know the figure, but the official estimates are in the order of 90,000 to 100,000. The information I have is that the number could be as high as 150,000-and that would vary, as I understand it, on anyone day. But these are not people who have come in boats-at least not the sort of boats that we think about when we talk about the boat people, the sort of clapped-out boats that float across the ocean and find their way to Australia's northern shores. These people who have overstayed, these 150,000 illegals or overstayers, if we like to use that word, are people who have come here on holidays-they have decided they like the place, so they have just stayed on-or they are people who have come here as students, decided that they did not like being students after all and have gone out and got themselves a job; or they are people who have come here as businessmen and they have abused the privilege that they have been given of coming here. There is an enormous number of people in that category. I think the Government is responsible in this particular area. In my view, the Government has shown itself to be incompetent in properly policing this particular situation. I would be interested to hear an argument that tells me that the Government is acting properly. I know that it has attempted to put a few inspectors out there to catch these overstayers, but I do not believe it is doing anything other than just plugging leaks as and when they arise. The Government, in fact, will be shown to have acted ineffectively in this particular situation. My concern-and I have raised the matter with the Minister personally on one occasion and written to him on a number of occasions-is that these people, these illegals or overstayers, if we want to use that sort of euphemistic term, are taking jobs off Australians. Jobs are being taken off Australians at a time when we need to preserve jobs for Australians. If there has been no other time in the last 60 years that we have needed to preserve jobs, we need to do it now. They are taking jobs particularly in my electorate. This probleth is rife in my electorate. The reason that I am so close to this particular issue is that I reckon a considerable proportion of these illegals are living and working in my electorate and taking jobs off young Australians. In my electorate, we have a youth unemployment rate of almost 30 per cent. In my electorate, we have a significant number-and my advice from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is hundreds and perhaps thousands-of people taking jobs that ought to be going to young Australians who are leaving school. These illegals-and I have also brought this matter to the Minister's attention and had some sort of perfunctory responsehave obtained tax file numbers without any problem at all. There is no problem with providing the necessary identification. They get drivers' licences and credit cards and live very comfortably here. They take jobs and pay tax-or they take jobs and do not pay tax at all. At least we would think we would get some tax out of them, but we do not even get any tax out of half these people. The unfortunate side, I guess, from their point of view, is that they are probably not even being paid proper wages and they are living in substandard conditions. There are a number of unscrupulous employers-and I am even-handed about this and critical of the ones that employ them-who are prepared to take advantage of these illegal immigrants and to employ them at below award rates. I believe that in these times of record high unemployment every effort must be made to ensure that illegal immigrants do not work here. I believe this is a matter in which we all have a role to play. I have suggested to the Government that it should contemplate a public relations thrust to make all employers aware that they have a responsibility to their country-because that is what it really boils down to-to ensure that they employ only Australian citizens or those who are legally entitled to work here. It is really only a simple matter of employers being able to recognise what a visa looks like. If a person's visa says 'No work' in big capital letters, of course he or she ought not to get a job because tl-at person is not entitled to work here. There is no doubt in my mind, as the honourable member for Dundas has said, that refugees are a legitimate cause for immigration. As I have said, we have taken more than our share and I believe we ought to continue to do that. In fact, it ought to be said that we as a country have had the highest immigration programs traditionally in the world. If we take 1988, we had a figure then of 8.7 per thousand compared to the United States with only 2.1 per thousand. So we have maintained at least in recent years the highest immigration program per capita in the world. We support a sympathetic and humanitarian approach to the refugee issue. We certainly agree that it is not as simple as pushing the boats when they land in the north offshore and hoping they will go somewhere else.
