However, the point that I am making, and I think the point that the honourable member for Calwell fails to grasp, is that in the handling of this problem justice must be done and must be seen to be done. We have talked tonight about the whole issue of the so-called unprocessed persons. In a sense, it is pathetic that we have this problem, but we do, and by and large we believe that these persons need to be approached sympathetically and humanely and given the opportunity to prove their bona fides at that time. We do not see it as an option in any sense to push them back. lVIr Hand-What a contradiction. lVIr BRADFORD-It is not a contradiction. If it is not clear to the Minister, I will say it again. lVIr Hand-You don't know what you are talking about. lVIr BRADFORD-If it is not clear to the Minister, I will try to make it a bit clearer. We believe that these people can be processed humanely, as long as we do not give the message that the Minister and his Government seem to want to give. We think that message is the wrong message; that is, that in some sense people are being encouraged to arrive here in the hope that we will give them some extra special treatment or some special privileges that the people over there, who are lining up and going through the proper procedures to get here, are not receiving. That is the difference. There is a great concern in the community as to whether there are continuing long term economic benefits for Australi- in maintaining a high immigration program. As I have said, many people are questioning that, although I am not entirely convinced one way or the other. Nevertheless, we need to make sure that the people who do the right thing and get on the end of the queue are the ones who are granted entry. That is why we cannot be sympathetic to illegal immigrants, no matter how worthy their cases or causes appear to be. Recently, an English woman in my electorate gave herself up as an illegal immigrant. In many ways, I suppose, she had been a fairly good citizen during the time she had been here. She had been in Australia for nine years, for the last six of which she had no visa. When she owned up to the fact-she had a guilty conscience-the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs terminated her bank job and ordered her deportation. Some people in the community came forward to defend her position. They pointed out what a good person she was and so on, but at that time, in my view, there could be no objective justification for allowing her to remain here. As it turned out, the real argument boiled down to the fact that she was British. There were some interesting contrasts being made at the time with the handling of some other, non-British people. The suggestion was made that if she had been Vietnamese, Chinese or Cambodian-to put it in the current terminology-the treatment she received would have been different. I remind the Minister and the honourable member for Calwell that it is important that policy be applied fairly and consistently if it is to have any credibility. In my last minute I will talk about a couple of other programs. I have raised these matters with the Minister. If he wants to take them up with me again, I would be happy to do so because I have written to him about them. The business migration program is shown to be deficient; it is being rorted. In another recent case, once again in my electorate, a person came to Australia under the business migration program. It was subsequently found that he had been gaoled for seven years in Japan on criminal charges and that he had been refused entry to the United States. When he was found here, he left. He was going to be deported, but I think he decided to leave. He quit while he was ahead. In my view, this is just the tip of the iceberg of the problems with this particular program. I do not think the Minister can deny that there have been numerous rorts in association with that program. I also have concerns about the working holiday program. The Minister is satisfied that it is working well. Let me tell him again that it is not. Mr Hand-What was that?

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The concerns I have with the working holiday program have been raised with the Minister. He is happy with the way it is working. I am telling him that it is not working, but we can differ on that. The temporary business entry program is also being abused. Recently I pointed out some of the problems I had with that program to the Minister. There is no doubt that postwar immigrants have made an enormous contribution to the development of this country, but those were different times-they were times of economic growth and expansion. A high immigration policy now may not be as appropriate as it was in 1950. As I said, I am an agnostic in that particular area. We have attempted to be bipartisan-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Mrs CRO,SIO (Prospect) (9.03 p.m.)On rising to speak on this Migration Amendment Bill, I can honestly say to the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) that, if he reads the Bill and the amendments that are going to be made, he might understand and appreciate that a lot of the tautology we have heard in the previous 20 minutes really has nothing to do with the amendments before the House. In the closing stages of his speech he commented on business migration without acknowledging the proposals the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) has already put forward for investigation and review, and without even acknowledging the very detailed investigation by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into what is happening in that field. It is extraordinary for an honourable member to get up and speak on a Bill that is before the House without understanding or appreciating it and with very little knowledge of what it is about. He then had the audacity to criticise the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who was completely misrepresented by the honourable member when he remarked about refugees. I would have that corrected in the Hansard records. I commend the Government for taking this action because it improves not only the efficiency of migration legislation but also the efficiency of the processing procedure for people who wish to travel to, enter or leave Australia. The Migration Amendment Bill will enable the Government to better handle the "boat people', to whom the previous speaker, the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford), and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) referred, while their applications are being processed, in that these migrants will have a status. As the law now stands, boat people are legally deemed as not being present in Australia, yet the Government houses them, clothes them and feeds them. This Bill will give the boat people 'legal status', during the proper processing of their applications. The Bill is a small but important part of the overall reforms that the Government has made regarding immigration policy. These reforms have tightened up loopholes in the legislation and produced a fairer system of immigration for all. I have been especially interested in the effects that this legislation will have on the processing of illegal and unexpected immigrants, such as our boat people. I believe it is of great importance to Australia for immigration officials to be able to process these illegal immigrants in an orderly, efficient and speedy manner. The honourable member for Dundas implied that the hold-up of the applications being processed was the Government's fault. We all know what has occurred since those people unfortunately arrived uninvited and illegally into this country almost 18 months ago, others as reccntly as three or four months ago. In fact, some of the applications have not· even been presented to this day. Again, I say to the members of the Opposition that when they spcak about those things they should have the facts and report them correctly. I have the utmost sympathy for many immigrants who face lifestyles in countries much harder than ours. Nevertheless, it is important to remember that these people are illegally in Australia - nd may very well have been unable to mIgrate to this country if they had followed the correct procedure, like the vast majority of immigrants. The problem that mallY legally processed would be migrants face is that due to the sheer number of applications for immigration into Australia, coupled with the problems of processing illegal immigrants' applications, there is a very lengthy wait, often up to two years, for applications to be processed. Illegals, and boat people, do not help the situation. If anything, they hinder the opportunities of legal immigrants to come to Australia. Sponsors of the migrant families see that many of the boat people are allowed to stay in Australia and begin to wonder whether the way to get their relatives out here is for them to jump aboard a boat. Clearly, this attitude does nothing to support any immigration debate. We have become accustomed to people fleeing from one country or another, but what is of concern as far as the boat people are concerned is that this situation never seems to change. There will always be people trying illegally to enter try seeking a better life. Refugees throughout the centuries have been an unfortunate result of most wars, political upheavals, persecution, floods famine. But no century can equal the twentieth century for the huge wave of people displaced from their place of birth and forced to live in refugee environments. There are an estimated 14 million refugees all over the world, and millions more who are not strictly classified as refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees but who are in great need of humanitarian assistance. Australia's main involvement with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has been as a country willing to accept refugees. Unfortunately, as the numbers and the diversity of refugees increase, the traditional immigrant receiving countries, such as America, Canada and Australia, are showing signs of compassionate fatigue-a term coined to explain the increasing reluctance of these countries to continue to take large numbers of refugees. Over the 40 years since the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees was established, refugee situations have proliferated throughout the world. Australia has responded to this by accepting more than 420,000 refugees during that time. Australia's official refugee policy that it accepts refugees because of an humanitarian commitment to assist in relieving the plight of the people who have no country to which they may return in safety. Australia now is under increasing pressure as the number of refugees continues to expand with the development of more crises internationally-crises such as the developments we have just experienced in eastern European and the Kurdish situation in the Middle East. One of this Government's more recent changes to the migration regulations has been that by which the grant of protection through refugee status or on humanitarian grounds does not now lead to a resident status under the Migration Act but leads to the grant of a four-year temporary entry pera coun- mit subject to review. Having one of the highest populations of people of ethnic backgrounds living in my electorate, more than 15 immigration and cases a week come through my office, often after applications have been unsuccessful and often with heart breaking stories of attempts to get families into Australia. One of the most heart wrenching legal cases came from Vietnam recently and involved a woman who has been trying to get her husband and two children out to Australia since 1986. The woman was separated from the rest of her family five years ago in a refugee camp and was brought to Australia, without her family, under an official refugee program. Since that time, much of her life in Australia has been spent in social isolation. She has experienced difficulties in learning a new language and has found the opportunities to find work and learn new skills very limited. Unfortunately, her family's application has been rejected because she is unable to sponsor its membe"rs as she is now on unemployment benefits. Without the support of her family unit, she is cut off from family interaction and consequently does not have any person close to her who would undertake to sponsor her family for her. It is frustrating for this Vietnamese woman, who is trying to do the right thing is by Australia; she has legally but unsuccessfully applied for her family to come to this country and yet now she sees other people from her own country arriving as boat people and endeavouring to obtain refugee status. I must make it clear again that, although I am sensitive towards these refugees and their situations, in Australia we have rules and regulations which must be adhered to. Boat people leave their own countries illegally and arrive here illegally. This country has been built on migrants, but not on illegal migrants. There are now well in excess of 90,000 illegal migl,"ants within Australia. Australia itself 'cannot simply open its gates to all of those who wish to enter either temporarily or permanently. This Government is obliged to the Australian people to consider the domestic labour market, public health and safety and the economy's capacity to provide for the needs of the population. (Quorum formed) I appreciate very much the coalition, in opposition, calling continual quorums on me, as they do. At least I then have the advantage of my colleagues coming in here to listen to the remainder of my speech. I know full well that they are glued to the television sets in their own rooms, aware of what is going on. This is probably about the ninth quorum that has been called on me this year. If people consider that I am standing up in the House with a slight chip on the shoulder, they will not mind in future if I get up and look around me so that I can remove this chip. The Migration Amendment Bill, which we are debating now in this House, is a most important piece of legislation. I would like to bring to the attention of the Opposition that, following the Second World War, Australia accepted 170,000 displaced persons from the refugee camps of Europe. This was a very quick and a very positive action. Throughout the 1960s and the 1970s refugees from all over the world were given asylum in this country-refugees from Hungary, from Czechoslovakia, from Chile and other parts of Central and South America, and Africa. The immigration of the Indo-Chinese people who have settled in Australia since the end of the Vietnamese· conflict has been controversial largely because of the way in which many of them arrived-that is, by boat-and also because they seem to have just kept coming. The arrival of the boat people has also been resented by many because of the cost to Australia in holding them here-whether it be the cost of feeding, clothing or housing themwhile their applications for refugee status are processed. My previous example represents one occasion when people in my electorate have legally processed applications for this country and have endeavoured to have their families join them without success. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs took over the full cost responsibility for illegal migrant detention centres at the beginning of 1989-90. Some interesting figures have come out of that. Nationwide, in 1990 1,497 people were admitted to those centres and their average length of stay was 15.5 days. The Villawood centre, on the periphery of my electorate, admitted 801 persons, whose average stay was some 16 days. Maribyrnong admitted 489, with an average stay of 19.6 days and the Perth centre admitted 207 persons, with an average stay of 4.1 days. The average cost is $320 per person per day. Those are 1990 figures. Illegal immigrants are certainly an expensive burden for Australia to carry. The legislation within this Bill will speed up the processing of refugee applications for those who are being held in illegal immigrant detention centres and therefore decrease the financial burden illegal immigrants place on Australia. The 1991-92 immigration program will serve Australia well and will continue to meet the Government's objective of achieving a balanced intake of settlers from the family, skilled, refugee, humanitarian and special assistance streams. The balance achieved over the past two years will be maintained, with some increased emphasis on our humanitarian response and the new special assistance category, which I believe will greatly increase the flexibility of our overseas resettlement programs. This Government and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs are certainly on the right track with their immigration policies and legislation. I believe this Bill continues in the direction that this Government has followed. I commend it to the House, and I hope that other speakers in supporting it will acknowledge the work that is being done to assist not only those people who at the moment have a right to legally enter this country but also those who have certainly been given every opportunity to have their applications processed in a most humane and sensitive manner. The media, in carrying on about happened to the Khmer-Cambodian areas. people, conveyed a lot of misinformation. I appeal to those people who arc aware the situation, and particularly to our dia which broadcast that story throughout Australia, to at least have factual mation before them. If they do not have the factual information, they should least take the time to speak to the people concerned. Most of thosc people who demonstrated rccently reside within the boundaries of my electoratc. I can assure refugees. this House that I am wcll awarc of the circumstances that arose. Certainly what we havc read is quite different from facts that were presented at the particular time. As I said in an inteIjeetion on the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), a lot of the proccss and cernationality tainly a lot of the loss of time has becn to do with the lawyers and the processing of the applications of these people in their to it. assessment for refugee status. Today a lot of them have still not had an opportunity to put their applications forward ?ecause their legal pcople have prevented It. We must have laws that regulate or certainly control the entry of people into this country. Most particularly, those must be enforced in a humane way and with compassion and integrity. I have full confidence in the people in the Departin ment of Immigration, Local Governmcnt and Ethnic Affairs who will apply the visions of this Bill. I commend the ister for the highly skilled departmental staff that he has. I certainly commend them for the way in which they carry out what must be a very trying exercise they have to reject or say to a pcrson, 'You may have the right to a rcview'. is not an easv task, but it is a task for which they ha;"e bccn wcll trained. I mend them, and I commend the Bill beSoviet fore the House. lVIr NUGENT (Aston) (9.22 p.m.)-The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in speaking to this Migration Amendment Bill has canvassed the coalicovers tion position. I will speak to one part of the Bill, namely, that which concerns unfor what processed persons and the processing Australia has a proud record of comof passion in accepting refugees. I remind methe House that people such as boat people, who come to Australia without the correct infordocumentation, are granted temporary entry permits and may apply for recogniat tion as refugees and on that basis seek permanent residence. Refugee status is determined in accordance with the Geneva Convention relating to the status of A refugee is defined by international the law as a person who, owing to a wellfounded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality or who, not having a and being outside the country of his former habitual residence, is unable or, owing to such fear, unwilling to return Refugee status is considered by the Committec for the Determination of Refugee Status, which makes recommendations to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), who has the final responsibility for laws the grant of refugee status. Since World War II more than 430,000 refugees and displaced people have settled Australia from Europe, Asia, the Middle East, Central and South America and Afprorica. Among them have been 170,000 Minpeople from Europe, including 63,000 from Poland, 34,000 from Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, 23,000 from Yugoslavia, 14,000 Hungarians, 5,000-plus Czechoslowhen vakians, 13,000 White Russians, over 100,000 Indo-Chinese and 22,000 east It Europeans. Other groups accepted included 18,000 Lebanese, 2,000 others from comthe Middlc East, 6,000 Timorese, 4,800 Jews, 2,800 Latin Americans and 250 Africans. In 1989-90 refugees and special humanitarian program arrivals-which is the spccial humanitarian program that persons whether in their own country or outside of it who are ineligible rcfugee status but who are suffering or have a well-founded fear of persecutiontotalled nearly 12,000 people, compared with 10,000 arrivals in 1988-89. The principal source countries for refugee and special humanitarian program arrivals in 1989-90 were Vietnam, 5,600; EI Salvador, 1,800; the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, 1,000; and the Lebanon, nearly 500. I agree with the Minister that it is important that boat people and similar people are treated with sensitivity. We are told by the explanatory memorandum to this Bill that the Bill introduces a new regime for the immigration processing of persons who arrive in Australia who it is not practicable or convenient to process for immigration purposes at the point of arrival because of difficulties associated with the place or timing of their arrival. This new regime enables their orderly processing, including the capacity for the speedy assessment of and reaction to any medical conditions which they may have. We are told it is a response to the increasing frequency of undocumented and 'unexpected' arrivals and brings more convenience and practicality to the processing of such arrivals both at busy airports and at remotc locations. It also enables processing outside the strict custodial situation of sections 88 and 89 of the Migration Act 1958 and, to this end, persons who arc held in section 88 or 89 custody may also be taken from that custody and brought within the scope of the new processing scheme. As an active member of Amnesty International, I am concerned for the well-being of refugees. I recognise the need for time in the processing of unexpected arrivals, for the orderly process and for the practicality of holding and investigating such arrivals. However, I must say, as a migrant myself-who, I might add, waited his turn to come into this country-that I am concerned at the lack of detail in the Bill. I am concerned at the apparent intent to ease up on controls for those who seek to come here illegally. The Bill itself merely defines a processing area in the following terms: 54A. The Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette, nominate areas to which unprocessed persons may be taken for the purposes of section 54B. I ask the Minister: where are they to be located? How many people are we talking about? What conditions of restraint will apply? How long will people be held there? Why is no time limit being stated on the decision making process? My concerns are really whether we hold people for lengthy periods, whether there are births in camps, whether they are near cities when perhaps there is the likelihood of escape, and, given the current Government's inability to deal with the 90,000odd ilIegals who are loose in Australia, whether there is sufficient control. I see this whole process as loosening the strings and increasing the general problem we have. Queue jumpers will be tempted to try this method of entry. Genuine people who go through the proper process will be disadvantaged both by the people queuejumping and by the fact that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will divert its resources into this area rather than handling the normal processing. I must admit I also have a bad dream about mass refugee pens, which very mueh conjure up visions of Hong Kong. I accept that the Bill is well motivated but I regret t!Jat it lacks the detail to allay my fears. It has the potential for encouraging many illegals who cannot gain entry by fair means. It could disadvantage genuine migrants who play the game. It will devour resources from the Department of Immigration. It could lead to the Hong Kong type of refugee camp nightmare. This Bill really sends the wrong message to the rest of the world. The Government should be deciding on these cases expeditiously but firmly. It should be sending a message of discouragement, if you like, and genuine migrants should be getting much more attention. I fear that all this Bill will do is introduce a new class of arri val on our shores-not unprocessed persons, but pseudo refugees using this legislation when they cannot get here legally by other means.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Melbourne-Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs) (9.30)-in reply-Much has been said-unfortunately, some of it is inaccurate-regarding what the Government is trying to do, and it shows that some honourable members have not cared to read the legislation and the proposals before the chamber. We have had a whole ,series of comments made about immigration which were of a general nature but did not necessarily have much to do with the matter before the House. First, I want to address the constant comments made about illegals. As honourable members know, some time ago the Government put additional resources into this area, and probably tomorrow I will be announcing the latest figures for the end of April, which may give all honourable members some joy. The fact is that the predictions of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and others about this figure of 90,000 as of 30 April last year and the blow-out that he and others have predicted have not occurred. In fact, quite a contrary position has been achieved. I pay credit to the officers in this section of the Department, who have applied themselves in an excellent way to what is a very difficult and delicate area of activity, that is, finding and processing illegals, and having to be quite careful about how that process is carried out. I place on record my congratulations to them for the way in which they have gone about their duties. So tomorrow honourable members will hear some good news about illegals. Also, for the benefit of the chamber, I want to say that illegals are not wanted here in Australia. Illegals are the single greatest threat to the immigration program. . Mr Bradford-Good!

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am glad that the honourable member says 'Good' because it is a statement. I have made on many occasions, and I will repeat it for the benefit of the honourable member. We must have stability in our immigration program, and I, like the honourable member, get very crooked on people who fly in here, ignore the rules of the game, and just stay here. I repeat: if you are an illegal, leave or regularise your status, and allow those people who are in the queue to take up their place here. Those people who are being processed-Mr Bradford-They will all pack and leave tonight, I suppose.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: When the Government announced the staffing increase in the compliance section of the Department, people such as the honourable member hoo-ha'd the Government and made all sorts of predictions about how the numbers would continue to grow. They have not, and that is because of the illegals campaign we have waged in the past six months. I am sure that the shadow Minister will at least nod his head in agreement, because that is about all he could do at this stage. We have constantly raised this issue. It is not a very popular issue sometimes because every illegal who wants to stay here thinks he ought to be entitled to. I am saying that they all ought to pack up. In fact, if they liked, from time to time. I could arrange someone to help them pack so they could leave and come back the right way. That is just one point about which honourable members opposite rambled on concerning our lax procedures, et cetera. We have applied resources and an announcement is due which will show that the score is on the board. We will maintain our efforts and continue to see that number fall. A number of other points were made, one with respect to the Cambodians. A long bow was drawn about the Cambodians and those from the People's Republic of China (PRC) who were allowed to stay here as a result of their being in Australia on 20 lune-Tiananmen Square time. We have been through this debate concerning the PRC nationals about three times. I will not go over old ground, apart from saying that that announcement was made and it will be honoured. What I do find mystifying is that the shadow Minister continues to create uncertainty in the minds of these people and, I think unintentionally, adds to the confusion that has been genetated amongst those PRC nationals who arrived here after 20 June. That is a bit of a problem, but I do not say that it is done intentionally. The commitment made by the Government will be honoured, and we will deal with anyone else who puts forward an application for refugee status, change of status or whatever in the proper way. Those opposite cannot have it both ways. One minute they are asking us to be tough, then they suggest that we are too tough, and the next minute they criticise the way in which we handled the Cambodian vote. There is a whole series of contradictions. If they read the three speeches from the Opposition side, if they have nothing else to do tomorrow, they will see a fair degree of contradiction between the three speeches and even within them. I stand by the decision to move the Cambodians from Sydney to Darwin. About a week ago I went out to a meeting which a large number of the Cambodian community attended and I also met with the leadership of the Cambodian community in that area and the support groups and I spelt out the processes to them. I find it extraordinary that people who have been in the process for, I think, 15 or 18 months, as I remember, are claiming that they did not understand the process. That is extraordinary when towards the latter half of last year I was approached by the support group, the Jesuit refugee group and the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, who asked me whether the cases of these people could be re-examined by the Legal' Aid Commission of New South Wales just to make sure they were all in order. In a sense of fair play, if there was this degree of doubt by the Jesuit refugee organisation and the support groups, I thought it proper to agree to the request. That took another seven months. This is a very difficult and delicate ter. First, J want to be sure that every person claiming to be a refugee is given a fair shake. If a person goes through the process and is not proven to be a refugee in terms of the criteria laid down, certain things will flow from that. Mr Ruddock-And should.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: And they will. The point is that we are playing around here with human lives, as if it were some sort of game. It is not a game. Our task is to ensure that everybody gets fair treatment. So when we received this request from the Cambodians, we agreed to that degree of re-examination by the Legal Aid Commission. I do not think anybody can be critical of that decision. I did not like how long it took and I am sure the Cambodians did not like how long it took, but that is the time it took. There was nothing I could do about it, other than to interfere in the process. For me to interfere in the process would have meant some form of challenge by somebody-presumably a lawyersuggesting that I had interfered and therefore had jeopardised their rights. The shadow Minister's point that some time should be allowed for these processes to be put in place is a valid point and is being looked at. I remind the House that a lot of comments were made by people about the status of these folk. Honourable members will recall a lot of comments coming out of Darwin when I attempted to move people into a, central position-all together in the one centre. Port Hedland was mentioned. I was threatened with Federal Court action. I was accused of moving all these people against their will. Suggestions were made that it would be dreadful to deny them the offers of legal help that were being made by people in Darwin. In Darwin, I agreed to allow the 26 or 27 lawyers to handle the cases there. I said, 'All right, I will not move these people because I do not want to go the Federal Court; I want to get on with the job of processing'. Twelve months later J had to move eight of them to Sydney because the good old lawyers had yet to mat- interview eight or nine of them. Mr Bradford-A tough job.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The honourable member can shake his head and laugh and say that it is a tough job. It is damned tough for these people. We have the Chief Minister, church leaders, land councils, local government people and all these other support organisations saying, 'Don't you dare move these people or we'll lie in front of the buses'. What did I do? I agreed to their requests, yet 12 months later eight or nine Cambodians are still to be even interviewed by a lawyer. I agree that something has to be done about the length of time this processing takes. I hope to be able to negotiate that with the Opposition and with the interested parties-that is, the Refugee Council of Australia and other respected bodies that I am sure the shadow Minister also respects. As to the people I moved from Sydney to Darwin the other day, as I said in the House, I have an obligation when these people are given a decision-bearing in mind they have not legally entered the country-to ensure that they do not move into the broader community at this point. The only secure facility available to us at that time was in Darwin. I talked to the people. I suggest that some of the people who have been stirring this up-I repeat, stirring this up-ought to do the right thing by the Cambodian people. If there were a lot less stirring and a lot more honesty, there would be a lot less heartbreak and worry by people connected with the Cambodian community. Nobody has been deported. The Cambodian people are entering into a period where they are able to seek a review of the decision. They have 28 days. I resent some of the more outrageous things that have been said about myself, departmental officers and the system that has been applied here. Nowhere else in the world would we get a fairer, more detailed system than that which we have operating here. Some of these more outrageous statements by people who, in some cases, live a long way away from the centre in Sydney where the people were moved from-and therefore, I suggest, have little knowledge of the background-would do well to be less emotive and sensational and stick basically to the facts. I think they would do the Cambodians a lot more good. The Cambodian community, which speakers on the other side talked about, will be given a fair go. I will see that get a fair go. The system will be maintained. The system is fair; everybody will get a fair go. I will not be bullied by people stirring up communities and turning up at demonstrations. I have told the community that I will not defer from the laid-down process. I repeat: some people have done a great injustice to the Cambodian people. I thank those members of the Government and the Opposition who took part in the drafting of the Bill. We are attempting to do a range of things to make things easier and better and to improve the system. I note the comments of the shadow Minister in relation to the consultations that he and I had. I would hope to be able to continue that sort of cooperation with the shadow Minister in regard to legislation that I bring in here. We will not always be able to agree; I think that is understood. Briefings by the Department to keep him abreast of what we do is a proper way to proceed. I would like to see that continue. I look forward to him continuing to cooperate in the way in which he has. It is of benefit to me, as I have said before, to have in place the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, of which members of the Opposition, including the shadow Minister, are members. From a point of view of policy that comes into the Parliament, that is proving to be an excellent process. Sometimes it is somewhat frustrating for me-I am sure the shadow Minister knows what I am referring to-and for the Committee. The workload that it has is immense and covers a number of issues. Sometimes I might get a bit frustrated over the speed with which things get to me, but it is conducting public inquiries and hearings. From time to time it is confronted with more submissions and information than it thought it would have to handle when it began to look into some particular issues. Under the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) as Chairman and the honourable member for Dundas as Deputy Chairman, the Committee has been a great help to me. I repeat: I will continue to cooperate with the shadow they Minister whenever I can. Like him, I reserve the right to disagree with the Committee, as I reserve the right to disagree with the Opposition. I will conclude on that point because we need to move to the committee stage. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. The Bill.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Melbourne-Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs) (9.48 p.m.)-by leave-I move: (1) Clause 2, page 1, omit the clause, substitute the following clause: Commencement "2. (5) Clause 8, page 5, after paragraph (g) insert the following paragraphs: "(ga) by omitting from subparagraph (2) (b) (ii) 'particular.' and substituting 'particular; or'; (gb) by adding at the end of paragraph (2) (b) the following subparagraph: '(iii) the person made, or caused to be made, a false or misleading statement in a declaration covered by subsection 34 (1A).';". Section 24 of the Principal Act is In Committee amended by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection: '(1A) If the applicant is a non-citizen, a form approved for the purposes of subsection (1) must: (a) require the applicant to make a declaration about his or her character or conduct, or both; or . (b) if the form so requires-require another person to make a declaration about the applicant's character or conduct, or both.'. Grant or refusal of entry permits "9B. Section 34 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection: '(1A) If: (a) the applicant is a non-citizen; and (b) the regulations provide for the approval of a form for the purposes of applications under subsection (1); the form approved must: (c) require the applicant to make a declaration about his or her character or conduct, or both; or (d) if the form so requires-require another person to make a declaration about the applicant's character or conduct, or both.'.". (7) Clause 19, page 12, omit the clause. I address my remarks to the additional amendments to the original proposal, circulated in my name. I repeat my thanks to the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), for the cooperation and dialogue that we have had in regard to these amendments. He will address two amendments that he has circulated in his name, to which, unfortunately, I cannot agree at this point. I understand that the Opposition is embracing amendments (1) to (7). It is important for the Committee to take on board the fact that there was some dialogue among the shadow Minister, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and myself on this issue. It is very important that immigration, where possible-because it concerns people-is dealt with in a bipartisan way. Whilst there are two amendments coming forward from the Opposition, I have explained by way of letter to the shadow spokesman that we cannot agree to those proposals at this point. The other amendments, which are explained in the explanatory memorandum, are quite procedural in nature and are agreed to by the Opposition. I gather they are also agreed to by honourable members on this side of the chamber because they have not rushed in here to disagree with them. I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that this Bill and the amendments to it will come into effect by proclamation rather than by royal assent. That is important because it allows the Department time to address machinery matters within the running of government. Because of time constraints and the degree of urgency for the shadow Minister to have some of the five minutes allowed him, I will sit down and let him formally move his two amendments and talk to them briefly. However, as he knows at this point, the Opposition amendments are not agreed to by the Government. Amendments agreed to.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Dundas) (9.53 p.m.)by leave-I move: (1) Clause 20, page 12, lines 14 and 15, omit "28 days", substitute "21 days". (2) Clause 20, page 12, line 17, omit "70 days", substitute "50 days". (3) Clause 21, page 12, line 38, omit "28 substitute "21 days". (4) Clause 21, page 12, line 39, omit "70 days", substitute" 50 days". In speaking briefly to these amendments, I will reiterate what I said when I spoke during the second reading debate. These amendments are to substitute 28 days, where that appears, with 21 days, and 70 days, where it appears, with 50 days. It may seem somewhat obscure, but the purpose of the amendment is to ensure that there are two stages for the appeal process-a first tier review and a second tier review. Under the regulations as they previously applied, the Government had periods of 70 days and 28 days for both stages of that process in which people could lodge their appeals-28 days if they were in Australia or 70 days if they were outside Australia-and they had review rights. Effectively the Government has now extended that period to both stages of the process. That will increase the periods from 28 days to 56 days and 70 days to 140 days. The Opposition's view is that those periods ought to be reduced. The effect of the amendments is to reduce them to 100 days, if people are overseas, and 42 days if they are onshore. Those periods, in keeping with the original scheme put forward by Senator Ray, seem very reasonable to the Opposition. That is why I press the matter. In relation to matters canvassed by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), I appreciate him giving me information about legislation and briefing me on it. I undertake to ensure that the Minister is advised of matters which the Opposition is looking to amend to see where agreement can be reached. If we are going to talk about nationals of the People's Republic of China (PRC), it is important that the Minister lets me know where any of my comments might mislead people into believing they are able to stay. Mr Hand-You're adding to the confusion.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I do not intend to do that. If the Minister can clarify the way in which my comments might do that, I days", would find it valuable because I would move to correct it. On the other side of the coin, I believe the Minister's real difficulty in assuring people that promises will be honoured is that while there are no amendments to the law to give people rights that can be enforced, the Minister cannot expect that I, as the Minister's successor-assuming he lasts that longwill be there to accept the promises he has given. I have made it very clear that the Opposition-Mr Hand-On a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman: I think the implication behind that comment that I will not be here to fulfil the four-year term is a slur and a dreadful thing to say. The Government's commitment to the PRC nationals will be honoured because I will still be here and will able to do it. That is where the honourable member for Dundas adds to confusion in the community.
