Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I move: That regulations 17, 19, 28 and 31 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), contained in Statutory Rules 1991, No. 60, made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed. The purpose of the disallowance motion is not to disallow the whole of the regulations made on 10 April 1991-in effect, most of those were of a technical character and give effect to changes foreshadowed by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) in recent statements, including the tightening of procedures for the entry of spouses and de facto spouses of Australian residents and the validation and use of profiles for assessing bona fides of entrants, particularly visitors, the use of which had been challenged by immigration tribunals-but rather to disallow those provisions which will allow for entry of homosexual partners of Australian citizens or permanent residents. It was somewhat difficult to discover these provisions in the regulations. The provisions that we are looking at were described, I think somewhat euphemistically, in the explanatory memorandum in these terms: To provide for the grant of permanent residence to a person (and the dependent children of such a person) who has established a genuine and continuing non-familial interdependent relationship with an Australian citizen or permanent resident. Those regulations, which have been made and which we are seeking to disallow, give effect to provisions for entry for people who are described as being in a continuing, non-familial, interdependent relationship and essentially deal with non-family members who are in an association, in an interdependent relationship, with an Australian citizen or permanent resident. Orders One can only assume that it is on the basis outlined in the regulations themselves that people will be allowed to obtain entry: that is, the person must be sponsored by an Australian citizen or permanent resident; the person cannot be a member of a family unit or another relative of the applicant; and the person must indicate that, with a person of the same sex, they are in fact residing together, closely interdependent, and having a continuing commitment to mutual, emotional and financial support. They must satisfy the Minister that the relationship is genuine, that it has existed for a period of at least six months and that it will continue. Essentially, those arc the criteria that have to be satisfied. It in fact involves very new principles on which the Government of this country has now embarked. I want to make clear on behalf of the Opposition a number of points at first. This issue deals with the migration of homosexual partners, and the Opposition's approach to homosexual migration has been, and remains, that no applicant for immigration under any of the available categories for entry now in place should bc discriminated against because of his or her sexual preference. Our concern is, rather, that there should not be specific provisions in which people are advantaged and able to access migrant entry purely on the basis of their homosexuality. That is in fact what is being sought. We in the Opposition have recognised in the past that there has been consideration given to a limited number of homosexual partners being granted entry on the basis of strong and compassionate grounds where ministerial discretion has been exercised. The best explanation of the basis upon which rules have previously been administered in the past was in answer to a question by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) to the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). It is recorded i:p the Hansard of the House of Representatives on 11 May 1989. There, the then Minister spelt out, I think, the principles which I have asserted here to.night and which I believe ought to be maintained. If Government members believe they ought to be maintained, they would support our motion for disallowance. The then Minister, when dealing with that matter, was asked this question: What procedures must be followed before homosexuals may enter Australia as immigrants and become Australian citizens? He said: People are not prevented from migrating, nor from obtaining citizenship, because they are homosexual. The procedures applying to homosexuals are identical to those applying to any other applicants: that is, for migrant entry they must satisfy policy requirements for the category under which they are applying and they must meet health and character requirements; for citizenship they must meet residential and othcr requirements, including a good character requirement. Homosexual relationships are not equated with marriages or heterosexual de facto relationships for migration purposes. He went on to say: An Australian citizen or resident cannot sponsor a homosexual partner under the criteria relating to spouses and heterosexual de facto partners. Nor is the homosexual partner of a principal applicant eligible as the "spouse" of that person. In relation to a second question he said: An individual's sexual orientation is not a relevant factor in considering an application grant entry and hence may not be known department, and is not recorded. He also added: There is no special program through which osexuals may enter Australia and become citisexual entry. zens. However, once in Australia the homosexual partners of Australian citizens or residents may apply for a grant of resident status. In answer to some specific points in tion to that, the then Minister recorded the basis on which strong and compasbipartisan sionate grounds under section 6A (1) (e) of the Migration Act could proceed. In relation to homosexual partners were lodging applications, he had this say: . . . Applications . . . lodged in Australia homosexual partners of Australian residents citizens who have entered Australia as visitors or temporary residents . . . Where an application for entry as a temporary resident on the basis of a relationship is lodged overseas, it is submitted to the Minister for personal consideration, compassionate entry may be accorded. He went on to say: Applications for GORS on strong compassionate grounds based on a homosexual relationship have bccn considered personally by successive Ministers . . . He also indicated that the Opposition was acquainted with the fact that such matters had been dealt with in that way. In answer to that question, he also outlined that some 265 applications had been considered and approved on that basis between September 1985 and January 1989. It is a matter of some knowledge of members of this Parliament and the public generally that discretionary entry, on the basis of strong and compelling compassionate grounds having been established, has been used as a basis for considering cases in the past where claims have been made by homosexual partners that they might be allowed entry. There have been claims put forward from time to time that the framework of law ought to be changed and there ought to be a much more rigid legal regime in place and that homosexual partners ought to be considered on such a basis. The former Minister for Local Government, for miImmigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator to my Ray, looked at this question when he brought in the new migration regulations. He sought to put in place a regulation homwhich prescribed a visa class for homoWhen that particular visa class was brought forward, the matter was considered by the Joint Standing Committee on relaMigration Regulations. The Joint Committee, like the present Committee, was a one made up of members on both sides of this Parliament. I think those of us who were members of it at that time who were the honourable member for Parkes to and myself, but the Committee comprised six Government members, I believe, a by lesser number of members of the Oppoand sition and an Australian Democrat. The Committee's view was reported in paragraph 3.21, where it said: It's the Committee's view that the provision of specific category of visa for homosexuals docs not reflect current policy or practice. The Committee argues that, although homosexuals should not be discriminated against for migrant cntry, neither should they be specifically advantaged. In the past in exceptional cases where an application is based on a relationship with a strong and compelling compassionate ground, or like grounds which apply to all relationships, entry has been allowed. It went on: Section 64u, if amended in accordance with the Committee's recommendations, would give the Minister an adequate discretion to admit those applicants who would have applied under this category. The Committee therefore recommends that: - the homosexual visa category and the consequential definition be deleted from the draft regulations. Former Minister Ray took the Committee's view and took that particular regulation out. For the sake of completeness, I add that the Committee stated: . . . some members of the Committee are of the view that a general "companionship" category should be provided where a sexual relationship is not necessarily involved. The exclusivity and duration of the relationship, its closeness mutual dependency would be relevant considerations. Members who put that forward had in mind that it might apply to the proverbial two maiden aunts who had strong emotiona1 ties. If the Government was going to put in place a broader category, their case might be one which would justify such a broader category. If that is what the Minister had in mind, he did not adopt it, because what he put in place are provisions which exclude familial relationships, so the case of the two maiden aunts, which is one that the Committec had in mind-I might say a minority of the Committee-would not have been accommodated under these new arrangements. I want to make a number of the Opposition's positions clear in relation to this matter. I have made the point a number of times now that the Opposition's view is that there should not be discrimination against people on the basis of their sexual preference, but that there should not be specific advantage for people based upon that factor, either. We are aware that ministerial discretion has been exercised in the past to admit a limited number of homosexual partners on compassionate grounds. We are of the view that those arrangements should remain in place; in other words, we are not demurring in relation to the fact that that discretion has been exercised in the past. We believe it is appropriate that such claims should still be possible and, I might say, if the review rcgulations are drawn in such a way to deny the Minister the opportunity to exercise such discretion, it would be our view, as the Committee put forward, that an amendment should be made to ensure that section 64u is able to operate to give the Minister that discretion. When I refer to section 64u, I mean the new provisions of section 115 of the Act, which embodies that section when it was first dealt with. The fact is that the Opposition does not believe that the issue of a visa on the basis of a homosexual relationship alone ought to be possible. We take the view and that to treat the relationship of homosexual partners on exactly the same basis as the relationship between a husband and wife creates a precedent of considerable significance. The fact is that the new arrangement moves to do exactly that. De facto partners have to prove a mere sixmonth relationship in order to seek entry on the basis of that relationship. The new regulations for homosexual partners, as I read them, require a relationship. of that duration. It used to be a duration of four years. The Minister reduced it to two years, and now it has to be a relationship of only six months. This is a precedent. Homosexual partners are not treated as spouses for tax purposes. They are not treated as spouses for the payment of social security benefits or other family based benefits; but if they are to be permitted migrant entry on the basis that their relationship is the equivalent of a family relationship-that is, a relationship of husband and wife-it is a precedent of very considerable moment. It disadvantages numbers of other people who seek migrant entry. I do not know how many people will apply on this ground. I do not know that the Minister will be in a position to control, as he might have in the past, how many people might apply under this ground. I mentioned that there were some 265 applicants in the space of several years, but it could run into thousands over time, particularly as we have seen the propensity of people to seek to apply on fraudulent grounds as spouses or de facto partners. People might seek to establish sham homosexual relationships. That is a distinct possibility under the provisions that are now being put in place. Mr Hand-That is what your proposal gets them to do.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I do not think it does at all; it specifically denies it. The point I am making is that if the Minister puts in place provisions that take it essentially out of his control, unless he is intending that in relation to the granting of these visas he will not delegate his responsibility to other officers, it will be essentially out of his hands; it will be in the hands of whoever exercises that delegation throughout Australia. That is a matter the Minister may care to clarify, if he is going to respond to this. I want to make the point, finally, because time is running out, that this visa class comes into the visa class for family members. That means that every homosexual partner who will be accommodated has the potential for displacing one other family member under the concessional family migration scheme. The fact, essentially, is that we have three streams. The first relates to family migration, the second to skilled migration, and the third to refugees. They each have a number of places allocated to them. The homosexual partners will fall into the family stream-60,000 this year. People who come into the preferential arrangements get their place as of right. But at the end of the day, if the total number of people for family places is going to exceed the total number allocated within the program, the program is capped. That means that every homosexual partner who obtains a place in the program, and particularly if it is demand driven, as it has the potential to be, displaces other family members who might be able to come within the concessional family reunion arrangements. They are the family members who have to be points tested. They are the brothers and sisters of Australian citizens and residents. They are the nephews and nieces of Australian citizens who can apply under the concessional family reunion arrangements. So what we are saying to large numbers of people who seek to access family reunion and are excluded is that the relationship involving homosexual partners is one of greater value than the familial relationships we have all known and understood. The· Opposition does not seek to discriminate against homosexuals. We seek to have these provisions disallowed and to put in place the arrangements that would enable the Minister to look individually at each case and exercise discretion on the basis of his judgment, as he has in the past, as to those cases that demand, because there is a compassionate and compelling element, that entry be granted, but only on that basis. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs SulIivan)-Is the motion for disallowance seconded? Mr Aldred-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: Melbourne-Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs) (10.26 p.m.)-Allow me, on behalf of the Government, to oppose the proposal that has been put forward by the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Firstly, I welcome this debate because I think there is already a misinformation campaign under way. That is unfortunate, and I will attempt, by way of my comments, to allay some of the fears the shadow Minister outlined. Secondly, I hear that some Opposition members were betting that we would not proceed with this. We are proceeding with it, on the basis that we are trying to establish a fair system. I want to go to one particular point that deals with decisions made by the Minister, to which I think the shadow Minister was referring in his comments. The regulations do not specify that the Minister personally makes decisions as to whether or not an interdependency visa or entry permit may be granted. However, I will not delegate this power. I will therefore personally be making decisions under the interdependency category, and I will undertake to inform the Parliament if in the future such power is proposed to be delegated. I make that commitment on behalf of the Government. I hope that that allays some of the fears the shadow Minister has. Mr Ruddock-And report on the numbers.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I hear the interjection and I will respond to him directly as to the practicality of that request. It should also be noted that as primary decision-maker I am bound by the rules in the regulations. It is only after the applicant has sought a review of the primary decision that I as Minister have a broader discretionary power under sections 115 and 137 of the Migration Act. In terms of the health area, I want to make a couple of points that I think need to be put on record. All applicants for an interdependency visa or entry permit must be assessed under the health criteria. The safeguard that now exists in the regulation applies not only to the conditional twoyear or permanent entry permit but also to those who are overseas and wish to enter Australia on a temporary basis under the interdependency visa category. It should also be noted that the regulations allow for the waiver of the health criteria in certain limited situations. The waiver of the health criteria provisions, under regulation 144, however, is subject to the following conditions: that the applicant is free of tuberculosis and other communicable diseases which are a threat to public health; is free of other diseases that are a danger to members of the Australian community; and is unlikely to prejudice the access to health care of any Australian citizen or resident. Further, as Minister I am not able to exercise discretion under regulation 144 unless I am satisfied that undue harm or undue cost would be unlikely to result to the Australian community if the visa entry permit is granted. I make those two points because they really go to the hub of what the shadow spokesman said and what other people have been indicating by their comments outside of this place. As the shadow spokesman has addressed the question of homosexual relationships, we need to put some facts in this area before the House. Firstly, on 25 July 1990, I wrote to the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), advising him of my intention to reinstate arrangements for the grant of permanent residence to homosexual partners on the grounds of non-familial relationship of emotional inter-dependency. No formal reply was received and the Secretary to the Committee indicated that the Committee did not wish to comment. This issue has now been placed fairly and squarely before the Parliament. Regulations, which are fair, have been put in place. We now have a proper process in place. The contradiction in the shadow Minister's comments are that we oppose a process being put in place that may disadvantage others and we want to leave in place a flawed system. The presumption he makes is that the previous system that my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) put in place will continue. That previous system ceased on 19 December 1989. There is currently no process. I am putting regulations in place, retaining ministerial control over the area, as requested by the shadow spokesman, and applying a proper process. I am amazed at the line being run by the Opposition. It wants me to continue the late night candle burning exercise of signing agreements for people to enter the country and to pretend it is not happening. That is the basis of the claims or requests of the shadow spokesman when he says, (We would like to return to the old way, the old system, the old flawed system'. It is flawed because it is not out in the public where it ought to be. As the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I am not prepared to have a system which we on this side of the House pretend does not exist and somehow are ashamed of. I am not ashamed of it. I will not be party to some late night signing racket. It has to be out where people can see it and people can judge it, and where the decisions can be properly made in a proper process. Mr Ruddock-It was out in the open.

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: It was not out in the open, and the shadow spokesman knows it was not out in the open. That is why the Opposition wants to push it back under the door again, back into the Minister's office, so that members opposite can all write their letters on behalf of their constituents to the Minister in order to get the Minister to use this discretion with which they are preoccupied. That, in itself, presents an unfair system. They want to pretend, 'Look, we really support this, but we don't support it publicly'. They cannot have their cake and eat it too, as it is said. It will not disadvantage people in the way in which the shadow spokesman outlined. It presents no more of a disadvantage than the system he advocates. How does it disadvantage other people when the shadow spokesman, in fact, advocates the maintenance of a system which is secret? This is out in the open, controlled by the Minister, whoever he or she may be, in a proper way. It can be no more of a disadvantage to anybody else than was the old system. We have this extraordinary proposition put by the shadow spokesman in which he suggests that people apply under some other section, such as that of a business migrant or an employer-nominated person, where they obviously do not meet the criteria; zingo, it goes through to the Migration Internal Review Office; and the Minister then has the power to use discretion and not be subject to the regulations. Mr Ruddock-I am sorry, the Act requires the Minister, when he exercises the discretion-

Speaker: Mr HAND
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: Because the shadow spokesman will not accept a proper process he, in fact, is encouraging, if we are goi-g to go down this route, a bodgic process. Not only does he want the old bodgie system in place but he also wants to suggest, 'Well, there's another way we can do it; we can do it by a bodgie process'. It is not on. The Opposition can come into this place and into the Senate and oppose this, but I will never return to the previous system. I know whose hearts on the other side are in this issue and whose are not. I know that some people on the other side agree with me, because they have told me, and I know some others do not. But I fail to see how those opposite, in all fairness to themselves and to the constituents about whom a number of honourable members opposite write to me, can want a return to the old flawed system. So this regulation is now clearly before us. I address myself also to the previous Minister, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports. He grappled with this issue. I note he is to speak in this debate. I was present and heard his comments in this place on the occasion of his answers to the honourable member for Parkes. In fact, I was very supportive of what the honourable member was attempting to put before the House on those occasions and of what was in the press release that he put out on 24 May 1988. But members opposite really are trying to return to something that is not possible. It is just not possible to go back to that system; nor is it right. These regulations will go forward to the Senate after tonight, because the Opposition's proposal, to put it bluntly, will be bowled over. I anticipate and hope that the Bill will be passed, because this is an honourable proposal. It is an honourable proposal in the sense that it puts before the public a proper process; it gives proper access to the system; and it is not a dreadfully flawed system which both sides of the House accept but is really not accepted publicly. I think the shadow Minister interjected when I referred to that before. There are some people who just pretend that this never existed, and he knows that. I think that is wrong. It covers a much broader range of situations than the narrow emphasis that both he and, I am sure, other speakers on the other side have given it. We all have had before us situationsto use his words-of a homosexual nature, which can be adequately addressed in this particular set of regulations. I regret that this matter has come before the House, although I do not run away from it. In fact, I think that probably it is time for an issue like this to be addressed in this way. But it was withdrawn on the last occasion when it was put before the Parliament. I believe that was not because the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, did not want to proceed with it. I think it was a matter of timing. There was a whole range of problems at that time in getting things before the Parliament, and he let it slide but knew full well-and I must add that the Department advised me very early onthat this matter had to be addressed. That was the understanding on which Senator Robert Ray did not proceed with it. I did hear comments from people, 'I think he'll be like Senator Robert Ray; he'll not proceed. Our notice to oppose this will frighten the Government off. It has not frightened us off; it is going to proceed. I suspect that members on the other side will welcome this proposal when it does finally go through the Senate because, as I said, I do know that some people really support the thrust of what' the Government is trying to achieve. I repeat that we cannot go backwards to an old system or request that we go back to an old system, which I think was a dishonest system. It would be dishonest now to go back to that system with the new structure that is in place. That is something we just cannot do. Therefore, I am quite happy to have this debate; I am quite happy to see members on both sides of the chamber discussing the issue. But I suspect, like every other time, the issue will get very narrow. I find it unfortun ate that the emphasis will be on one particular aspect of the regulations. However, if it is designed to try to frighten the Government, it will not. We will continue with it right through to the Senate. I have no difficulty with this proposal. I hope that people take notice of what we are trying to do here: that is, to bring increased integrity into this area. At the moment it must be remembered that from 19 December 1989 there is not an adequate way to address a range of people who would come forward unless we introduce these regulations, and that is very unfair. I have listened to what the shadow spokesman has had to say on this matter. I cannot agree with his comments. In fact, I gave him an undertaking that I would come back to him on one point, and I will.

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: Deakin) (10.41 p.m.)The House now has before it 45 proposed amendments to the Migration Regulations (Amendment) and, generally, the Opposition is supportive of the various changes involved. Both the Government and the Opposition obviously believe that clear guidelines need to exist in the operation of Australia's migration policy and that areas of potential abuse need to be most directly addressed. It is no exaggeration to say that the integrity of our immigration policy is a vital clement in safeguarding our national sovereignty. However, the Opposition finds it impossible to accept the proposed regulations Nos 17, 19, 28 and 31. Accordingly, my colleague, the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), has submitted a notice of motion, which states: That regulations 17, 19, 28 and 31 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment) contained in Statutory Rules 1991, No. 60, made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed. It is my pleasure to second the motion moved by my colleague, which I now formally do. On 30 April this year, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) announced a reduction of 15,000 persons in the overall annual migrant intake to Australia for \ 1991-92. This was supported by the Opposition, especially in view of Australia's current circumstances and acute recession. It is a move that I believe is also supported by public opinion throughout Australia. The regulations which the Opposition rejects-namely, Nos 17, 19,28 and 31provide for the granting of permanent residence to a person who has established a continuing non-family independent relationship with an Australian citizen or a permanent resident of Australia. May I say, firstly, it seems curious when most areas of immigration have been cut that an exception should be made to facilitate easier migratory rules for a category of people generally regarded as outside the mainstream of traditional values espoused by the Australian electorate. Although I and, I believe, most of my colleagues value the status of marriage as superior to that of a de facto relationship, a greater concern is that the entry into Australia of homosexual partners should formally be made easier, particularly-I repeat-shortly after the ministerial statement outlining cuts to the immigration program. Newspaper headlines at that time were consistent in their thrust. The Australian Financial Review had the headline on 30 April this year, 'Cabinet set to trim immigration'. In the Herald-Sun of 1 May, 'ACTU wins big cuts in migration' was the headline. The Melbourne Age of the same day had the headline, 'Labor to cut immigration by 12,500'. Another article in the Age, this time on 9 May, had a headline, 'Migrant category rejected for sake of economy'. Mr Hand-Madam Deputy Speaker, my point of order is on relevance. The press comments on the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) relating to the skills-migration category are probably a little wide of the mark in this debate. I draw that to your attention, Madam Deputy Speaker. There might be some skills involved in it, but I think that the reference by the media to the ACTU, which is being quoted by the honourable member, does not appear to be relevant to the debate before the House. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-I suggest that the honourable member for Deakin points out the relevance of the matters he has raised.

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: That will be forthcoming shortly. Why do we have a relaxation of rules for this special new category of migrants? The implication of the implementation of proposed regulations Nos 17, 19,28 and 31 is to formalise a new category of migrant. Previously, where strong and compelling compassionate reasons were shown, admission was allowed at the discretion of the Minister. The Opposition reaffirms that arrangement and totally rejects a classification by which a visa entry for Australia is based on a homosexual relationship. It is the Opposition's belief that to treat a homosexual partnership on exactly the same basis as a husband-wife relationship would create a dangerous precedent, as well as run completely contrary to all prevailing community values. As well as this, currently, while so many families are excluded entry to Australia under the family reunion scheme, a relaxed criterion involving six months or even less. of cohabitation for homosexual partners cannot be justified on grounds of fairness, reasonableness and equity. In addition, there are other dangers involved in the short term liaison period required of partners should this category of migrant become officially established. Here I refer to the disturbing numbers of scam marriages between Australian nationals and partners from other countries. One of these recent scams involved a company which operated for a number of years in Victoria, where fees up to $16,000 were being paid for marriages of convenience to enable Fijians and Indians to migrate to Australia. The sum of $4,000 went to the Australian partners, some of whom were mentally handicapped, and the rest to the Melbourne principals of this particular marriage-fixing racket. Millions of dollars were made over this period from customers applying through the company in Fiji. Imagine the implications if regulations Nos 17, 19,28 and 31 are passed by the Government-the homosexual liaison business might well be thriving in a very short time. Thrive it will, if the sham marriage racket already referred to is any guide. Not only is there the very worrying Victorian example referred to, but New South Wales has been blighted by a similarly disturbing problem. It appears that during 1990 the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs conducted a random survey of 848 marriage applications in New South Wales. Various criteria were used to measure which marriages were of a dubious nature, including the type of visa used, the spouse's background, clear and obvious differences between the couple, the gap between when they met and the marriage date, plus what was known about the marriage celebrant and, of course, that well known species, the migration agents involved. Subsequent analysis, using this criteria on the sample group, determined that 516, or 61 per cent, of the 848 selected cases were suspect. One then has to wonder why Australia should welcome, or even encourage, the type of migrant covered by regulations Nos 17, 19, 28 and 31, when decent people from countries with traditional values are finding it very difficult Australia as migrants. It would appear that the Hawke Labor Government cares little for tradition or sound community values. Mr Hand-Come on! What nonsense, and you know it. You know that under your own government you did it. Your own government did it.

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: It is a pity the Minister does not share the mainstream values of the Australian community. I conclude by confirming my belief that the great majority of people in Australia would, if they were able to, vote against the implementation of regulations Nos 17, 19,. 28 and 31, and the Minister knows that as well as we do. It therefore gives me pleasure to second the motion now before the House for the disallowance of these specific regulations.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: It is regrettable that the last speaker for and on behalf of the Opposition, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred), has really blurred and muddied the waters on an issue which is comparatively straightforward and simple. We are not dealing with a concept that is outside traditional values; what we are talking about is a regulation which initially involved the consideration of an applicant on the basis of their not being a member of a family unit but being a person who had a relationship with an applicant which was acknowledged by both and that involved residing together, being closely interdependent and having continuing commitment to mutual emotional and financial support. That concept can include a great variety of relationships. I dealt with a number of situations when I was Minister for immigration and I know of a number of situations currently. For example, there is an elderly woman who is blind and who has been cared for for many years by a non-Australian citizen; that relationship is not only mutually dependent but is basically a situation which would fall within the category we are discussing. I share with the shadow Minister, the to enter honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)-and, as long as I have known the honourable member, I would not say that he is unaware of traditional valuesthe view that people who are in homosexual relationships should have no more rights than the average citizen-but they should have no fewer rights. Mr Ruddock-That is what J said.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I am indebted to the honourable member for Dundas, who confirms that that is his position. I had the experience of being Minister when the method used was basically that of determining the rights of people applying where there was a homosexual relationship. That did not emerge just as a matter of a Minister waking up in the middle of the night and saying, 'We have to do something about homosexual relationships'; it arose on the basis of legal advice that the existence of a homosexual relationship could be a relevant factor for consideration under what was old section 6A (1) (e) of the Migration Act-that is to say, that this category of applicant had a legal right that had to be considered under the Act. In 1985 then Minister Hurford met with representatives of the gay immigration task force. He spoke to the then relevant shadow Ministers and a system was put in place where cases could be dealt with on the basis of ministerial discretion. What has occurred since then, of course, is virtually the abolition of ministerial discretion on the basis of a series of regulations which would determine the rights of all applicants for immigration. The Government has attempted, painstakingly, to produce a code, which can be subject to independent legal assessment, which confers rights upon applicants and provides a method of determining those rights. The question that we are being asked to determine is simply, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) says, whether applicants who are basing their application on the basis of a mutually interdependent relationship do so under the old system or whether they are brought into the broad stream category of regulation, where their rights are defined, their applications can be dealt with according to law and where they have no more and no fewer rights than any other citizen. Mr Aldred-That puts them on the same basis as a married couple, and you know that.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: The problem with the honourable gentleman is that not only docs he have a view about marriage but also he has substantial prejudices against anybody who does not conform to his notions of a traditional value. The difference between him and me on that issue is that I believe that in OUf community there are people who have emotionally dependent relationships. Mr Ruddock-For how long?

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: For substantial periods. Mr Aldred-You are opening up a whole new rort; you realise that, don't you?

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: The honourable member can call it a rort, but the difference between the view of the Opposition and the view of the Government is this: we believe that, to the extent to which this matter is governed by regulation, and rights are determined openly, frankly and publicly, that is to be preferred to a system where those opposite want to put the matter back in the closet. Mr Aldred-You want to open up a whole new series of rorts, all of which flourished in your time as Minister. Mr HOI"DING-If the honourable gentleman wants to indulge himself, let him. Unlike the honourable gentleman, as Minister for immigration I had the experience of making the decisions in these cases-and it is not a happy experience. The Minister is asked to go back to his office late at night or early in the morning and be confronted with a pile of files which can be quite substantial in which people arc asked to expose the full detail of their relationships and how the situation arose, going into very great detail. One accepts some and one rejects others, but the problem is, as the honourable Minister says, that is done in secret. I would hope and pray that the decisions that I made were just and proper decisions, but sometimes at 11.30 at night one may be tired and may make a legitimate error in judgment. That may favour the applicant or it may not. But in any event, if we are a mature society, it seems to me that we should support the attempt by the Minister to say that there ought to be a regulation which governs this process, that we have to get away from the system where, in order not to offend the fantasies and the vivid imagination of some of the honourable gentlemen opposite, we go back to a system which will say, 'We are pretty liberated people in the coalition; we do not have any basie problem about people applying on the basis of homosexual relationships'. Let me say quite frankly that, as Minister, I received as many applications-there may even have been a few more-forwarded by members on the other side of the House as on this side, so, whatever one says, there is certainly within the coalition people who do not share the prejudices of some of those that have spoken. What is important is that those who are applicants are dealt with within the framework of due process of the law. What is the problem? If in fact, as the honourable shadow Minister says, there is not any reaJ problem about there being a category of homosexual relationships, what is the problem about saying that there will be regulations, that those regulations will have to be complied with and that they are subject to objective public scrutiny, with all the relevant provisions that deal with that? That is preferable to saying to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who is at the table, 'We do not really want to go down that track; we would really prefer you to go back to your office at 11.30 tonight'-and in the case of the present Minister perhaps open a packet of cigarettes-'sit down, wade through a pile of files and make a determination'. If the Minister has had a hard day, he might be feeling that people do not require too much consideration but if he has had a win at the races he might be feeling generously disposed. Who is to know? Mr Aldred-Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am sure we are all very sympathetic to the long hours that the honourable member had to work when he was Minister for immigration, but I do not see that what he has to say now has much to do with the disallowance of these regulations. I ask you to direct him to return to the main game of the debate. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-I do not think there is a point of order.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: It has a great deal to do with it, for this reason: what the Minister is properly saying is that this category will be dealt with in the same way as every other applicant is dealt with-in a due process with a regulation that is open and public and where the matter can be dealt with within the framework of that. Because the sexual preferences of some honourable gentlemen opposite are offended by the concept of homosexuality-it is not a traditional value and certainly not one which appeals to the prejudices of some of the honourable gentlemen opposite-they say, 'Oh no, we must not deal with it openly. We will make the Minister go away and he can give his decision. Nobody will question that, and that will be all right'. Mr Ruddock-The Act does not permit it now.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: Opposition members are on the record as saying 'that that is the system they want to go back to. Mr Aldred-That is right.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: If they do not want to go back to it, they should tell us what they do propose. Mr Aldred-Exercise discretion under section 115.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I exempt the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), from this, but one of the problems about elements of the coalition on this whole question of immigration is that every now and then, if they want to take a populist position, they boot some class of applicant for immigration. It might be Asians, it might be the last group of arrivals or it might be homosexuals. It might be some other group. Mr Bradford-Let them all in; that is what you want to do-let them all in.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: If the honourable gentleman wants me to go into the detail of some of the members of his Party who were endorsed and took that view, I will be only too happy to entertain him; but I am not going to get into the exercise that he would prefer. As I said at the outset before he wandered in, I am not saying that homosexual people ought to have any fewer rights; but they should not have any more. It is a question of balance. The Minister is endeavouring to provide a due process. The Opposition does not know whether it wants a regulation, it does not know whether it wants to engage in good old-fashioned poofter bashing-it does not know where it stands. The Opposition talks about rackets, but it never knows where it stands. Does the honourable member want me to tell the names of some of his colleagues who wanted to sponsor this sort of activity at any level?

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: Yes. Name them.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I am not going to get into that exercise. I will tell him privately, and he knows them. As many applications came, they came to one or two individuals. I must say I have a higher regard for their integrity than I have for this slcazy exercise I am hearing from the honourable gentlemen opposite. If this process is eliminated, many people who would be proper applicants will be eliminated from entry. There is a whole range of categories. There can be an emotional dependency which is not necessarily a sexual one. People in that category also ought to be considered. This is a gap in the regulations and it ought to be dealt with. In my view the Minister has dealt with it in a responsible way, and I would suggest that members of the coalition ought to make up their minds whether they support the general view of the shadow Minister, who wants to go back to an old system which is flawed in many ways-and I know, because I had to try to operate it-or whether they want to abolish the whole concept. They have to make up their minds. The Parliament is at least entitled to know whether they are saying at one level they are opposed to any kind of-Mr Aldred-I raise a point of order. Would the honourable member advise us how the six-month liaison period is not going to open up a whole new area of scams and rOl'is? Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: The honourable gentleman would know more about scams and rorts. He lives off the concept of scams and rorts. When he goes to bed at night he dreams of scams and rorts. I do not know how many he has ever been involved in. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! Ml' HOLDING-If that is the area he wants to live in, he is entitled to live in it. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! Ml' Aldred-I would ask that the remark be withdrawn. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Yes. I ask that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports withdraw the remark. Ml' HOLDING-What? That he dreams about scams and rorts? Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-The honourable member will withdraw the implication in the statement that he made.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: MIGRATION REGULATIONS
text: I am just wanting to know what aspect. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Maybe the honourable member's tongue ran away with him, but I think it was the statement he made aftcr that. I ask the honourable member to withdraw the statement. Ml' HOLDING-If I have offended the honourable gentleman, I withdraw it. I would simply say this: everybody knows, including members of his own Party, that he is totally preoccupied with the concept of scams and rorts. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! The following answer to a question is 3169 of Hansard of 7 May 1991, Dental Decay (Question No. 550) Dr Bob Woods asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 February 1991: (1) What is the nature of the factor required for weighting to allow the Dental Statistics and Research Unit of the Australian Institute of Health to calculate weighted caries severity rates for 12 year old children for (a) 1986, (b) 1987, (c) 1988, (d) 1989 and (e) 1990. (2) Is a representativc national figure available of caries severity rates for the years listed in part (1). (3) What is the weighted caries severity rate for South Australia for (a) 1988 and (b) 1989. (4) Will he explain the formula developed by the Unit head, Professor John Spencer, some years ago to predict the future rates of dental decay. (5) How do Professor Spencer's predictions compare to the results of the Child Dental Health Survey on an annual basis. (6) With respect to the Unit, (a) when was it set up, (b) how is it funded, (c) what role does it play and (d) what arc its aims and priorities. (7) What is the importance of the calculation of dental caries severity rates for 12 year old Australian children.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Title: PAPER
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Caries severity has traditionally been measured by the Decayed, Missing and Filled Teeth (DMFT) Index. Observations for this measure are collected as part of the care of children by the School Dental Services of each State or Territory in Australia. When DMFT measures are being calculated for an age group, say 12 year Year NSW Vic. 1986 1.53 2.42 1987 1.29 2.13 1988 1.24 1.93 1989 1.32 1.54 * Preliminary estimates (3) See (2) above. However, when scores from all States and Territories are combined to calculate a national or Australian estimate, the scores from each State and Territory are weighted. The weights are numeric in nature and reflect the proportion of the Australian child population (aged 4-13 years) resident in each State or Territory. In the preliminary estimates of caries severity presented in the answer to ql,lestion (2), the same weight has been used for each of the years 1986,1987,1988 and 1989. These weights were: NSW 0.343; VIC 0.271; QLD 0.152; SA 0.086; WA 0.090; TAS 0.030; NT 0.010 and ACT 0.018. For 1990, the nature of the weighting will be similar, however, no national weighted estimates have been compiled for 1990. (2) No national figure of caries severity rates for 12 year old children has been published for the years 1986 (not for full year), 1987, 1988, 1989 or 1990. The Dental Statistics and Research Unit assumed responsibility for the Child Dental Health Survey data in March 1989. It has since obtained, from the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, the necessary data for 1986, 1987 and 1988 to calculate the national figure for the DMFT of 12 year olds. The sampling, data processing, analysis and reporting of caries severity was redesigned when the Dental Statistics and Research Unit assumed responsibility for the data collcction. One State, Western Australia, delayed introduction of the new data collection methods. Data have recently become available from all States and Territories allowing calculation of the national figure for 1989. The processing and analysis of data for 1990 will not be completed until mid 1991. Professor Spencer has qualifications in Children's and Preventive Dentistty, Public Health and Research. It was as part of Professor Spencer's research for a Doctor of Philosophy degree that work was undertaken on prediction of rates of dentai decay. This work was completed in 1984, although some scientific papers arising from it appeared in 1986 and 1987. Professor Spencer established a data set comprising all findings of mean caries severity of samples of Australian adolescents over the period 1965 to 1978; these included 21 studies involving survcys, clinical trials and analysis of service records of dental programs. Professor Spencer hypothesised that the age-specific DMFT scores, and in some cases scores for socio-economic groups at an individual age, could be explained by a number of predictor variables related to fluoride exposure such as proportion of lifetime exposure to water fluoridation, regular use of fluoride supplements and use of fluoride containing toothpaste. Hence, each mean DMFT score was linked in the data set to mean estimates of these fluoride predictor variables. The resultant cross-sectional time series data were analysed by multiple regression procedures and the results of how predictors had behaved in the past were used to extrapolate into the future. In order to estimate the caries severity in future years, Professor Spencer attempted to track patterns of exposure to the fluoride predictor variables, extrapolate their trends and apply estimates of their likely magnitude within the multiple regression model. In this way, estimates of future caries severity of Australian adolescents up to 1990 were calculated. In Professor Spencer's report on this work in 1984, he pointed out that his predictions were built on data reflecting all children, whilc the Child Dental Health Survey captures data only on children under the care of the School Dental Services. Hence, although the comparison is convenient, it is not necessarily an apt comparison. Biases may exist in terms of the children who are included in the dental care program of the School Dental Services. As the School Dental Services in most States and Territories were expanding, the nature of the social mix of the children whose caries severity was captured in the Child Dental Health Survey also changed across these years. In an article in the Australian Dental Journal in 1986, Professor Spencer reported that the steeper declinc in the Child Dental Health Survey data between 1979 and 1983 than predicted for all Australian 12 year old children may have indicated that factors other than fluoride, not included in the predictive model, may be associated with the greater decrease observed in the Child Dental Health Survey data. It used only data from the School Dental Service in South Australia. It is, thereforc, entirely appropriate in this case to comparc the research predictions with the subsequent data available from the South Australian School Dental Service which has, in the late 1980s, provided care for a relatively constant percentage of the child population at 12 years old. 3. Whereas Professor Spencer's earlier work was on understanding and tracking changes in fluoride exposure which in turn determined future caries severity, this more recent research uses changes between ages and across time to predict future caries severity. Hence, it does not seek to explain why caries severity is changing; it seeks only to understand how caries severity is changing. The data assembled for Sladc, Spencer and Dooland's work were again a sequential timc scries of cross-sectional surveys covering childrcn aged six to 12 years cared for by the South Australian School Dental Service between 1976 to 1988. Multiple regression analysis was used to cstimate age, cohort and period effccts within Adelaide and non-Adelaide parts of South Australia. The outcome was again a formula that could be used to predict future caries severity in each part of the State. Such changes would be bound to reduce the accuracy of the predictions. A further note of caution is necessary when interpreting estimates which are based on cxtrapolated data. It is always the case that a single estimate for any year represents a point within a range of figurcs, and any other figure within that range would constitute a statistically valid prediction. (6) (a) The Australian Institute of Health's Dental Statistics and Research Unit was set up in 1987 and began operating in 1988. The Dental Statistics and Research Unit is an external unit of the Australian Institute of Health, being located within the Department of Dentistry at the University of Adelaidc. (b) Its core funding comes from the Australian Institute of Health. Additional funding is obtained through compctiti vc application for research funds and contracted research. (c) The role of the Dental Statistics and Research Unit is to improve the range and quality of information available on the dental workforce, oral health, use of services and dcntal practice in Australia. The aims of the Dental Statistics and Research Unit are: 1. To establish a national minimum data set on dental personnel and provide descriptive statistics on labourforce activity; 2. To establish and maintain the national child dental health survey; 3. To provide information on all data available in Australia on the dcntal labourforce, dental practice, use of dental services and dental health status, facilitating reviews from time to timc; and Observed 4. To conduct supplementary research as DMFT deemed necessary. Child The priorities for the Unit rcflect the aims. Dental The areas of data collection, preparation, analysis Hcalth and reporting on the dental labourforce and oral Survey health status equally have highest priority, fol1.69 lowed by supplementary research and the broader 1.47 'clearing house' role on dental statistics. (7) The ready availability of basic planning information on the potential requirement for services is a major factor needed to improve the delivery of dental care and the dental health of Australian children. Monitoring the caries severity of Australian children and predicting future caries severity is an intcgral aspect of preparing information for such planning. This has become a major feature of the School Dental Services in Australia, through their evaluation and planning systems which draw upon the Child Dental Health Survey data. The School Dental Services seem to have overcome three cqmmon deficiencies in the use of caries severity' data for service planning. First, there is a general awareness of how such data might be used to improve the delivery of dental services within the School Dental Services. Second, the data which are collected are made accessible to the potential users, in an appropriate form, and without undue delay. Third, the skills necessary to manipulate and interpret such data arc usually available within the service environment. Data on dental caries severity are used to provide new insights and descriptions of what is known and what is predicted about the potential requirement for dental care for use in the planning of dental services. Improved data sources, methodology, and techniques of analysis and prediction provide a basis for better elucidation of the service delivery issues. The data also identify issues that require further study to gain a better understanding of problems, encouraging others to dispute and discuss findings. This process not only improves the information generated, but improves decision-making on the delivery of dental services. Effective planning is possible only if the circumstances under which decisions on the future are made can be predicted with reasonable accuracy. This is always difficult in the long term planning of dental health services. Estimates of the size and the structure of populations may be in error, while new understanding and developments in dental care may change patterns of disease and service requirements in fundamental ways. On the other hand, the provision of key resources in the delivery of dental health care, i.e. facilities and a trained dental labourforcc, are subject to substantial lead times. This paradox can only be resolved if the preparation of plans incorporates a wide range of assumptions about the future, and is an activity which is kept under continuous review as more recent information becomes available.
